definition: A mechanic whose occupation is to build mills, or to set uptheir machinery.
According to measure or proportion; proportionable;proportionate. [Obs.]
A made-up face; a grimace. "What mops and mowes it makes!"Beau. & Fl.
Obsequiousness; obedience. [Obs.] Evelyn.
See Melanotype.
The platform about the head of the mainmast in square-riggedvessels.
To call by a wrong title.
Having many faces.

The act of doing what magnificent; the state or quality ofbeing magnificent. Acts xix. 27. "Then cometh magnificence." Chaucer.And, for the heaven's wide circuit, let it speak The Maker's highmagnificence, who built so spacious. Milton.The noblest monuments of Roman magnificence. Eustace.
A man whose occupation is to make malt.
Having no mistrust or suspicion.The swain mistrustless of his smutted face. Goldsmith.
Pertaining to manufacturing.
A division of birds including the swifts and humming birds. Socalled from the length of the distal part of the wing.
To err in pleading.
A small abscess or tumor having a resemblance to a mulberry.Dunglison.
A person of modern times; -- opposed to ancient. Pope.
of Mote. Chaucer.
A female maker of, or dealer in, articles of fashion,especially of the fashionable dress of ladies; a woman who givesdirection to the style or mode of dress.
Of or pertaining to machines.
A fermented beverage made of honey and water; mead. Gay.
The middle segment of the thorax in insects. See Illust. ofColeoptera.
Bearing fruit but once; monocarpic.
To appropriate wrongly; to use for a wrong purpose.
The offspring of a white person and a quadroon; -- so called inthe West Indies. [Written also mustee.]
Erroneous conception; false opinion; wrong understanding.Harvey.
One who maunders.
An infinitesimal change in a varying quantity; an increment ordecrement. [Obs.]
Furnished with a mast or masts; -- chiefly in composition; as,a three-masted schooner.
The office or jurisdiction of a matriarch; a matriarchal formof government.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, CH2O2(CO2H)2, obtainedfrom amido malonic acid.
Unfortunate. [Obs.]
Inflammation of the spinal marrow or its membranes.
A mineral occurring in soft, lead-gray, foliated masses orscales, resembling graphite; sulphide of molybdenum.
Being about the middle of the ordinary age of man; between 30and 50 years old.
A kind of hard finish for plasterwork, made of plaster of Parisand marble dust, and capable of taking a high polish.
See Macrocosm. Croft.
Rubble masonry.
A handlelike process or part; esp., the anterior segment of thesternum, or presternum, and the handlelike process of the malleus.
The description of microscopic objects.
Having the ratio of the length to the breadth of the cranium amedium one; neither brachycephalic nor dolichocephalic.
Having but one person, or form of existence.
The quality or state of being mercenary; venality. Boyle.
To reduce to the smallest part or proportion possible; toreduce to a minimum. Bentham.
Erroneous or false belief.
Much; great. [Written also muckle and mockle.] [Old Eng. &Scot.] "A man of mickle might." Spenser.
of Mete, to dream. Chaucer.

An instrument containing a combination of colored glasses suchthat they transmit only red light, so that objects of other colors,as green leaves, appear black when seen through it. It is used forviewing colored flames, to detect the presence of potassium, lithium,etc., by the red light which they emit.

Pertaining to, or of the nature of, unrefined or raw sugar,obtained from the juice of the sugar cane by evaporating and drainingoff the molasses. Muscovado sugar contains impurities which render itdark colored and moist.
Pertaining to the maxillary and palatine regions of the skull;as, the maxillo-palatine process of the maxilla. Also used as n.
To have a mistaken notion of or about. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
One who monarchizes; also, a monarchist.
Of or pertaining to Mongolia or the Mongols.-- n.
One skilled in the theory or construction of machines; amachinist. Boyle.
One of a tribe of beetles (Malacodermata), with a soft andflexible body, as the fireflies.
A sporangium or conceptacle containing only large spores; --opposed to microsporangium. Both are found in the genera Selaginella,Isoctes, and Marsilia, plants remotely allied to ferns.
A flat-bottomed boat with a pointed prow and square stern,using oars or sails or both, used esp. on the upper Great Lakes andtheir tributaries.
A bit; a morsel.
Like mutton; having a flavor of mutton.
To magnify or extol. [Obs.] Marston.
A myodynamometer.
Pertaining, or suited, to the audition of small sounds; fittedto assist hearing.
Of or pertaining to the Monothelites, or their doctrine.
The god of war and husbandry.
Such as can be chewed; fit to be eaten. [R.]Any manducable creature. Sir T. Herbert.
Adhering to facts; not turning aside from absolute realities;not fanciful or imaginative; commonplace; dry.
The era in use in Mohammedan countries. See Mohammedan year,below.
One of the elementary granules found in blood. They are muchsmaller than an ordinary corpuscle, and are particularly noticeablein disease, as in an√¶mia.
The act of interpreting erroneously; a mistaken interpretation.
To think wrongly. [Obs.]
In a ministerial manner; in the character or capacity of aminister.
To give the wrong meter to, as to a line of verse. [R.]Chaucer.
A kind of garlic (Allium Moly) with large yellow flowers; --called also golden garlic.
A woman who milks cows or is employed in the dairy.
To get wrongfully. [Obs.]
Same as Miniver.
A maxim or saying embodying a moral truth. Farrar.
A building of masonry, generally circular, usually erected onthe seacoast, with a gun on the summit mounted on a traversingplatform, so as to be fired in any direction.
Mariolatry.
Single-voiced; having but one part; as, a monophoniccomposition; -- opposed to Ant: polyphonic.
, a thermometer for recording the lowest temperature since itslast adjustment.
A measure of electro-motive force; the millionth part of onevolt.
To cause to have a wrong inclination or tendency; to affectwrongly.
One of a sect, chiefly in Syria and Egypt, which acknowledgesthe authority of the pope, but adheres to the liturgy and ceremoniesof the Eastern Church.
A sudden vertigo in a horse, succeeded sometimes byunconsciousness, produced by an excess of blood in the brain; a mildform of apoplexy. Youatt.
The Infusoria.
In England, the hawthorn; in New England, the trailing arbutus(see Arbutus); also, the blossom of these plants.
The state of being a matron.

A subclass of Mammalia, having a cloaca in which the ducts ofthe urinary, genital, and alimentary systems terminate, as in birds.The female lays eggs like a bird. See Duck mole, under Duck, andEchidna.
Moist. [Obs.]

"Our Lord cometh;" -- an expression used by St. Paul at theconclusion of his first Epistle to the Corinthians (xvi. 22). Thisword has been used in anathematizing persons for great crimes; asmuch as to say, "May the Lord come quickly to take vengeance of thycrimes." See Anathema maranatha, under Anathema.
Having discomfort or misery; troubled. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To counsel or advise wrongly.
In a Magnificent manner.

In the southwestern part of the united States, a bullock orheifer that has not been branded, and is unclaimed or wild; -- saidto be from Maverick, the name of a cattle owner in Texas whonaglected to brand his cattle.
A South African carnivore (Cynictis penicillata), allied to theichneumons.
A coloring produced by the deposition of some metalliccompound; specifically, the prismatic tints produced by depositing afilm of peroxide of lead on polished steel by electricity.

The art of working metals, comprehending the whole process ofseparating them from other matters in the ore, smelting, refining,and parting them; sometimes, in a narrower sense, only the process ofextracting metals from their ores.
By way of derision; in a contemptuous or mocking manner.
Inflammation of the breast.
One who borrows personal chattels which are to be consumed byhim, and which he is to return or repay in kind. Bouvier.
Pertaining to the Monogynia; monogynous.-- n.
The quality or state of being mawkish. J. H. Newman.

Pertaining to, or obtained from, apples; as, malic acid. Malicacid, a hydroxy acid obtained as a substance which is sirupy orcrystallized with difficulty, and has a strong but pleasant sourtaste. It occurs in many fruits, as in green apples, currants, etc.It is levorotatory or dextrorotatory according to the temperature andconcentration. An artificial variety is a derivative of succinicacid, but has no action on polarized light, and thus malic acid is aremarkable case of physical isomerism.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a monogram.
Same as Marginate, a.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a metropolitan or thepresiding bishop of a country or province, his office, or hisdignity; as, metropolitan authority. "Bishops metropolitan." Sir T.More.
An optical apparatus in which pictures are viewed through alarge lens with stereoptical effects. It is often combined with thestereoscope.
A round-bottomed glass flask having a long neck; a bolthead.
A white amorphous or crystalline substance, obtained bydehydration of mannite, and distinct from, but convertible into,mannitan.
Things remarkable and worthy of remembrance or record; also,the record of them.
The kusimanse.

A genus of mintlike plants (Origanum) comprising about twenty-five species. The sweet marjoram (O. Majorana) is pecularly aromaticand fragrant, and much used in cookery. The wild marjoram of Europeand America is O. vulgare, far less fragrant than the other.
To go, or move (in a certain manner); -- usually with out, off,along, etc. [Colloq.]  E. N. Wescott.
Of or pertaining to Madrid in Spain, or to its inhabitants.-- n.
Of or pertaining to mental culture; serving to improve orstrengthen the mind. [R.]
Consisting of, or having, many lobes.
A white amorphous or crystalline substance obtained by thepartial dehydration of mannite.
To midwife. [Obs.]
A genus of grasses (Melica) of little agricultural importance.
Master; sir; -- a title of the Middle Ages, given to a personin authority, or to one having a license from a university to teachphilosophy and the liberal arts.
Doing evil, harm, or mischief.
One of the larger measures of electro-motive force, amountingto one million volts.
The great world; that part of the universe which is exterior toman; -- contrasted with microcosm, or man. See Microcosm.
A mercenary. [Obs.]
A Mohammedan crier of the hour of prayer. [Written alsomouezzin, mueddin, and muwazzin.]
The man who occupies a central position in a file of soldiers.

Pertaining to, connected with, produced by, or consisting of,molecules; as, molecular forces; molecular groups of atoms, etc.Molecular attraction (Phys.), attraction acting between the moleculesof bodies, and at insensible distances.-- Molecular weight (Chem.), the weight of a molecule of any gas orvapor as compared with the hydrogen atom as a standard; the sum ofthe atomic weights of the constituents of a molecule; thus, themolecular weight of water (H2O) is 18.
Sullen; displeased. [Obs.]
Silent and idle. [Colloq.]Boys can't sit mum-chance always. J. H. Ewing.
A prefix meaning pertaining to, produced by, or in some wayconnected with, magnetism.
One of a race of a brown or copper complexion in the MalayPeninsula and the western islands of the Indian Archipelago.
Improper. [Obs.] Spenser.
Round and without a cella; consisting of a single ring ofcolumns supporting a roof; -- said esp. of a temple.
A variety of sugar isomeric with sucrose, extracted from cottonseeds and from the so-called Australian manna (a secretion of certainspecies of Eucalyptus).
Consisting of, or having, many cells or more than one cell.
A woodcock.
Either one of two handles on the back of a piece of ordnance.
Melancholy. [R.] Milton.
See Marquee.
The quality or state of being movable; mobility; susceptibilityof motion.
The condition of being mendicant; beggary; begging. Burke.
The art of memory; a system of precepts and rules intended toassist the memory; artificial memory.
The act of uttering the sound of a mouill√© letter.

A breed of large dogs noted for strength and courage. There arevarious strains, differing in form and color, and characteristic ofdifferent countries. Mastiff bat (Zo√∂l.) , any bat of the genusMolossus; so called because the face somewhat resembles that of amastiff.
The art or process of coloring metals.
See Opal.
of Made. Chaucer.
To utter or give forth in low or indistinct words or sounds;as, to murmur tales. Shak.The people murmured such things concerning him. John vii. 32.
See Mimetite.
Erroneous observation. J. S Mill.

Capable of being extended or shaped by beating with a hammer,or by the pressure of rollers; -- applied to metals. Malleable iron,iron that is capable of extension or of being shaped under thehammer; decarbonized cast iron. See under Iron.-- Malleable iron castings, articles cast from pig iron and mademalleable by heating then for several days in the presence of somesubstance, as hematite, which deprives the cast iron of some of itscarbon.
To make malign or malignant. [R.] "A strong faith malignified."Southey.
To supply with money. [Obs.]

A gentlewoman; -- an appellation or courteous form of addressgiven to a lady, especially an elderly or a married lady; -- muchused in the address, at the beginning of a letter, to a woman. Thecorresponding word in addressing a man is Sir.
Belonging to the Malacopterygii.
Crystalline on a fine, or microscopic, scale; consisting offine crystals; as, the ground mass of certain porphyrics ismicrocrystalline.
Like a mammilla or nipple; mammilliform.
A small flat bastion, raised in the middle of an overlongcurtain.
Containing larval tapeworms; -- said of pork and beef.
Same as Personate.
To time wrongly; not to adapt to the time.
See Matross. [Obs.]
One who governs alone.
The act or process of increasing to the highest degree.Bentham.
Same as Mescal.
A mosque.
The doctrine that there is but one immortal soul or intellectwith which all men are endowed.
Having many rays.
A crime less than a felony. Wharton.
A gambling game in vogue in the eighteenth century. Thackeray.
Of or pertaining to a monopolist. North Am. Rev.
A soft thin silk fabric with a weave like that of muslin.
Having many poles; -- applied especially to those ganglionicnerve cells which have several radiating processes.
In a municipal relation or condition.
A large stone; especially, a large stone used in ancientbuilding.-- Meg`a*lith"ic, a.
A name of certain curious orchids which bear three kinds offlowers formerly referred to three genera, but now ascertained to besexually different forms of the same genus (Catasetum tridentatum,etc.).
One who soliloquizes; esp., one who monopolizes conversation incompany. De Quincey.
Of or pertaining to the metapodialia, or to the parts of thelimbs to which they belong.
Raised; high. [Obs.]
An instrument for recording minor fluctuations of atmosphericpressure, as opposed to general barometric surges.
The principal mast in a ship or other vessel.
Related to or resembling the marsupials; furnished with a pouchfor the young, as the marsupials, and also some fishes and Crustacea.
A trailing plant (Lysimachia Nummularia), with rounded oppositeleaves and solitary yellow flowers in their axils.
One who petitions by a memorial. T. Hook.
Erroneous thought; mistaken opinion; error. [Obs.] Spenser.

A class of peculiar organisms, the slime molds, formerlyregarded as animals (Mycetozoa), but now generally thought to beplants and often separated as a distinct phylum (Myxophyta). They arefound on damp earth and decaying vegetable matter, and consist ofnaked masses of protoplasm, often of considerable size, which creepvery slowly  over the surface and ingest solid food. --Myx`o*my*ce"tous (#), a.
The protoplasmic matter of which bacteria are composed.
A composer of fables.
A sort of coarse or light cotton cloth.
Same as Manometer.

The act of changing place or posture; esp., the act of changingone's dwelling place or place of business. Moving day, a day when onemoves; esp., a day when a large number of tenants change theirdwelling place.

A general term for certain kinds of fabrics, which are formedof two series of threads interlacing each other, thus forming doublecloth, quilted in the loom; -- so named because first made inMarseilles, France.
A meeting for mirth.

An aniline dye obtained as an amorphous substance having agreen bronze surface color, which dissolves to a shade of red; also,the color; -- so called from Magenta, in Italy, in allusion to thebattle fought there about the time the dye was discovered. Calledalso fuchsine, rose√Øne, etc.
To dissatisfy. [Obs.]
The fault of improperly uniting in one bill distinct andindependent matters, and thereby confounding them. Burrill.

. (Bot.) A perennial plant of the genus Caltha (C. palustris),growing in wet places and bearing bright yellow flowers. In theUnited States it is used as a pot herb under the name of cowslip. SeeCowslip.
The marrow of bones; the deep or inner portion of an organ orpart; as, the medulla, or medullary substance, of the kidney;specifically, the medula oblongata.
Of or pertaining to the mesoscapula.
The state or quality of being mediate. Sir W. Hamilton.
A genus of reef corals abundant in tropical seas. It includesthan one hundred and fifty species, most of which are elegantlybranched.-- Mad`re*po"ral, a.
The state or condition of being marshy.
To set pr place wrongly.
A genus of trees, some species of which produce edible fruit;the mulberry. See Mulberry.
The art of prolonging life.
One of an extinct sect, named after Ludovic Muggleton, anEnglish journeyman tailor, who (about 1657) claimed to be inspired.Eadie.
Low, wet ground; a marsh; a fen; a bog; a moor. [Archaic]Milton. Tennyson.
Of or pertaining to macrospores.
Of or resembling the moon; symbolized by the moon. "Sharpeningin mooned horns." "Mooned Ashtaroth." Milton.
The quality or state of being mute; speechlessness.
The quality or state of being manly.
To rule badly; to misgovern.
An ideal machine; a combination of movable bodies constitutinga machine, but considered only with regard to relative movements.
Fine white bread; a loaf of fine bread. [Archaic] Bacon.Tennyson.
The state of being a mother; the character or office of amother.
False resemblance or semblance. [Obs.]
An extinct Miocene mammal of the Horse family, closely relatedto the genus Anhithecrium, and having three usable hoofs on eachfoot.
A king and lawgiver of Crete, fabled to be the son of Jupiterand Europa. After death he was made a judge in the Lower Regions.

One of certain public pawnbroking establishments whichoriginated in Italy in the 15th century, the object of which was tolend money at a low rate of interest to poor people in need; --called also mount of piety. The institution has been adopted in othercountries, as in Spain and France. See Lombard-house.
The office of a minister. Swift.
Having the qualities of honey. [R.]
One who engraves in mezzotint.
An old Anglo Saxon coin both of gold and silver, and ofvariously estimated values. The silver mancus was equal to about oneshilling of modern English money.
Multitudinous.
A sail sometimes carried in light winds, above a skysail. R. H.Dana, Jr.
A hypothetical radical, CH3O, analogous to hydroxyl.
In the manner of a martyr.
To act the part of a malingerer; to feign illness or inability.
Such as can be mined; as, minable earth. Sir T. North.
Arrayed, prepared, or furnished, unsuitably. [Archaic] Bp.Hall.
Consisting or partaking of marl; resembling marl; aboundingwith marl.
Giving admonition; instructing by way of caution; warning.Losses, miscarriages, and disappointments, are monitory andinstructive. L'Estrange.
Pertaining to, or resembling, pearl; pearly.
A master in any art, especially in music; a composer.
History of the evolution of forms; that part of ontogeny thatdeals with the germ history of forms; -- distinguished fromphysiogeny. Haeckel.

A fatty substance, extracted from animal fats and certainvegetable oils, formerly supposed to be a definite compound ofglycerin and margaric acid, but now known to be simply a mixture orcombination of tristearin and teipalmitin.
Manuscript. [Obs.]
A prism of an orthorhombic crystal between the macropinacoidand the unit prism; the corresponding pyramids are calledmacropyramids.

A strong nitrogenous base, C3H6N6, produced from severalcyanogen compounds, and obtained as a white crystalline substance, --formerly supposed to be produced by the decomposition of melam.Called also cyanuramide.
To misgraft. [Obs.] Shak.
Musty; moldy; slimy; mucous.-- Mu"cid*ness, n.
See Mohammedanism.
The quality of being miry.

One of the twelve portions into which the year is divided; thetwelfth part of a year, corresponding nearly to the length of asynodic revolution of the moon, -- whence the name. In popular use, aperiod of four weeks is often called a month.
To eat or prey upon, as a moth eats a garment. [Rarely usedexcept in the form moth-eaten, p.p. or a.]Ruin and neglect have so moth-eaten her. Sir T. Herbert.
The quality of being mucky.
pl. of Man.
Containing many nuclei; as, multinuclear cells.
Bromine; -- formerly so called from its being obtained from seawater.
An officer who ascertains meres or boundaries. [Eng.]
The seed of the opium poppy.
One of the lower or outer jaws of arthropods.
A measure of length; the thousandth part of one millimeter; themillionth part of a meter.
A variety of pyroxene.

A name given to several species of Arctostaphylos, but mostlyto A. glauca and A. pungens, shrubs of California, Oregon, etc., withreddish smooth bark, ovate or oval coriaceous evergreen leaves, andbearing clusters of red berries, which are said to be a favorite foodof the grizzly bear.
An instrument for determining the size or distance ofinaccessible objects by means of two reflectors on a common sextant.
Erroneously.
Being on a small; much reduced from the reality; as, aminiature copy.

The female of a ray or skate, esp. of the gray skate (Raiabatis), and of the thornback (R. clavata). [Prov. Eng.] Fair maid.(Zo√∂l.) See under Fair, a.-- Maid of honor, a female attendant of a queen or royal princess; -- usually of noble family, and having to perform only nominal orhonorary duties.-- Old maid. See under Old.
To misguide. [Obs.]
Situated most nearly in the middle; middlemost; midmost. [Obs.]" 'Mongst the middest crowd." Spenser.
Overgrown with moss.
To tell erroneously.
Having a mind of a jester; foolish. Shak.
The land belonging to a lord or nobleman, or so much land as alord or great personage kept in his own hands, for the use andsubsistence of his family.My manors, rents, revenues, l forego. Shak.

Of or pertaining to, or being in, the middle of a ship. Midshipbeam (Naut.), the beam or timber upon which the broadest part of avessel is formed.-- Midship bend, the broadest frame in a vessel. Weale.

A change in the form or function of a living organism, by anatural process of growth or development; as, the metamorphosis ofthe yolk into the embryo, of a tadpole into a frog, or of a bud intoa blossom. Especially, that form of sexual reproduction in which anembryo undergoes a series of marked changes of external form, as thechrysalis stage, pupa stage, etc., in insects. In these intermediatestages sexual reproduction is usually impossible, but they ultimatelypass into final and sexually developed forms, from the union of whichorganisms are produced which pass through the same cycle of changes.See Transformation.

A genus of large eels of the family Mir√¶nid√¶. They differ fromthe common eel in lacking pectoral fins and in having the dorsal andanal fins continuous. The murry (Mur√¶na Helen√¶) of Southern Europewas the mur√¶na of the Romans. It is highly valued as a food fish.
One of a group which includes the higher orders of mammals,having a large size as a typical characteristic.
Very strongly; mightily; to a great degree. [Obs.] Bacon. Shak.
See Murnival.
The middle portion, or body, of the sternum.
A covering placed over the upper part of a horse's head.
To acquire desert; to gain value; to receive benefit; toprofit. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
The millionth part of a farad.
Of the color of red or vermilion. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Manganic. [Obs.]
A generalized concept of magnitude.
One of a sect, in the ancient church, who maintained that thehuman and divine in Jesus Christ constituted but one compositenature. Also used adjectively.
A myriapod with many legs, esp. a chilognath, as thegalleyworm. [Written also millipede and milliped.]
The principles of, or preference for, monarchy.

To kill in considerable numbers where much resistance can notbe made; to kill with indiscriminate violence, without necessity, andcontrary to the usages of nations; to butcher; to slaughter; --limited to the killing of human beings.If James should be pleased to massacre them all, as Maximian hadmassacred the Theban legion. Macaulay.
Such as can be mounted.
One of the three classes into which the fungi are divided inBrefeld's classification. -- Mes`o*my*ce"tous (#), a.
Manlike; not womanly; masculine; bold; cruel. [Obs]Are women grown so mankind Must they be wooing Beau. & Fl.Be not too mankind against your wife. Chapman.
Of or pertaining to the morning; early.
A grotesque head or face, used to adorn keystones and otherprominent parts, to spout water in fountains, and the like; -- calledalso mascaron.
The quality or state of being mealy.

Less; requiring to be subtracted; negative; as, a minusquantity. Minus sign (Math.), the sign [-] denoting minus, or less,prefixed to negative quantities, or quantities to be subtracted. SeeNegative sign, under Negative.
Mistress. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Improperly appreciated.
Capable of assuming a molten state; meltable; fusible. [Obs.]

One of the forms in which bacteria group themselves; a more orless thick layer of motionless but living bacteria, formed by thebacteria uniting on the surface of the fluid in which they aredeveloped. This production differs from the zo√∂loea stage of bacteriaby not having the intermediary mucous substance.
A leper. [Obs.] [Written also meazel, and mesel.] Wyclif (Matt.x. 8. ).
Having very dark or black hair; black-haired. Prichard.
Moderation in doctrines or opinion, especially in politics orreligion.
The quality or state of being moist.
One who minces.
A mop or sponge attached to a jointed staff for swabbing out acannon.
A genus of ranunculaceous plants (Myosurus), in which theprolonged receptacle is covered with imbricating achenes, and soresembles the tail of a mouse.
Mountain.
Analysis of the structure of materials from careful observationof photomicrographs.
The quahog.
Of or pertaining to Monogynia; having only one style or stigma.
See Manilla, 1. Sir T. Herbert.
Of or pertaining to Machiavel, or to his supposed principles;politically cunning; characterized by duplicity or bad faith; crafty.
A variety of pyroxene, from the Mussa Alp in Piedmont;diopside.

The handling or government of anything, but esp. of a horse;management; administration. See Manege. [Obs.]Young men, in the conduct and manage of actions, embrace more thanthey can hold. Bacon.Down, down I come; like glistering Pha√´thonWanting the manage of unruly jades. Shak.The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl. Shak.
Mysterious. [Obs.]
A large field tent; esp., one adapted to the use of an officerof high rank. [Written also markee.]
Wrong ordination.
Wild; crack-brained.
Raining in very small drops.
Same as Mimicry.
In a mixed or mingled manner.
To join unfitly or improperly.
Leprosy. [Obs.] R. of Brunne.
A wry face. "Make mows at him." Shak.
A stone serving the same purpose as a milepost.
To write incorrectly.
A wasting away of flesh; decay. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Like a maiden; modest; coy.
The office or character of a mediator.
A substance, present in the protoplasm of the retinalepithelium cells, and resembling, if not identical with, thesubstance (myelin) forming the medullary sheaths of nerve fibers.
Same as Thomsonite.
A genus of marine gastropods, having rough, and frequentlyspinose, shells, which are often highly colored inside; the rockshells. They abound in tropical seas.
Mashed; brewed. [Obs.] Shak.
Modeate; temperate. [Obs.]
Small-leaved.
To cover, as part of a rope, with marline, marking a pecularhitch at each turn to prevent unwinding. Marling spike. (Naut.) Seeunder Marline.
One who, or that which, malaxates; esp., a machine forgrinding, kneading, or stirring into a pasty or doughy mass. [R.]
, Melanistic.
An evil deed; artifice; enchantment. [Obs.]
The rise of a hawk after prey. Sir P. Sidney.
See Mangcorn.
The method or spirit of the Middle Ages; devotion to theinstitutions and practices of the Middle Ages; a survival from theMiddle Ages. [Written also medievalism.]
Marked with spots of different colors; variegated; spotted; as,mottled wood. "The mottled meadows." Drayton.
Containing one carboxyl group; as, acetic acid is amonocarbonic acid.
One versed in minerals; mineralogist. [R.]
The act of diminishing, or the state of being diminished;diminution. [Obs.]
To measure or estimate incorrectly.

An order of large, extinct, marine reptiles, found in theCretaceous rocks, especially in America. They were serpentlike inform and in having loosely articulated and dilatable jaws, with largerecurved tteth, but they had paddlelike feet. Some of them were overfifty feet long. They are, essentially, fossil sea serpents withpaddles. Called also Pythonomarpha, and Mosasauria.

My lord; -- a title in France of a person of high birth orrank; as, Monseigneur the Prince, or Monseigneur the Archibishop. Itwas given, specifically, to the dauphin, before the Revolution of1789. (Abbrev. Mgr.)
In a military manner.
Of or pertaining to the mesencephalon or midbrain.
Being in the middle, or nearest the middle; midmost.
To cast off; to molt.Have I muted all my feathers Beau. & Fl.
The middle one of the three principal basal cartilages in thefins of fishes.-- Me*sop`ter*yg"i*al, a.
A slattern; a mawk. [Prov. Eng.]
Imposing a pecuniary penalty; consisting of, or paid as, afine.Fines, or some known mulctuary punishments. Sir W. Temple.

A simple form of moving-picture machine in which the series ofviews, exhibiting the successive phases of a scene, are printed onpaper and mounted around the periphery of a wheel. The rotation ofthe wheel brings them rapidly into sight, one after another, and theblended effect gives a semblance of motion.
Monoecious.
Capability of motion; contractility.
A market place. [Obs.] Drayton.

A tree of the genus Acer, including about fifty species. A.saccharinum is the rock maple, or sugar maple, from the sap of whichsugar is made, in the United States, in great quantities, byevaporation; the red or swamp maple is A. rubrum; the silver maple,A. dasycarpum, having fruit wooly when young; the striped maple, A.Pennsylvanium, called also moosewood. The common maple of Europe isA. campestre, the sycamore maple is A. Pseudo-platanus, and theNorway maple is A. platanoides.
Of or pert. to a microphone; serving to intensify weak sounds.
To recite erroneously.
Of or pertaining to the Monoecia; monoecious.-- n.
pl. of Medium.
Composed of convex convex concretions, somewhat resembling thebreasts in form; studded with small mammiform protuberances.
A kind of four-stringed lute.
To describe wrongly.
A native or natives of Madagascar; also (sing.), the language.
Melodrama.
To traffic. [Obs.] Bacon.
Of or pertaining to millions; consisting of millions; as, themillionary chronology of the pundits. Pinker
Bold; forward; impudent; saucy; pert. Shak.-- n.
A woman who assists other women in childbirth; a femalepractitioner of the obstetric art.

Of or pertaining to money, or consisting of money; pecuniary."The monetary relations of Europe." E. Everett. Monetary unit, thestandard of a national currency, as the dollar in the United States,the pound in England, the franc in France, the mark in Germany.

That science, or class of sciences, which treats of the exactrelations existing between quantities or magnitudes, and of themethods by which, in accordance with these relations, quantitiessought are deducible from other quantities known or supposed; thescience of spatial and quantitative relations.
Having missed stays; -- said of a ship.
One who, or a work which, narrates wonderful things; one whowrites of wonders. [Obs.] Bacon.
See Misspense. Bp. Hall.
A prefix denoting a thousandth part of; as, millimeter,milligram, milliamp√®re.
Wrong practice.
By merit; deservedly.
Very liberal in giving or bestowing; lavish; as, a munificentbenefactor.-- Mu*nif"i*cent*ly, adv.
One of the posterity of Moab, the son of Lot. (Gen. xix. 37.)Also used adjectively.
A genus of small Arctic fishes. One American species, thecapelin (Mallotus villosus), is extensively used as bait for cod.
Leprosy; also, a leper. [Obs.]

A heavy locomotive for freight traffic, having three pairs ofconnected driving wheels and a two-wheeled truck. Great, or Grand,Mogul, the sovereign of the empire founded in Hindostan by theMongols under Baber in the sixteenth century. Hence, a very importantpersonage; a lord; -- sometimes only mogul. Dryden.
A line above or below a hanging net, to which the net isattached in order to strengthen it.

A device utilized in the making of a loud-speaking telephone,depending on the fact that the friction between a metallic point anda moving cylinder of moistened chalk, or a moving slip of paper, onwhich it rests is diminished by the passage of a current between thepoint and the moving surface. -- Mo`to*graph"ic (#), a.
A form of double monster, in which two individuals are unitedby a common umbilicus.
The wife or the widow of a marquis; a woman who has the rankand dignity of a marquis. Spelman.

A hydrocarbon radical, CH2, not known in the free state, butregarded as an essential residue and component of certain derivativesof methane; as, methylene bromide, CH2Br2; -- formerly called alsomethene. Methylene blue (Chem.), an artificial dyestuff consisting ofa complex sulphur derivative of diphenyl amine; -- called also pureblue.
Capital letters, as found in manuscripts of the sixth centuryand earlier.
Appropriate or peculiar to a mandarin.
The middle or inferior horn of each lateral ventricle of thebrain. B. G. Wilder.

To treat with malice; to show hatred toward; to abuse; towrong; to injure. [Obs.]The people practice what mischiefs and villainies they will againstprivate men, whom they malign by stealing their goods, or murderingthem. Spenser.
In the manner of the Middle Ages; in accordance withmedi√¶valism.
Erroneous disposal or application. Bp. Hall.
A magpie. [Obs.] Shak.
Unbecoming. Milton.-- Mis`be*com"ing*ly, adv.-- Mis`be*com"ing*ness, n. Boyle.
See Mewl, and Miaul.
A piece of parchment bearing the Decalogue and attached to thedoorpost; -- in use among orthodox Hebrews.
A cutaneous disease characterized by numerous tumors, ofvarious forms, filled with a thick matter; -- so called from theresemblance of the tumors to some molluscous animals. Dunglison.
Marriageable.[Obs.]

The enriched block or horizontal bracket generally found underthe cornice of the Corinthian and Composite entablature, andsometimes, less ornamented, in the Ionic and other orders; -- socalled because of its arrangement at regulated distances.
One given to mysticism; one who holds mystical views,interpretations, etc.; especially, in ecclesiastical history, one whoprofessed mysticism. See Mysticism.
The act or process of matriculating; the state of beingmatriculated.
See Musicomania.
Of or pertaining to Melanesia.
Wrong treatment.
A leper. [Obs.]
One who acts in, or writes, melodramas.
One of a group of wading birds (Macrodactyli) having very longtoes. [Written also macrodactyle.]
Of or pertaining to the middle of the ethmoid region or ethmoidbone.-- n. (Anat.)
A common American minnow (Fundulus majalis). See Minnow.
Wrong conduct; bad behavior; mismanagement. Addison.
Disposed to mutiny; in a state of mutiny; characterized bymutiny; seditious; insubordinate.The city was becoming mutinous. Macaulay.-- Mu"ti*nous*ly, adv.-- Mu"ti*nous*ness, n.

A large stork of the genus Leptoptilos (formerly Ciconia), esp.the African species (L. crumenifer), which furnishes plumes worn asornaments. The Asiatic species (L. dubius, or L. argala) is theadjutant. See Adjutant. [Written also marabu.]
Commiseration. [Obs.]

A dwelling house, with the adjacent buildings and curtilage,and the adjoining lands appropriated to the use of the household.Cowell. Bouvier.They wedded her to sixty thousand pounds, To lands in Kent, andmessuages in York. Tennyson.
Of or pertaining to a moranie.
Metagenetic.
Fond of woman. [R.] Charles Reade.
Half-rotten straw, or any like substance strewn on the ground,as over the roots of plants, to protect from heat, drought, etc., andto preserve moisture.
In a mad manner; without reason or understanding; wildly.
A twelfth part of the heavens; a house. See 1st House, 8.Chaucer.
A small European falcon (Falco lithofalco, or F. √¶salon).
Wet; moist; as, a madid eye. [R.] Beaconsfield.
A somewhat aromatic composite weed (Artemisia vulgaris), at onetime used medicinally; -- called also motherwort.
Such as can be managed or used; suffering control; governable;tractable; subservient; as, a manageable horse.

The act of manifesting or disclosing, or the state of beingmanifested; discovery to the eye or to the understanding; also, thatwhich manifests; exhibition; display; revelation; as, themanifestation of God's power in creation.The secret manner in which acts of mercy ought to be performed,requires this public manifestation of them at the great day.Atterbury.
Having the form of a miter, or a peaked cap; as, a mitriformcalyptra. Gray.
Divided into many parts; having several parts.
One of a class of Mohammedans in Malabar.
Malediction; curse; execration. [Poetic]God's malison on his head who this gainsays. Sir W. Scott.
Of or pertaining to Majorca.-- n.
Unseasonable or unseasonably; unsuitable or unsuitably.
A false persuasion; wrong notion or opinion. Dr. H. More.
A genus of small rodents, including the common mouse and rat.
The science which treats of the chemical properties, actions orrelations of substances in quantity; -- distinguished from micro-chemistry.
A feigning to believe; make believe. J. H. Newman.
A publication which appears regularly once a month.
Infected with the mange; scabby.
genus of marsupials including the common kangaroo.
Customs; habits; esp., customs conformity to which is more orless obligatory; customary law.

The process of repeating, or adding to itself, any given numberor quantity a certain number of times; commonly, the process ofascertaining by a briefer computation the result of such repeatedadditions; also, the rule by which the operation is performed; -- thereverse of division.
That part of anatomy which treats of muscles.
Having the properties of a nonmetal; nonmetallic; acid;negative.
A genus of small, polished, marine univalve shells, native ofall warm seas.
The hard pearly internal layer of several kinds of shells, esp.of pearl oysters, river mussels, and the abalone shells; nacre. SeePearl.

Any one of series of compounds, hydrosulphides of alcoholradicals, in composition resembling the alcohols, but containingsulphur in place of oxygen, and hence called also the sulphuralcohols. In general, they are colorless liquids having a strong,repulsive, garlic odor. The name is specifically applied to ethylmercaptan, C2H5SH. So called from its avidity for mercury, and othermetals.
See Murenger. Jacob.
See 1st Manilla, 1.

An extract of quassia licorice, fraudulently used by brewers inorder to economize malt and hops. Craig. Hard multum, a preparationmade from Cocculus Indicus, etc., used to impart an intoxicatingquality to beer.
To rehearse or quote incorrectly. Sir T. More.

To treat (cotton fiber or fabrics) with a solution of causticalkali. Such treatment causes the fiber to shrink in length andbecome stronger and more receptive of dyes. If the yarn or cloth iskept under tension during the process, it assumes a silky luster. --Mer`cer*i*za"tion (#), n.
One who is versed in the science of morphology.
A coat made of match-cloth.
Of or pertaining to the middle portion of the nasal region.
Pert. to Mendel, or to Mendel's law. -- Men*de"li*an*ism (#),Men*del"ism (#), n.
Of or pertaining to a monolith; consisting of a single stone.
To trouble; to disturb; to render uneasy; to interfere with; tovex.They have molested the church with needless opposition. Hooker.
Bearing or having a motto; as, a mottoed coat or device.
Magneticalness. [Obs.]
To measure. [Obs.]
One of the side ropes to the gangway of a ship. Totten.
Mesaticephalic.
Obedient. [Obs.]

Adherence to a peculiar style or manner; a characteristic modeof action, bearing, or treatment, carried to excess, especially inliterature or art.Mannerism is pardonable,and is sometimes even agreeable, when themanner, though vicious, is natural . . . . But a mannerism which doesnot sit easy on the mannerist, which has been adopted on principle,and which can be sustained only by constant effort, is alwaysoffensive. Macaulay.
Disposition to threaten. [R.]
The privelege granted to a town of having a public market.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, methyl;specifically, designating methyl alcohol. See under Methyl.

A large heavy knife resembling a broadsword, often two or threefeet in length, -- used by the inhabitants of Spanish America as ahatchet to cut their way through thickets, and for various otherpurposes. J. Stevens.
Mesenteric.
Like or pertaining to the Macrura.
A sweet liquor; mead. [Obs.] Chaucer. Milton.
The science which treats of the means of increasing theintensity of low or weak sounds, or of the microphone.
To count erroneously.
Illumined by the moon. "The moonlit sea." Moore. "Moonlitdells." Lowell.
Mustache.
A camera in which a number of plates can be exposed withoutreloading.
In a magisterial manner.

A government vessel employed for the purposes of war, esp. oneof large size; a ship of war. Man-of-war bird (Zo√∂l.), The frigatebird; also applied to the skua gulls, and to the wandering albatross.-- Man-of-war hawk (Zo√∂l.), the frigate bird.-- Man-of-war's man, a sailor serving in a ship of war.-- Portuguese man-of-war (Zo√∂l.), any species of the genus Physalia.See Physalia.
Having the spirit of a male; vigorous; courageous. [R.] B.Jonson.
Theft; cheating. [Obs.] Gower.
To daub; to make dirty; to soil; to defile.Thou ... doest thy mind in dirty pleasures moil. Spenser.
Amount; sum; quantity; extent. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The Thursday in Passion week, or next before Good Friday.
A group of very lowly organized, wormlike parasites, includingthe Dicyemata. They are found in cephalopods. See Dicyemata.
A larval crustacean in a stage following the nauplius, andhaving about seven pairs of appendages.
Furnished with muscles; having muscles; as, things wellmuscled.
Having the orbital index relatively small; having the orbitsbroad transversely; -- opposed to Ant: megaseme.
One who mingles.
To behave ill; to conduct one's self improperly; -- often usedwith a reciprocal pronoun.

Any one of several very large extinct species of wingless birdsbelonging to Dinornis, and other related genera, of the suborderDinornithes, found in New Zealand. They are allied to the apteryx andthe ostrich. They were probably exterminated by the natives beforeNew Zealand was discovered by Europeans. Some species were muchlarger than the ostrich.
To place in a wrong order, or improper manner.
A macaw.
The bare end of the nose between the nostrils; -- used esp. ofruminants.
Having many heads or many stems from one crown or root. Gray.
The fruit of the oak and beech, or other forest trees; nuts;acorns.Oak mast, and beech, . . . they eat. Chapman.Swine under an oak filling themselves with the mast. South.
Any agent detrimental to, or destructive of, the life ofmicrobes or bacterial organisms.
The quality of being minute.
Relating to the mesoblast; as, the mesoblastic layer.

Perplexed with turns and windings; winding; intricate;confusing; perplexing; embarrassing; as, mazy error. Milton.To range amid the mazy thicket. Spenser.To run the ring, and trace the mazy round. Dryden.
One who methodizes.
A measure of surface in the metric system containing tenthousand ares, or one million square meters. It is equal to about247.1 acres.
That which is a month old, or which lives for a month. [R.]Wordsworth.
The act of magnifying; enlargement; exaggeration. [R.]
A female malefactor. Hawthorne.
Barley or other grain, steeped in water and dried in a kiln,thus forcing germination until the saccharine principle has beenevolved. It is used in brewing and in the distillation of whisky.
Magnet. [Obs.] Spenser.
Large-eared.
See Malodor.
A genus of parasitic or saprophytic plants including the Indianpipe and pine sap. The name alludes to the dropping end of the stem.
One of the Myogalod√¶, a family of Insectivora, including thedesman, and allied species.
A fixed part of a module. See Module.
A species of jalap, of very feeble properties, said to beobtained from the root of a species of Convolvulus (C. Mechoacan); --so called from Michoacan, in Mexico, whence it is obtained.

In an internal-combustion engine with two or more cylinders, aninduction coil and vibrator placed in the circuit between the batteryor magneto and the coils for the different cylinders, which are usedwithout vibrators of their own.
An absorption of one estate, or one contract, in another, or ofa minor offense in a greater.
Quality of being magnetic.
The tenth month of the French republican calendar dating fromSeptember 22, 1792. It began June 19, and ended July 18. SeeVend√âmiaire.
Murder. [Obs.] Farfax.
Any Asiatic pheasant of the genus Lophophorus, as the Impeyanpheasant.
Assuagingly.
A transparent pyx, in which the consecrated host is exposed toview.
A transition from one subject to another.
In a muscular manner.
The long silky hair or wool of the Angora goat of Asia Minor;also, a fabric made from this material, or an imitation of suchfabric.
A stinking tobacco.
A salt of mellitic acid.
A small fish of the Mediterranean; a gilthead. See Gilthead(a).
See Macroprism.
An unsect which feeds on mucus, or the sap of plants, ascertain Diptera, of the tribe Mucivora.
To make muscular. Lowell.
Anything used for healing diseases or wounds; a medicine; ahealing application.

(Bot.) A cherry tree (Prunus Mahaleb) of Southern Europe. Thewood is prized by cabinetmakers, the twigs are used for pipe stems,the flowers and leaves yield a perfume, and from the fruit a violetdye and a fermented liquor (like kirschwasser) are prepared.
Timid; fearful.-- Me*tic"u*lous*ly, adv.
The common mallow.
The system of Malthusian doctrines relating to population.
A marksman. [Obs.] Shak.
Having powers of self-motion, though unconscious; as, themotile spores of certain seaweeds.
The god of dreams.
A monoplastic element.
See Menge.
To render wrongly; to translate or recite wrongly. Boyle.
Not easy; painful. [Obs.]
A native house servant in India. Balfour (Cyc. of India).
To mix; to mingle; to meddle. [Written also medly.] [Obs.]Chaucer.
To cloud; to cover with mist; to dim. Shak.
Belonging to, or affecting, a single organ, or set of organs.
The millionth part of an ohm.
Busy in making or contriving marriages; as, a matchmakingwoman.
A kind of intercolumniation in an entablature, in which onlyone triglyph and two metopes are introduced.
Of or pertaining to the metanephros.
An animal which imitates something else, in form or habits.
Magisterialness; authoritativeness. [R.] Fuller.
The state of being a mother; the character or relation of amother.
To cause to become mechanical.

Evils; wrongs; offenses against right and law. Mala in se Etym:[L.] (Law), offenses which are such from their own nature, at commonlaw, irrespective of statute.-- Mala prohibita Etym: [L.] (Law), offenses prohibited by statute,as distinguished from mala in se, which are offenses at common law.
A substance of variable composition, but resembling a soft,dark-colored metal, used in the bearings of machines for obviatingfriction, and as a substitute for lubricants.
To bring into a state of mesmeric sleep.
See Meter.
A stammerer. [Obs.]

An optical effect, sometimes seen on the ocean, but morefrequently in deserts, due to total reflection of light at thesurface common to two strata of air differently heated. The reflectedimage is seen, commonly in an inverted position, while the realobject may or may not be in sight. When the surface is horizontal,and below the eye, the appearance is that of a sheet of water inwhich the object is seen reflected; when the reflecting surface isabove the eye, the image is seen projected against the sky. The fataMorgana and looming are species of mirage.By the mirage uplifted the land floats vague in the ether, Ships andthe shadows of ships hang in the motionless air. Longfellow.
To happen ill or unluckily. Spenser.
A puppet; a doll; originally, an idol, because in the MiddleAges it was generally believed that the Mohammedans worshiped imagesrepresenting Mohammed. [Obs.] Wyclif. Beau. & Fl.
In a mercenary manner.
Of or pertaining to the Muses, or to Poetry. [R.]
See Misprize. [Obs.] Shak.
A stone designating a limit or boundary; a landmark. Bacon.
Having the form of the breast; breast-shaped.
Mastology. See Mammalogy.
A large stone set upright in olden times as a memorial ormonument. Many, of unknown date, are found in Brittany and throughoutNorthern Europe.
Diminution; a species of hyperbole, representing a thing asbeing less than it really is.
A certain measure of distance, being equivalent in England andthe United States to 320 poles or rods, or 5,280 feet.
Biting; corrosive. [R.] Holland.
A chronoscope.
Mistaken devotion.

A name of several maritime grasses, as the sea sand-reed(Ammophila arundinacea) which is used in Holland to bind the sand ofthe seacoast dikes (see Beach grass, under Beach); also, the LygeumSpartum, a Mediterranean grass of similar habit.
The master or superintendent of a mint. Also used figuratively.
Sourly; with sullen austerity.

An element obtained by reduction of its oxide, as a hard,grayish white metal, fusible with difficulty, but easily oxidized.Its ores occur abundantly in nature as the minerals pyrolusite,manganite, etc. Symbol Mn. Atomic weight 54.8.

A name given to several varieties of Old World grapes,differing in color, size, etc., but all having a somewhat muskyflavor. The muscat of Alexandria is a large oval grape of a paleamber color. [Written also muskat.]
One versed in magnetism.
Capable of miscarrying; liable to fail. [R.] Bp. Hall.
Of or pertaining to myopathia.
A subterranean repository for wheat.
The smallest part of any substance which possesses thecharacteristic properties and qualities of that substance, and whichcan exist alone in a free state.
One who makes dresses, cloaks, etc., for women; a dressmaker.
One who makes merriment or indulges in conviviality; a jovialcomrade.
Of or pertaining to a meatus; resembling a meatus. Owen.
The Unicorn, a constellation situated to the east Orion.
A product of metabolism; a substance produced by metabolicaction, as urea.
Having parts, as leaves, arranged in many vertical rows.
Diminutive for Mouse. Burns.
A surface decoration made by inlaying in patterns small piecesof variously colored glass, stone, or other material; -- called alsomosaic work.
Act or recreation of riding in or driving a motor car orautomobile.
A kind of large field beet (B. macrorhiza), used as food forcattle, -- by some considered a mere variety of the ordinary beet.See Beet. [Written also mangold-wurzel.]
Producing honey.
A military officer of high rank; a marshal. [Obs.]
In a marked emphatic manner; -- used adverbially as adirection.
To mate wrongly or unsuitably; as, to mismate gloves or shoes;a mismated couple.
The millionth part of a meter.
A kind of pantograph which produces copies microscopicallyminute.
A mammonite.
Minced meat; meat chopped very fine; a mixture of boiled meat,suet, apples, etc., chopped very fine, to which spices and raisinsare added; -- used in making mince pie.
The dagger held in the left hand, while the rapier is held inthe right; -- used to parry thrusts of the adversary's rapier.
A name given by coppersmiths to an alloy of copper, tin, iron,etc., usually called white metal. [Written also matt.]
A Franciscan friar.

Formerly, a kind of drama having a musical accompaniment tointensify the effect of certain scenes. Now, a drama abounding inromantic sentiment and agonizing situations, with a musicalaccompaniment only in parts which are especially thrilling orpathetic. In opera, a passage in which the orchestra plays a somewhatdescriptive accompaniment, while the actor speaks; as, the melodramain the gravedigging scene of Beethoven's "Fidelio".
A person of congenitally abnormal mind bordering on insanity ordegeneracy.
A caste of priests, philosophers, and magicians, among theancient Persians; hence, any holy men or sages of the East.The inspired Magi from the Orient came. Sandys.
An apparatus for raising a liquid by pressure of air or steamin a reservoir containing the liquid.
To make or form amiss; to spoil in making. "Limpingpossibilities of mismade human nature." Mrs. Browning.
Making or producing myths; giving rise to mythical narratives.The mythopoeic fertility of the Greeks. Grote.
A pick with two prongs, to pry with.
The quality or state of being mucous or slimy; mucousness.
A Moorish pike. [Obs.]
A Linn√¶an order of plants, having solitary flowers with unitedanthers, as in the genus Lobelia.

A follower of Marcion, a Gnostic of the second century, whoadopted the Oriental notion of the two conflicting principles, andimagined that between them there existed a third power, neitherwholly good nor evil, the Creator of the world and of man, and theGod of the Jewish dispensation. Brande & C.
A large, flattened corpuscle, twice the diameter of theordinary red corpuscle, found in considerable numbers in the blood inprofound an√¶mia.
A modal relation or quality; a mode or point of view underwhich an object presents itself to the mind. According to Kant, thequality of propositions, as assertory, problematical, or apodeictic.
Matutinal. [R.]
To warn; to admonish; to advise. [Obs.] Wyclif (2 Cor. v. 20).
Without; weak. [Obs.]

A system of mechanism for transmitting motion of a definitecharacter, or for transforming motion; as, the wheelwork of a watch.Febrille movement (Med.), an elevation of the body temperature; afever.-- Movement cure. (Med.) See Kinesiatrics.-- Movement of the bowels, an evacuation or stool; a passage ordischarge.
A genus of mammals, including the skunks.
A genus of marsipobranchs, including the hagfish. See Hag, 4.
One who works wi
Bad fortune or luck; calamity; an evil accident; disaster;mishap; mischance.Consider why the change was wrought, You 'll find his misfortune, nothis fault. Addison.
Nauseous. [Obs.] L' Estrange.
A short, straight, horizontal mark [-], placed over vowels todenote that they are to be pronounced with a long sound; as, a, indame; e, in seam, etc.
See Muskellunge.
A name given in contempt to strict Calvinists in Switzerland,France, and some parts of Germany, in the early part of the 19thcentury.
Dehiscent by the separation of united carpels; -- said offruits.
One who munches.
One guilty of a misdemeanor. Sydney Smith.
To reform wrongly or imperfectly.

Any plant of the genera Asclepias and Acerates, abounding in amilky juice, and having its seed attached to a long silky down;silkweed. The name is also applied to several other plants with amilky juice, as to several kinds of spurge.
To release from slavery; to liberate from personal bondage orservitude; to free, as a slave. "Manumitted slaves." Hume.
Miscreated; illegitimate; forged; as, miscreate titles. [Obs.or Poet.] Shak.
Bad growth; an unnatural or abnormal growth.
The act of issuing or flowing out. [Obs.]
The finish around a fireplace, covering the chimney-breast infront and sometimes on both sides; especially, a shelf above thefireplace, and its supports. [Written also mantle.]
A rural custom in England, of visiting one's parents on MidlentSunday, -- supposed to have been originally visiting the motherchurch to make offerings at the high altar.

The telegraphic code, consisting of dots, dashes, and spaces,invented by Samuel B. Morse. The Alphabetic code which is in use inNorth America is given below. In length, or duration, one dash istheoretically equal to three dots; the space between the elements ofa letter is equal to one dot; the interval in spaced letters, as O .., is equal to three dots. There are no spaces in any letter composedwholly or in part of dashes.
The European goldcrest.
Having only one axis; developing along a single line or plane;as, monaxial development.
To live amiss.
To pity. [Obs.] Spenser.
A West African arboreal monkey (Cercopithecus cynosurus).
To make a false profession; to make pretensions to skill whichis not possessed.
The space between two triglyphs of the Doric frieze, which,among the ancients, was often adorned with carved work. See Illust.of Entablature.
The long and heavy hair growing on the upper side of, or about,the neck of some quadrupedal animals, as the horse, the lion, etc.See Illust. of Horse.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, microphytes.
To charge erroneously, as in account.-- n.
Having fever stamens than the parts of the corolla.
One presiding over mysteries. [Obs.]

A parasitic evergreen plant of Europe (Viscum album), bearing aglutinous fruit. When found upon the oak, where it is rare, it was anobject of superstitious regard among the Druids. A bird lime isprepared from its fruit. [Written also misletoe, misseltoe, andmistleto.] Lindley. Loudon.
The state or quality of being momentary; shortness of duration.
The operation of cutting into the uterus; hysterotomy; theC√¶sarean section.
Having numerous spines, as certain fishes.
A name for several plants with golden yellow blossoms,especially the Calendula officinalis (see Calendula), and thecultivated species of Tagetes.
A rhythmic series, consisting of a single meter.
An instrument, resembling a eudiometer, to detect the presenceand amount of methane, as in coal mines.
The quality or state of being mannerly; civility; complaisance.Sir M. Hale.
The difference between the cost and the selling price of anarticle.
One who serves a mitrailleuse.

One of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom, including theclasses Cephalopoda, Gastropoda, PteropodaScaphopoda, andLamellibranchiata, or Conchifera. Most of them develop a mantle, whichincloses either a branchial or a pulmonary cavity. They are generallymore or less covered and protected by a calcareous shell, which maybe univalve, bivalve, or multivalve.

An extensive group of Invertebrata, including the Mollusca,Brachiopoda, and Bryozoa. Called also Malacozoaria.

In a mincing manner; not fully; with affected nicety.

Any wicked or mischievous intention of the mind; a depravedinclination to mischief; an intention to vex, annoy, or injureanother person, or to do a wrongful act without just cause or causeor excuse; a wanton disregard of the rights or safety of others;willfulness. Malice aforethought or prepense, malice previously anddeliberately entertained.

To lead into a wrong way or path; to lead astray; to guide intoerror; to cause to mistake; to deceive.Trust not servants who mislead or misinform you. Bacon.To give due light To the mislead and lonely traveler. Milton.
Of or pertaining to Mars, the Roman god of war, or to theplanet bearing his name; martial.

of Misbede.
Somewhat mad. Beau. & Fl.

An enlargement or protrusion of the mucous membrane of thelachrymal passages, or dropsy of the lachrymal sac, dependent uponcatarrhal inflammation of the latter. Dunglison.

Mortar bed (Mil.), a framework of wood and iron, suitablyhollowed out to receive the breech and trunnions of a mortar.-- Mortar boat or vessel (Naut.), a boat strongly built and adaptedto carrying a mortar or mortars for bombarding; a bomb ketch.-- Mortar piece, a mortar. Any one of several species of Old World blood-sucking bats ofthe genus Megaderma.

See Fid. [Written also marlin spike] -- Marline-spike bird.Etym: [The name alludes to the long middle tail feathers.] (Zo√∂l.)(a) A tropic bird. (b) A jager, or skua gull.

A small European fern (Asplenium Ceterach) formerly used inmedicine.

Having a typically large size; belonging to the megasthenes.
That branch of zo√∂logical science which relates to thecrustaceans; -- called also carcinology.
According to merit; suitably.
A small evergreen tree or shrub (Arbutus Menziesii), ofCalifornia, having a smooth bark, thick shining leaves, and ediblered berries, which are often called madro√±a apples. [Written alsomadro√±o.]
A breech-loading machine gun consisting of a number of barrelsfitted together, so arranged that the barrels can be firedsimultaneously, or successively, and rapidly.
An extensive group of rodents which includes the rats, mice,jerboas, and many allied forms.
The state or quality of being miserable.

A record; the evidences or writings whereby a man is enabled todefend the title to his estate; title deeds and papers. Blount.Muniment house or room, that room in a cathedral, castle, or otherpublic building, which is used for keeping the records, charters,seals, deeds, and the like. Gwilt.
An East Indian coin, of about one tenth of the weight of arupee.

The third division, or that between the reticulum, or honeycombstomach, and the abomasum, or rennet stomach, in the stomach ofruminants; the omasum; the psalterium. So called from the numerousfolds in its mucous membrane. See Illust of Ruminant.
Capable of being mooted.

Earth and water mixed so as to be soft and adhesive. Mud bass(Zo√∂l.), a fresh-water fish (Acantharchum pomotis) of the EasternUnited States. It produces a deep grunting note.-- Mud bath, an immersion of the body, or some part of it, in mudcharged with medicinal agents, as a remedy for disease.-- Mud boat, a large flatboat used in deredging.-- Mud cat. See Catfish.-- Mud crab (Zo√∂l.), any one of several American marine crabs of thegenus Panopeus.-- Mud dab (Zo√∂l.), the winter flounder. See Flounder, and Dab.-- Mud dauber (Zo√∂l.), a mud wasp.-- Mud devil (Zo√∂l.), the fellbender.-- Mud drum (Steam Boilers), a drum beneath a boiler, into whichsediment and mud in the water can settle for removal.-- Mud eel (Zo√∂l.), a long, slender, aquatic amphibian (Sirenlacertina), found in the Southern United States. It has persistentexternal gills and only the anterior pair of legs. See Siren.-- Mud frog (Zo√∂l.), a European frog (Pelobates fuscus).-- Mud hen. (Zo√∂l.) (a) The American coot (Fulica Americana). (b)The clapper rail.-- Mud lark, a person who cleans sewers, or delves in mud. [Slang] -- Mud minnow (Zo√∂l.), any small American fresh-water fish of thegenus Umbra, as U. limi. The genus is allied to the pickerels.-- Mud plug, a plug for stopping the mudhole of a boiler.-- Mud puppy (Zo√∂l.), the menobranchus.-- Mud scow, a heavy scow, used in dredging; a mud boat. [U.S.] --Mud turtle, Mud tortoise (Zo√∂l.), any one of numerous species offresh-water tortoises of the United States.-- Mud wasp (Zo√∂l.), any one of numerous species of hymenopterousinsects belonging to Pep√¶us, and allied genera, which constructgroups of mud cells, attached, side by side, to stones or to thewoodwork of buildings, etc. The female places an egg in each cell,together with spiders or other insects, paralyzed by a sting, toserve as food for the larva. Called also mud dauber.
To utter with imperfect articulations, or with a low voice; as,to mutter threats. Shak.

A fern of the genus Adiantum (A. pedatum), having very slendergraceful stalks. It is common in the United States, and is sometimesused in medicine. The name is also applied to other species of thesame genus, as to the Venus-hair. Maiden grass, the smaller quakinggrass.-- Maiden tree. See Ginkgo.
The middle of the way or distance; a middle way or course.Shak.Paths indirect, or in the midway faint. Milton.
Sirs; gentlemen; -- abbreviated to Messrs., which is used asthe plural of Mr.
The quality or state of being malevolent; evil dispositiontoward another; inclination to injure others; ill will. See Synonymof Malice.
Offensive to the sense of smell; ill-smelling. --Mal*o"dor*ous*ness. n. Carlyle.[1913 Webster]
To skulk; to cower. See Mich.
To persuade amiss.
Accompanied with an eruption like millet seeds; as, a miliaryfever.
Suitable to be taken as a model or pattern; as, a model house;a model husband.
One of a denomination of Christians formerly living under thegovernment of the Moors in Spain, and having a liturgy and ritual oftheir own. [Written also Mozarab, Mostarab.] Brande & C.
Of or pertaining to a mandible; like a mandible.-- n.
To receive wrongly.
To bewitch; to harm. [Obs.] Burton.
The fruit of the Adansonia digitata; also, the tree. SeeAdansonia.
Moonlight. [Colloq.]I went to see them in a moonshiny night. Addison.
The person who employs another to perform a mandate. Bouvier.

Containing, or producing, melody; musical; agreeable to the earby a sweet succession of sounds; as, a melodious voice. "A melodiousvoice." "A melodious undertone." Longfellow.-- Me*lo"di*ous*ly, adv.-- Me*lo"di*ous*ness, n.
Of or pertaining to Moravia, or to the United Brethren. SeeMoravian, n.
A climbing plant (Ipomoea purpurea) having handsome, funnel-shaped flowers, usually red, pink, purple, white, or variegated,sometimes pale blue. See Dextrorsal.
A shrike or butcher bird; -- called also mattages. [Prov. Eng.]
A moralizer. [Obs.] Shak.
To happen or come to pass unfortunately; also, to suffer evilfortune. [Obs.]
Slatternly. [Obs.]
One who murders one's own mother.
Indicating, or pertaining to, some mode of conceivingexistence, or of expressing thought.
Having the lower part of the body like a fish. Crabb.
An incorrect statement.
Iron sesquioxide in isometric form, probably a pseudomorphafter magnetite.
The quality of being warlike; exercises suitable for war.[Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the political economist, the Rev. T. R.Malthus, or conforming to his views; as, Malthusian theories.

The state of being monstrous, or out of the common order ofnature; that which is monstrous; a monster. South.A monstrosity never changes the name or affects the immutability of aspecies. Adanson (Trans. ).
A large transverse commissure in the third ventricle of thebrain; the middle or soft commissure. B. G. Wildex.
Mistletoe. [Obs.] Missel bird, Missel thrush (Zo√∂l.), a largeEuropean thrush (Turdus viscivorus) which feeds on the berries of themistletoe; -- called also mistletoe thrush and missel.

The conversion of a cell wall into a material of a stonynature.

A cage for hawks; a mew. See 4th Mew, 1. Milman.
Of or pertaining to the millennium, or to a thousand years; as,a millennial period; millennial happiness.

A black pigment found in the pigment-bearing cells of the skin(particularly in the skin of the negro), in the epithelial cells ofthe external layer of the retina (then called fuscin), in the outerlayer of the choroid, and elsewhere. It is supposed to be derivedfrom the decomposition of hemoglobin.
A soft Tertiary sandstone; -- applied to a rock occurring inSwitzerland. See Chart of Geology.
Resembling a fungus.

The court or seat of a marshal; hence, the prison in Southwark,belonging to the marshal of the king's household. [Eng.] Court ofMarshalsea, a court formerly held before the steward and marshal ofthe king's house to administer justice between the king's domesticservants. Blackstone.

The sphere or globular mass of cells (blastomeres), formed bythe clevage of the ovum or egg in the first stages of itsdevelopment; -- called also mulberry mass, segmentation sphere, andblastosphere. See Segmentation.

Belonging, or relating, to the secondary or reptilian age, orthe era between the Paleozoic and Cenozoic. See Chart of Geology.
The act of biting. Swift.
One who works in metals, or prepares them for use; one who isskilled in metallurgy.
The nucleus of a cell; mesoblast. Agassix.
Shortsighted; mope-eyed.
A person whose intellectual development proceeds normally up toabout the eighth year of age and is then arrested so that there islittle or no further development.
One of the solid parts of a battlemented parapet; a battlement.See Illust. of Battlement.
To turn amiss; to pervert.
To address or petition by a memorial; to present a memorial to;as, to memorialize the legislature. T. Hook.
of Methinks.
The quality or state of being marriageable.

Having the same elements united in the same proportion byweight, and with the same molecular weight, but possessing adifferent structure and different properties; as, methyl ether andethyl alcohol are metameric compounds. See Isomeric.
Any one of several species of small Asiatic deer of the genusCervulus, esp. C. muntjac, which occurs both in India and on the EastIndian Islands. [Written also muntjak.]

Like man, or like a man, in form or nature; having thequalities of a man, esp. the nobler qualities; manly. " Gentle,manlike speech." Testament of Love. " A right manlike man." Sir P.Sidney.In glaring Chloe's manlike taste and mien. Shenstone.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, or derived from, a muscatgrapes or similar grapes; a muscatel grapes; muscatel wine, etc.
See Diaphragm, n., 2.Smote him into the midriff with a stone. Milton.
Want of esteem; disrespect. Johnson.
Full of whims or fancies; maggoty.
To give untrue information to; to inform wrongly.
In a dying state; dying; at the point of death.The patient was comatose and moribund. Copland.
Capability of being mixed.
Any marine bivalve shell of the genus Mactra, and alliedgenera. Many species are known. Some of them are used as food, asMactra stultorum, of Europe. See Surf clam, under Surf.
A distilled liquor prepared in Mexico from a species of agave.See Agave.
Inflammation of the myocardium.

The art of inducing an extraordinary or abnormal state of thenervous system, in which the actor claims to control the actions, andcommunicate directly with the mind, of the recipient. See Animalmagnetism, under Magnetism.
Same as Manul.
A leaf-cutting bee of the genus Megachilus. See Leaf cutter,under Leaf.
Affected with, or characterized by, madness; maniac.-- Ma*ni"a*cal*ly, adv.
Of or pertaining to microspores.
See Myope.
Of or pertaining to Moschus, a genus including the musk deer.
Pertaining to, or designating, a force producing magnetic flux,analogous to electromotive force, and equal to the magnetic fluxmultiplied by the magnetic reluctance.
Municipal condition.
A marriage with a person of inferior rank or social station; animproper alliance; a mesalliance.A Leigh had made a misalliance, and blushed A Howard should know it.Mrs. Browning.
A genus of tropical American shrubs with opposite leaves andsmall white or reddish flowers. The drupes of Malpighia urens areeaten under the name of Barbadoes cherries.
With distrust or suspicion.
Of, pertaining to, or caused by, microbes; as, the microbiantheory; a microbian disease.
A metropolis. [Obs.] Sir T. Herbert.
A worker in metals.
The third or middle finger; the third digit, or that whichcorresponds to it.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, minutes. [Obs.] Fuller.
See Mosque.
One who misobserves; one who fails to observe properly.
A narration of mere fable.
Derived from the name of one's mother, or other femaleancestor; as, a metronymic name or appellation.-- A metronymic appellation.
A salt of metastannic acid.
The name of several cereal and forage grasses which bear anabundance of small roundish grains. The common millets of Germany andSouthern Europe are Panicum miliaceum, and Setaria Italica.
A blotch or spot of ink on a printed page, caused by the inknot being properly distributed. It is distinguished from a friar, orwhite spot caused by a deficiency of ink.
In, near, or toward, the mesial plane; mesiad.
A colorless liquid hydrocarbon resembling oil of turpentine,obtained by dehydrating menthol. It has an agreeable odor and acooling taste.

A rare element of the chromium group, occurring in nature inthe minerals molybdenite and wulfenite, and when reduced obtained asa hard, silver-white, difficulty fusible metal. Symbol Mo. Atomicweight 95.9.
Having a typically small size; of or pertaining to themicrosthenes.
Silent; not speaking. Thackeray.The citizens are mum, and speak not a word. Shak.
In a malevolent manner.
A mustache. Longfellow.
To cleanse. [Obs.]
A colloquial abbreviation of midshipman.
The close linen or muslin cap of an old woman. [Prov. Eng. &Scot.]
Wrong expression.

A more or less musical sound made by many of the lower animals.See Stridulation. Magic music, a game in which a person is guided infinding a hidden article, or in doing a specific art required, bymusic which is made more loud or rapid as he approaches success, andslower as he recedes. Tennyson.-- Music box. See Musical box, under Musical.-- Music hall, a place for public musical entertainments.-- Music loft, a gallery for musicians, as in a dancing room or achurch.-- Music of the spheres, the harmony supposed to be produced by theaccordant movement of the celestial spheres.-- Music paper, paper ruled with the musical staff, for the use ofcomposers and copyists.-- Music pen, a pen for ruling at one time the five lines of themusical staff.-- Music shell (Zo√∂l.), a handsomely colored marine gastropod shell(Voluta musica) found in the East Indies; -- so called because thecolor markings often resemble printed music. Sometimes applied toother shells similarly marked.-- To face the music, to meet any disagreeable necessity withoutflinching. [Colloq. or Slang]
To fortify; to strengthen. [Obs.]
An instrument for determining and recording the differentphases, as the intensity, velocity, etc., of a muscular contraction.

An American marine fish of the genus Porichthys, allied to thetoadfish. Cadet midshipman, formerly a title distinguishing a cadetline officer from a cadet engineer at the U. S. Naval Academy. Seeunder Cadet.-- Cadet midshipman, formerly, a naval cadet who had served histime, passed his examinations, and was awaiting promotion; -- nowcalled, in the United States, midshipman; in England, sublieutenant.
Of or pertaining to micro-geology.
A fresh-water alga (Cladophora √Ügagropila) which forms aglobular mass.
A conductor; an officer in the ancient church who gave thesignal for the choir to sing, and who beat time with the hand, andregulated the music. Moore (Encyc. of Music.)
By or pertaining to metagraphy.
The quality or state of being marvelous; wonderfulness;strangeness.
The quality of being multiple, manifold, or various; a state ofbeing many; a multitude; as, a multiplicity of thoughts or objects."A multiplicity of goods." South.
A hare. [Scot.]
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a vanadic acid analogous tometaphosphoric acid.

The quality of being magnanimous; greatness of mind; elevationor dignity of soul; that quality or combination of qualities, incharacter, which enables one to encounter danger and trouble withtranquility and firmness, to disdain injustice, meanness and revenge,and to act and sacrifice for noble objects.
See Molasses.
To adjust wrongly of unsuitably; to throw of adjustment. I.Taylor.

Mixed; mingled; consisting of several things; of diverse sorts;promiscuous; heterogeneous; as, a miscellaneous collection. "Amiscellaneous rabble." Milton.-- Mis`cel*la"ne*ous*ly, adv.-- Mis`cel*la"ne*ous*ness, n.
A false or erroneous trial; a trial which has no result.
The person who makes a promissory note.
A repetition at the end of a stanza.
Serving to soften; assuaging; emollient.
The representation of a mantle, or the drapery behind andaround a coat of arms: -- called also lambrequin.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, the poppy or opium; specif.(Chem.), designating an acid related to aconitic acid, found in opiumand extracted as a white crystalline substance.
The process or act of macadamizing.
Pairing with several males; -- said of certain fishes of whichseveral males accompany each female during spawning.
A great quantity or number. [Prov. Eng.]There was a mort of merrymaking. Dickens.
Of or pertaining to Malta or to its inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.
Lit., my lord; hence (as used on the Continent), an Englishnobleman or gentleman.
See Muse, and Muset.
A game of guessing the number of fingers extended in a quickmovement of the hand, -- much played by Italians of the lowerclasses.
Having many flues; as, a multiflue boiler. See Boiler.
The mouth. [Obs.]One a penny, two a penny, hot cross buns, Butter them and sugar themand put them in your muns. Old Rhyme. Halliwell.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the devil Mephistopheles, "acrafty, scoffing, relentless fiend;" devilish; crafty.
By, or from, memory.
Any one of several African monkeys of the genus Cercocebus, asthe sooty mangabey (C. fuliginosus), which is sooty black. [Alsowritten mangaby.]
See Maltreat.
Having been subjected to some process of milling. Milled cloth,cloth that has been beaten in a fulling mill.-- Milled lead, lead rolled into sheets.
Changing the form; transforming. [R.] Pownall.
With a moderate degree of quickness; moderately. Allegromoderato, a little slower than allegro.-- Andante moderato, a little faster than andante.

Any plant of the genus Verbascum. They are tall herbs havingcoarse leaves, and large flowers in dense spikes. The common species,with densely woolly leaves, is Verbascum Thapsus. Moth mullein. Seeunder Moth.-- Mullein foxglove, an American herb (Seymeria macrophylla) withcoarse leaves and yellow tubular flowers with a spreading border.-- Petty mullein, the cowslip. Dr. Prior.
A little elevation of earth made by a mole; a molehill.Mortimer.
To grow better; to advance to a better state; to becomeimproved. Shak.
Eating, or feeding upon, honey.
Pertaining both to muscles and skin; as, the musculocutaneousnerve.
Slender rods or tubes of colored glass fused together andembedded in clear glass; -- used for paperweights and other smallarticles.
Producing metals; yielding metals.
To enter into the conjugal or connubial state; to take ahusband or a wife.I will, therefore, that the younger women marry. 1 Tim. v. 14.Marrrying man, a man disposed to marry. [Colloq.]
The catamenial or menstrual discharge, a periodic flow of bloodor bloody fluid from the uterus or female generative organs.
In a mingling manner.
The hypothetical hydrocarbon radical CH, regarded as anessential residue of certain organic compounds.
An intermediate product formed in the gastric digestion ofalbuminous matter.
Majestic. Cowley.An older architecture, greater, cunninger, more majestical. M.Arnold.-- Ma*jes"tic*al*ly, adv.-- Ma*jes"tic*al*ness, n.
Of or pertaining to monogenesis; as, monogenous, or asexual,reproduction.
To wrap up. [Obs.]

A condition in which the lower classes of a nation controlpublic affairs without respect to law, precedents, or vested rights.It is good name that Dr. Stevens has given to our present situation(for one can not call it a government), a mobocracy. Walpole.
A quack. [R.] Whitlock.
To temper ill; to disorder; as, to mistemper one's head.Warner.This inundation of mistempered humor. Shak.
Of or pertaining to materialism or materialists; of the natureof materialism.But to me his very spiritualism seemed more materialistic than hisphysics. C. Kingsley.
A city of Saxony. Magdeburg centuries, Magdeburg hemispheres.See under Century, and Hemisphere.
Containing mammalian remains; -- said of certain strata.
That doctrine which refers all phenomena to a single ultimateconstituent or agent; -- the opposite of dualism.
Malconformation.
