Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a natural order of tropicaltrees and shrubs (Malpighiace√¶), some of them climbing plants, andtheir stems forming many of the curious lianes of South Americanforests.
The crossed iron that supports the upper millstone by restingon the spindle; a millrind. Cross moline (Her.), a cross each arm ofwhich is divided at the end into two rounded branches or divisions.

A series of pictures, usually photographs taken with a specialmachine, presented to the eye in very rapid succession, with some orall of the objects in the picture represented in slightly changedpositions, producing, by persistence of vision, the optical effect ofa continuous picture in which the objects move in some manner, asthat of some original scene. The usual form of moving pictures isthat produced by the cinematograph.
The dark coloring matter of the liquid of the cuttlefish.
In the margin of a book.
Having only one petal, or the corolla in one piece, or composedof petals cohering so as to form a tube or bowl; gamopetalous.
A compound radical forming the base of menthol.
A macadamized road.
Of or pertaining to the monandria; having but one stamen.
Mezzotint.
An ancient weight or denomination of money, of varying value.The Attic mina was valued at a hundred drachmas.
Having a single floral envelope, that is, a calyx without acorolla, or, possibly, in rare cases, a corolla without a calyx.

Culminating, or coming to the meredian, at or about the sametime with the moon; -- said of a star or stars, esp. of certain starsselected beforehand, and named in an ephemeris (as the NauticalAlmanac), as suitable to be observed in connection with the moon atculmination, for determining terrestrial longitude.
Having a single heart, as fishes and amphibians.-- n.

A telegraphic alphabet in very general use, inventing by SamuelF.B.Morse, the inventor of Morse's telegraph. The letters arerepresented by dots and dashes impressed or printed on paper, as, .-(A), -... (B), -.. (D), . (E), .. (O), ... (R), -- (T), etc., or bysounds, flashes of light, etc., with greater or less intervalsbetween them.

Any one of many species of marine bivalve shells of the genusMytilus, and related genera, of the family Mytid√¶. The common mussel(Mytilus edulis; see Illust. under Byssus), and the larger, or horse,mussel (Modiola modiolus), inhabiting the shores both of Europe andAmerica, are edible. The former is extensively used as food inEurope.
Having but one brood in a season.
The quality of being maidenly; the behavior that becomes amaid; modesty; gentleness.
Having many kinds.
Of or pertaining to a microbe.
Of or pertaining to the first Frankish dynasty in Gaul orFrance.-- n.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid of titaniumanalogous to metasilicic acid.
Of or pertaining to Muzarabs; as, the Muzarabic liturgy.[Written also Mozarabic.]
A monopodium.
See Methylene.
Of a mean spirit; base; groveling.-- Mean"-spir`it*ed*ness, n.
Worship of a single deity.
The teledu.
See Melocoton.
The quality or state of being memorable.
One whose wealth is counted by millions of francs, dollars, orpounds; a very rich person; a person worth a million or more.[Written also millionnaire.]
To hear incorrectly.
A soldier armed with a musket.
A small plate covering the armpit in armor of the 14th centuryand later.
To nurture or train wrongly; as, to misnurture children. Bp.Hall.
Ill advised.-- Mis`ad*vis"ed*ly, adv.
The legalized use of one metal only, as gold, or silver, in thestandard currency of a country, or as a standard of money values. SeeBimetallism.
Unhappy. [Obs.]
Same as Multinodate.
A Russian village community. D. M. Wallace.
Producing misfortune. [Obs.]
The largest of the three orders into which the Fungi Imperfectiare divided, including various forms.
Wrong or evil suggestion. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Soft; sticky, and dirty. [Prov. Eng.] See Mucky.
A word of many syllables; a polysyllable. [R.] --Mul`ti*syl*lab"ic, a.
Pertaining to, or designating, a variety of tannic acidextracted from fustic (Maclura, formerly Morus, tinctoria) as ayellow crystalline substance; -- called also maclurin.
A turban ornamented with an imitation of gold or silverembroidery.

Those animals in which the protoplasmic mass, constituting theegg, is converted into a multitude of cells, which are metamorphosedinto the tissues of the body. A central cavity is commonly developed,and the cells around it are at first arranged in two layers, -- theectoderm and endoderm. The group comprises nearly all animals exceptthe Protozoa.
A wild cat (Felis manul), having long, soft, light-colored fur.It is found in the mountains of Central Asia, and dwells among rocks.

Liquefaction; the act of causing (something) to melt, or theprocess of becoming melted. Melting point (Chem.), the degree oftemperature at which a solid substance melts or fuses; as, themelting point of ice is 0¬∫ Centigrade or 32¬∫ Fahr., that of urea is132¬∫ Centigrade.-- Melting pot, a vessel in which anything is melted; a crucible.
One who admires the moderns, or their ways and fashions.

To make mellow. Shak.If the Weather prove frosty to mellow it [the ground], they do notplow it again till April. Mortimer.The fervor of early feeling is tempered and mellowed by the ripenessof age. J. C. Shairp.
The doctrine that the members of the human race have all acommon origin.

A species of the genus Myrtus, especially Myrtus communis. Thecommon myrtle has a shrubby, upright stem, eight or ten feet high.Its branches form a close, full head, thickly covered with ovate orlanceolate evergreen leaves. It has solitary axillary white or rosyflowers, followed by black several-seeded berries. The ancientsconsidered it sacred to Venus. The flowers, leaves, and berries areused variously in perfumery and as a condiment, and the beautifullymottled wood is used in turning.
Same as Menostasis.
A genus of rubiaceous trees and shrubs, mostly East Indian,many species of which yield valuable red and yellow dyes. The wood ishard and beautiful, and used for gunstocks.
To instruct amiss.
One of the bones of either the carpus or tarsus.
The spirit or practices of a malingerer; malingering.
Same as Mollusk.
See Monogrammic.
A male fish.
A weight of the metric system, being one million grams; ametric ton.
Monkish. [R.] Coleridge.
A genus of fishes including the gray mullets. See Mullet.

A genus of perennial, herbaceous, endogenous plants of greatsize, including the banana (Musa sapientum), the plantain (M.paradisiaca of Linn√¶us, but probably not a distinct species), theAbyssinian (M. Ensete), the Philippine Island (M. textilis, whichyields Manila hemp), and about eighteen other species. See Illust. ofBanana and Plantain.
The worship of the Virgin Mary.
Belonging to a fast day or fast; as, a maigre day. Walpole.Maigre food (R. C. Ch.), food allowed to be eaten on fast days.
Wrong imagination; delusion. Bp. Hall.
In a manifold manner.
The act or process of methodizing, or the state of beingmethodized.
A species of tinamou (Calopezus elegans), having a long slendercrest.
The state or quality of being manageable; manageableness.
Of or pertaining to mollusks.-- n.
A die, cut in intaglio, for stamping an ornament in relief, asupon metal.
A conical rifle bullet, with a cavity in its base plugged witha piece of iron, which, by the explosion of the charge, is drivenfarther in, expanding the sides to fit closely the grooves of thebarrel.
A month. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A hole made by a mouse, for passage or abode, as in a wall;hence, a very small hole like that gnawed by a mouse.
An upward thrust or blow. Shak.
Maize or Indian corn; -- the common name in South Africa.
To masticate; to chew; to eat. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
One who maintains.
Shaped like a bushel measure.
The middle space or region between heaven and hell; the abodeof human beings; the earth.
A small hole or gap through which a wild animal passes; a muse.Shak.
Ministerial. [Obs.] Johnson.
An instrument consisting of a short pendulum with a slidingweight. It is set in motion by clockwork, and serves to measure timein music.
See Miter.
Serving to cleanse and heal.-- n.
Subject to monthly flowing or menses.
A killer of men; a manslayer. [Obs.] Carew.
In a magnanimous manner; with greatness of mind.
The European house martin.
At salt of malonic acid.
The natural history of Mammalia.
See Maim, and Mayhem.
Kinesiatrics.
A dam or mound to obstruct a water course, and raise the waterto a height sufficient to turn a mill wheel.
Showing good manners; civil; respectful; complaisant.What thou thinkest meet, and is most mannerly. Shak.
The berry or fruit of any tree of the genus Morus; also, thetree itself. See Morus.
The state of being mortified; humiliation; subjection of thepassions. [R.]
Misstep; misbehavior. "To punish my mistreadings." Shak.
A female servant.
Discoidal by derivation; -- applied especially to the placentaof man and apes, because it is supposed to have been derived from adiffused placenta.
Worldliness. [Obs.]
To heat and ferment in the mow, as hay when housed too green.
Faulty or imperfect nutrition.
Bad administration; bad management of any business, especiallyof public affairs. [Written also maleadministration.]
See under Metal.

Any one of several species of large pelagic petrels andfulmars, as Fulmarus glacialis, of the North Atlantic, and severalspecies of √Üstrelata, of the Southern Ocean. See Fulmar. [Writtenalso mollymawk, malmock, mollemock, mallemocke, etc.]
The tropical plants (Manihot utilissima, and M. Aipi), fromwhich cassava and tapioca are prepared; also, cassava.[Written alsomandioc, manihoc, manihot.]
Written with or by the hand; not printed; as, a manuscriptvolume.
Of or pertaining to divination, or to the condition of oneinspired, or supposed to be inspired, by a deity; prophetic. [R.]"Mantic fury." Trench.
To suffer to go at large, on his finding sureties, ormainpernors, for his appearance at a day; -- said of a prisoner.
Capable of being multiplied.-- Mul"ti*pli`a*ble*ness, n.
An extinct genus of large slothlike American edentates, alliedto Megatherium.
Untrue representation; false or incorrect statement or account;-- usually unfavorable to the thing represented; as, amisrepresentation of a person's motives. Sydney Smith.
A kind of wild red cherry.
The Paraguay tea, being the dried leaf of the Brazilian holly(Ilex Paraguensis). The infusion has a pleasant odor, with anagreeable bitter taste, and is much used for tea in South America.
A nun. [Obs.]
To word wrongly; as, to misword a message, or a sentence.
To covet wrongfully. [Obs.]
Having a monopodium or a single and continuous axis, as abirchen twig or a cornstalk.
A single stone, especially one of large size, shaped into apillar, statue, or monument.
That condition of the pulse in which the pulse curve orsphygmogram shows but a single crest, the dicrotic elevation entirelydisappearing.
One who practices, or believes in, mesmerism.
See Mestee.
Not cognizant; ignorant; not knowing.
One who, or that which, causes to be remembered. [Obs.]
A contrivance or maneuvering to catch game illegally.
A Mussulman; an orthodox Mohammedan. [Written also muslim.]"Heaps of slaughtered Moslem." Macaulay.They piled the ground with Moslem slain. Halleck.
See 1st Measle. [Obs.]
Cultivation. [Obs.] W. Wotton.
The stormy petrel. [Prov. Eng.]
To render fit. [R.]
One who maintains that the human races are all of one species;-- opposed to polygenist.
One who models; hence, a worker in plastic art. [Written alsomodeller.]
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid, obtainedindirectly from mucic acid, and somewhat resembling itaconic acid.
A child's name for mamma, mother.
Pertaining to, or employed in, the measurement of magneticforces; obtained by means of a magnetometer; as, magnetometricinstruments; magnetometric measurements.
A delicate pastry made of powdered sugar and the whites of eggswhipped up, -- with jam or cream added.

One who mediates; especially, one who interposes betweenparties at variance for the purpose of reconciling them; hence, anintercessor.For there is one God, and one mediator between God and men, the manChrist Jesus. 1 Tim. ii. 5.

The act or employment of grinding or passing through a mill;the process of fulling; the process of making a raised or intentededge upon coin, etc.; the process of dressing surfaces of variousshapes with rotary cutters. See Mill. High milling, milling in whichgrain is reduced to flour by a succession of crackings, or of slightand partial crushings, alternately with sifting and sorting theproduct.-- Low milling, milling in which the reduction is effected in asingle crushing or grinding.-- Milling cutter, a fluted, sharp-edged rotary cutter for dressingsurfaces, as of metal, of various shapes.-- Milling machine, a machine tool for dressing surfaces by rotarycutters.-- Milling tool, a roller with indented edge or surface, forproducing like indentations in metal by rolling pressure, as inturning; a knurling tool; a milling cutter.
Made, or done, with a single color; as, a monochromic picture.
Making or producing mirth; convivial; jolly.

The fruit of a cucubritaceous plant (Cicumis Melo), having apeculiar aromatic flavor, and cultivated in many varieties, theprincipal sorts being the cantaloupe, of oval form and yellowishflesh, and the smaller nutmeg melon with greenish flesh. See Illust.of Melon.
Environment.
To acquire a monopoly of; to have or get the exclusiveprivilege or means of dealing in, or the exclusive possession of; toengross the whole of; as, to monopolize the coffee trade; tomonopolize land.

Greater by a semitone, either in interval or in difference ofpitch from another tone. Major axis (Geom.), the greater axis. SeeFocus, n., 2.-- Major key (Mus.), a key in which one and two, two and three, fourand five, five and six and seven, make major seconds, and three andfour, and seven and eight, make minor seconds.-- Major offense (Law), an offense of a greater degree whichcontains a lesser offense, as murder and robbery include assault.-- Major premise (Logic), that premise of a syllogism which containsthe major term.-- Major scale (Mus.), the natural diatonic scale, which hassemitones between the third and fourth, and seventh and fourth, andseventh and eighth degrees; the scale of the major mode, of which thethird is major. See Scale, and Diatonic.-- Major second (Mus.), a second between whose tones is a differencein pitch of a step.-- Major sixth (Mus.), a sixth of four steps and a half step. Inmajor keys the third and sixth from the key tone are major. Majorkeys and intervals, as distinguished from minors, are more cheerful.-- Major term (Logic), that term of a syllogism which forms thepredicate of the conclusion.-- Major third (Mus.), a third of two steps.

Of or pertaining to music; having the qualities of music; orthe power of producing music; devoted to music; melodious;harmonious; as, musical proportion; a musical voice; musicalinstruments; a musical sentence; musical persons. Musical, or Music,box, a box or case containing apparatus moved by clockwork so as toplay certain tunes automatically.-- Musical fish (Zo√∂l.), any fish which utters sounds under water,as the drumfish, grunt, gizzard shad, etc.-- Musical glasses, glass goblets or bowls so tuned and arrangedthat when struck, or rubbed, they produce musical notes. CF.Harmonica, 1.
A mineral of the feldspar group, like orthoclase or commonfeldspar in composition, but triclinic in form.
A short, round iron bar or lever used in naval gunnery. Totten.
Of, pertaining to, or involving, monism.

In a mediate manner; by a secondary cause or agent; notdirectly or primarily; by means; -- opposed to immediately.God worketh all things amongst us mediately. Sir W. Raleigh.The king grants a manor to A, and A grants a portion of it to B. Inthis case. B holds his lands immediately of A, but mediately of theking. Blakstone.
Sending forth; emitting. [Obs.] Wiseman.
A rich wine made on the Island of Madeira.A cup of Madeira, and a cold capon's leg. Shak.Madeira nut (Bot.), the European walnut; the nut of the Juglansregia.
A proclaiming of evil against some one; a cursing; imprecation;a curse or execration; -- opposed to benediction.No malediction falls from his tongue. Longfellow.
Capable of being misinterpreted; liable to be misunderstood.
A dull, silent person; a blockhead. [Obs.] Spenser.
A man who is mad; lunatic; a crazy person.When a man mistakes his thoughts for person and things, he is mad. Amadman is properly so defined. Coleridge.
A salt of muriatic hydrochloric acid; a chloride; as, muriateof ammonia.
A white waxy substance, found in small quantities in spermacetias an ethereal salt of several fatty acids, and regarded as analcohol of the methane series.
Of or pertaining to the dead; as, mortuary monuments. Mortuaryurn, an urn for holding the ashes of the dead.
A mixture; a medley.
Pertaining to, or discovered by, Meton, the Athenian. Metoniccycle or year. (Astron.) See under Cycle.
To represent incorrectly (almost always, unfacorably); to givea false erroneous representation of, either maliciously, ignirantly,or carelessly. Swift.

. A kind of boat used on the coast of Madras, India. The planksare sewed together with strands of coir which cross over a wadding ofthe same material, so that the shock on taking the beach through surfis much reduced. [Written also masula, masulah, etc.]
Ornamented by means of an imitation or suggestion of quilting,the surface being marked by depressed lines which form squares orlozenges in relief; as, matelass√© silks.
Moving. [R.] Grew.

The fruit of two South American trees (Lecythis Ollaria, and L.Zabucajo), which have for their fruit large, pot-shaped, woodycapsules containing delicious nuts, and opening almost explosively bya circular lid at the top. Vases and pots are made of this capsule.
A bale of raw silk.
To swear falsely. [Obs.] Blount.
The act of cleansing. [Obs.]
Same as Micmacs.
A m√™l√©e; a conflict. Tennyson.
The state or office of the Messiah.
A mope; a drone. [Obs.] Swift.
Moodily. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the two posterior gastric lobes of thecarapace of crabs.

A wild sheep (Ovis musimon), inhabiting the mountains ofSardinia, Corsica, etc. Its horns are very large, with a triangularbase and rounded angles. It is supposed by some to be the original ofthe domestic sheep. Called also musimon or musmon. [Written alsomoufflon.]
A fabled marine creature, typically represented as having theupper part like that of a woman, and the lower like a fish; a seanymph, sea woman, or woman fish.
A tune or air to regulate the movements of the dance so called;a movement in suites, sonatas, symphonies, etc., having the danceform, and commonly in 3-4, sometimes 3-8, measure.

Pertaining to, or resembling, a natural order of plants(Malvace√¶), of which the mallow is the type. The cotton plant,hollyhock, and abutilon are of this order, and the baobab and thesilk-cotton trees are now referred to it.
See Misy.
A genus of Hydrocorallia, which includes the millipores.
The cackerel.
A wall. [Obs.] Shak.

A small orange, with easily separable rind. It is thought to beof Chinese origin, and is counted a distinct species (Citrusnobilis)mandarin orange; tangerine. Mandarin duck (Zo√∂l.), abeautiful Asiatic duck (Dendronessa galericulata), oftendomesticated, and regarded by the Chinese as an emblem of conjugalaffection.-- Mandarin language, the spoken or colloquial language of educatedpeople in China.-- Mandarin yellow (Chem.), an artificial aniline dyestuff used forcoloring silk and wool, and regarded as a complex derivative ofquinoline.
Of or pertaining to the Monotremata.
Green gram, a kind of pulse (Phaseolus Mungo), grown for foodin British India. Balfour (Cyc. of India).
The department of physiology which deals with the principles ofmuscular contraction; the exercise of muscular force or contraction.
A lily (Lilium Martagon) with purplish red flowers, found inEurope and Asia.
A composer or singer of melodies.
Mezzo-rilievo.
A Peruvian plant (Piper, or Artanthe, elongatum), allied to thepepper, the leaves of which are used as a styptic and astringent.
Honey of roses.
Erroneous construction; wrong interpretation. Bp.Stillingfleet.
To embalm and dry as a mummy; to make into, or like, a mummy.Hall (1646).
The scutum or dorsal plate of the middle thoracic segment of aninsect. See Illust. of Butterfly.
A Marsh. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Any one of several species of large-footed, gallinaceous birdsof the genera Megapodius and Leipoa, inhabiting Australia and otherPacific islands. See Jungle fowl (b) under Jungle, and Leipoa.
Any bird of the genus Merganser, and allied genera. They areallied to the ducks, but have a sharply serrated bill.
See Muezzin.
The American badger.
A form of albumin found in ascitic and certain serous fluids.It is sometimes regarded as a mixture of albumin and mucin.
The engagement of the teeth of wheels, or of a wheel and rack.Mesh stick, a stick on which the mesh is formed in netting.
The sacrifice in the sacrament of the Eucharist, or theconsecration and oblation of the host.
An artificial organic base, obtained by oxidizing a mixture ofaniline and toluidine, and valuable for the dyestuffs it forms.[Written also mauvine.]

The act or process, by which living tissues or cells take upand convert into their own proper substance the nutritive materialbrought to them by the blood, or by which they transform their cellprotoplasm into simpler substances, which are fitted either forexcretion or for some special purpose, as in the manufacture of thedigestive ferments. Hence, metabolism may be either constructive(anabolism), or destructive (katabolism).
Monticulate.
A female monarch. [Obs.]
A climbing plant of the genus Menispermum; -- so called fromthe crescentlike form of the seeds.

An optical instrument, consisting of a lens, or combination oflenses, for making an enlarged image of an object which is too minuteto be viewed by the naked eye. Compound microscope, an instrumentconsisting of a combination of lenses such that the image formed bythe lens or set of lenses nearest the object (called the objective)is magnified by another lens called the ocular or eyepiece.-- Oxyhydrogen microscope, and Solar microscope. See underOxyhydrogen, and Solar.-- Simple, or Single, microscope, a single convex lens used tomagnify objects placed in its focus.
State of being misty.
Mesocephalic.
To go wrong; to go astray. [Obs.] "The world is miswent."Gower.
Any fly of the genus Musca, or family Muscid√¶.
Troublesome; vexatious. [R.]
Formerly, in the British service, a gunner or a gunner's mate;one of the soldiers in a train of artillery, who assisted the gunnersin loading, firing, and sponging the guns. [Obs.]
A small tufted monkey.
A marquisate.
Divided into many similar segments; -- said of an insect ormyriapod.
Destitute of marrow.

The misnaming of a person in a legal instrument, as in acomplaint or indictment; any misnaming of a person or thing; a wrongor inapplicable name or title.Many of the changes, by a great misnomer, called parliamentary"reforms". Burke.The word "synonym" is fact a misnomer. Whatel
Unjustly gotten. Spenser.
Ministration. [Obs.]
The African white two-horned rhinoceros (Atelodus simus).
Any one of a series of compounds of mercaptans with aldehydes.
Massicot. [Obs.]
A syllable applied to the third tone of the scale of C, i. e.,to E, in European solmization, but to the third tone of any scale inthe American system.
Having many cusps or points.
Regulated or determined by a standard; hence, equal; uniform;graduated; limited; moderated; as, he walked with measured steps; heexpressed himself in no measured terms.-- Meas"ured*ly, adv.
A West Indian food fish (Malacanthus plumieri) related to thetilefish.
To match unsuitably.
A metropolitan. Barrow.
To infer incorrectly.
A manganate. [Obs.]
A device to magnify sound, or direct it in a given direction ina greater volume, as a very large funnel used as an ear trumpet or asa speaking trumpet.

Received by birth or from ancestors; native, natural; as,mother language; also acting the part, or having the place of amother; producing others; originating.It is the mother falsehood from which all idolatry is derived. T.Arnold.Mother cell (Biol.), a cell which, by endogenous divisions, givesrise to other cells (daughter cells); a parent cell.-- Mother church, the original church; a church from which otherchurches have sprung; as, the mother church of a diocese.-- Mother country, the country of one's parents or ancestors; thecountry from which the people of a colony derive their origin.-- Mother liquor (Chem.), the impure or complex residual solutionwhich remains after the salts readily or regularly crystallizing havebeen removed.-- Mother queen, the mother of a reigning sovereign; a queen mother.-- Mother tongue. (a) A language from which another language has hadits origin. (b) The language of one's native land; native tongue.-- Mother water. See Mother liquor (above).-- Mother wit, natural or native wit or intelligence.
Mohammedanism. [Obs.]
Designating an organic acid obtained from oil of ben. SeeMoringa.
One who believes wrongly; one who holds a false religion. Shak.
To state wrongly; as, to misstate a question in debate. Bp.Sanderson.

The moral condition, or the condition in other respects, so faras it is affected by, or dependent upon, moral considerations, suchas zeal, spirit, hope, and confidence; mental state, as of a body ofmen, an army, and the like.
Of or pertaining to Miletus, a city of Asia Minor, or to itsinhabitants.
See Mormal. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A morate.
An instrument which registers meteorologic phases orconditions.
One of the New England States. Maine law, any law prohibitingthe manufacture and sale of intoxicating beverages, esp. oneresembling that enacted in the State of Maine.
Of or resembling birds of the kite kind.
Of or pertaining to monandry; practicing monandry as a systemof marriage.

An alkaloid distinct from picrotoxin and obtained from thecocculus indicus (the fruit of Anamirta Cocculus, formerlyMenispermum Cocculus) as a white, crystalline, tasteless powder; --called also menispermina.
A handcuff; a shackle for the hand or wrist; -- usually in theplural.Doctrine unto fools is as fetters on the feet, and like manacles onthe right hand. Ecclus. xxi. 19.
Hatred of women. Johnson.

In mass; not necessarily without a crystalline structure, buthaving no regular form; as, a mineral occurs massive. Massive rock(Geol.), a compact crystalline rock not distinctly schistone, asgranite; also, with some authors, an eruptive rock.
Greatness. [Obs.] Wyclif.
See Miocene.
Of or pertaining to mode, modulation, module, or modius; as,modular arrangement; modular accent; modular measure.
A spider monkey (Ateles belzebuth) of Central and SouthAmerica.
Having the form of a monad; resembling a monad in having one ormore filaments of vibratile protoplasm; as, monadiform young.
Extremely rash; foolhardy. See under March, the month. Sir W.Scott.
, One who, or that which, melts.

A combined rotary type-setting and printing machine for officeuse. The type is transferred semi-automatically by means of keys froma type-supply drum to a printing drum. The printing may be done bymeans of an inked ribbon to print "typewritten" letters, or directlyfrom inked type or a stereotype plate, as in a printing press.
Dejected; sorrowful; downcast. [Obs.] "So piteous and so maat."Chaucer.
Untrue or incorrect information. Bacon.
Membranaceous. Membranous croup (Med.), true croup. See Croup.
An old dance with swords and bucklers; a sword dance.
A tall pole erected in an open place and wreathed with flowers,about which the rustic May-day sports were had.
In the greatest or highest degree.Those nearest to this king, and most his favorites, were courtiersand prelates. Milton.
An alga of any kind that produces blackish spores, or seeddust. The melanosperms include the rockweeds and all kinds of kelp.-- Mel`a*no*sper"mous, a.
An impure yellow sulphate of iron; yellow copperas orcopiapite.
Malformation.
A metrical composition consisting of a single strophe.
The European sedge warbler (Acrocephalus phragmitis).
To congratulate. [Oxford Univ. Cant]  Whately.
Myotic.
One who imitates or mimics, especially one who does so forsport; a copyist; a buffoon. Burke.
The act of ministering; service; ministry. "The days of hisministration." Luke i. 23.
Full of milk; abounding with food. [R.] "Milkful vales."Sylvester.
An irregular or partisan soldier; a bandit.

Formed by mixing; united; mingled; blended. See Mix, v. t. & i.Mixed action (Law), a suit combining the properties of a real and apersonal action.-- Mixed angle, a mixtilineal angle.-- Mixed fabric, a textile fabric composed of two or more kinds offiber, as a poplin.-- Mixed marriage, a marriage between persons of different races orreligions; specifically, one between a Roman Catholic and aProtestant.-- Mixed number, a whole number and a fraction taken together.-- Mixed train, a railway train containing both passenger andfreight cars.-- Mixed voices (Mus.), voices of both males and females united inthe same performance.
A closely fitting knit sleeve; also, a legging of knittedmaterial. [Scot.]
A goatlike antelope (Haplocerus montanus) which inhabits theRocky Mountains, frequenting the highest parts; -- called alsomountain goat.
A substance which is formed in mucous epithelial cells, andgives rise to mucin.
A native or inhabitant of Media in Asia.
A germ in that stage of development in which its form is simplythat of a non-nucleated mass of protoplasm. It precedes the one-celled germ. So called from its likeness to a moner. Haeckel.
Ill luck; ill fortune; mishap. Chaucer.Never come mischance between us twain. Shak.
To take in a wrong sense; to misunderstand. Locke.
Of or pertaining to the Myelencephala.
To serve unfaithfully.
One who habitually intoxicates himself with a narcotic obtainedfrom mandrake.
See Morrow. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A tumor made up of a gelatinous tissue resembling that found inthe umbilical cord.
To moisten. [Obs.] Shak.
An insect having many feet, as a myriapod.
A species of informal state paper, much used in negotiation.
Mangy. [Obs.] Skelton.
See Motive, n., 3, 4.
The land within the boundaries of a farm; a farmstead or farm.[Archaic.] Longfellow.
Lowing; bellowing. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
One of the serial segments, or metameres, of which the bodiesof vertebrate and articulate animals are composed.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the ethylene series,metameric with fumaric acid and obtained by heating malic acid.
One who mislays.
See Nepenthes.
The fire god of the Ammonites, to whom human sacrifices wereoffered; Moloch. Lev. xviii. 21.
Unlawful use of a right; use in excess of, or varying from,one's right. Bouvier.
A great circle of the sphere passing through the poles of theheavens and the zenith of a given place. It is crossed by the sun atmidday.
The trade of mercers; the goods in which a mercer deals.

A cryptogamous plant of a cellular structure, with distinctstem and simple leaves. The fruit is a small capsule usually openingby an apical lid, and so discharging the spores. There are manyspecies, collectively termed Musci, growing on the earth, on rocks,and trunks of trees, etc., and a few in running water.
Wrong summation.
The female of the horse and other equine quadrupeds.
Same as Mantling.
A Linn√¶an class of plants embracing those having but a singlestamen.
A girl; esp., a great, awkward girl; a wench. [Prov. Eng.]
Quality or state of being mellow.
Having many streaks.
To wed improperly.
Microscopic. [R.] Berkeley.
Pertaining to, or derived from, fustic (see Morin); as, moricacid.
See Madecassee.
A repository or a collection of natural, scientific, orliterary curiosities, or of works of art. Museum beetle, Museum pest.(Zo√∂l.) See Anthrenus.
The world; a globe as an ensign of royalty. [R.] A. Drummond.Le beau monde Etym: [F.], fashionable society. See Beau monde.-- Demi monde. See Demimonde.

Pertaining to, in the manner of, or designating, a kind ofmarriage, called also left-handed marriage, between a man of superiorrank and a woman of inferior, in which it is stipulated that neitherthe latter nor her children shall enjoy the rank or inherit thepossessions of her husband. Brande & C.-- Mor`ga*nat"ic*al*ly, adv.
Having some resemblance to a mummy; -- in zo√∂logy, said of thepup√¶ of certain insects.
A large leather flap which covers the saddletree. [WesternU.S.]

An opera in which the text and action are not interrupted byset arias, duets, etc., the music being determined throughout bydramatic appropriateness; musical drama of this character, ingeneral. It involves the use of a kind of melodious declamation, thedevelopment of leitmotif, great orchestral elaboration, and a fusionof poetry, music, action, and scene into an organic whole. The termis applied esp. to the later works of Wagner: "Tristan und Isolde,""Die Meistersinger," "Rheingold," "Walk√ºre," "Siegfried,""G√∂tterd√§mmerung," and "Parsifal."
A clump of trees in a prairie. [Local, U.S.]
To sport with roughly; to rumple. [Written also mouzle.] [Obs.]Wycherley.
A minnow.
A moor. [Scot.] Lockhart.
A bugbear; false terror. [Obs.] Jonhson.
A gull.
A stone, or cast-iron plate, or former, on which hot glass isrolled to give it shape.
My lady; -- a French title formerly given to ladies of quality;now, in France, given to all married women. Chaucer.

The act of one who, or that which, marks; the mark or marksmade; arrangement or disposition of marks or coloring; as, themarking of a bird's plumage. Marking ink, indelible ink, because usedin marking linen.-- Marking nut (Bot.), the nut of the Semecarpus Anacardium, an EastIndian tree. The shell of the nut yields a blackish resinous juiceused for marking cotton cloth, and an oil prepared from it is usedfor rheumatism.
In a meek manner. Spenser.
The order or mode of development of an organ or part.
Having long or large leaves.
An artist who, by mechanical means, multiplies copies of worksof art.
A misanthrope. [Obs.] Shak.
To govern ill; as, to misgovern a country. Knolles.

A disease producing a peculiar cretinoid appearance of theface, slow speech, and dullness of intellect, and due to failure ofthe functions of the thyroid gland. -- Myx`o*dem"a*tous (#), a.,Myx`o*dem"ic (#), a.
Of or pertaining to the mesosternum.
Wrong policy; impolicy.
One skilled in magic; one who practices the black art; anenchanter; a necromancer; a sorcerer or sorceress; a conjurer.
Act of forming matter. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The act of rendering modern in style; the act or process ofcausing to conform to modern of thinking or acting.
To report erroneously; to give an incorrect account of. Locke.
Pertaining to a monarch; suiting a monarch; sovoreign; regal;imperial.Satan, whom now transcendent glory raised Above his fellows, withmonarchal pride. Milton.
See Matrix.
A slender, lofty tower attached to a mosque and surrounded byone or more projecting balconies, from which the summon to prayer iscried by the muezzin.
A work of twelve volumes, each containing the offices in theGreek Church for a month; also, each volume of the same. Shipley.
The muscular system of an animal, or of any of its parts.
Misuse. [Obs.]
Having long or large petals.
One who, or that which, mortifies.
The see of a metropolitan bishop. Milman.
To be struck with surprise, astonishment, or wonder; to wonder.Marvel not, my brethren, if the world hate you. 1 john iii. 13.
See Mawmet. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An officious or unlawful intermeddling in a cause dependingbetween others, by assisting either party with money or means tocarry it on. See Champerty. Wharton. Cap of maintenance. See underCap.
A system of farming on halves. [France & Italy]
One skilled in, or given to, microscopy.
A dry measure, containing about a peck.
The possession by a woman of only one husband at the same time;-- contrasted with polyandry.
A wrong or unjust judgment.
Admissible lawfully into the mail. [U.S.]
A class of claret wines, including several varieties, from thedistrict of M√©doc in the department of Gironde.
One who misunderstands. Sir T. More.
To affect with mercury.
See Mustaiba.
The state or quality of being massive; massiness.
The nickname of a crackbrained Italian who fancied himself anemperor. [Obs.] Shak.
Dim-sighted; purblind.
A range, chain, or group of such elevations; as, the WhiteMountains.
Possession of lands or tenements in, or conveyance to, deadhands, or hands that cannot alienate.
A literal translator.
Leprosy. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A genus of corals with meandering grooves and ridges, includingthe brain corals.
Being the last one of a million of units or objects counted inregular order from the first of a series or succession; being one ofa million.
The doctrine of mutual dependence as the condition ofindividual and social welfare. F. Harrison. H. Spencer. Mallock.
To frame wrongly.
One who mistrusts.
A small lake. See Mere. [Prov. Eng.]
A division of Invertebrata which includes the classesBrachiopoda and Bryozoa; -- called also Anthoid Mollusca.
A bird. See Martin.
State of being a minion. [R.]
Affected with melanism; of the nature of melanism.

A custom, formerly practiced by the scholars at Eton school,England, of giing every third year, on Whittuesday, to a hillock nearthe Bath road, and exacting money from all passers-by, to support atthe university the senior scholar of the school.
See Multi-.
Too frequent use of the letter m, or of the sound representedby it.
To move. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Consisting of a thousand years; of or pertaining to themillennium, or to the Millenarians.
Very extremely; as, main heavy. "I'm main dry." Foote. [Obs. orLow]
Bearing or producing much or many. [R.]

An opening affording entrance or exit; orifice; aperture; as:(a) The opening of a vessel by which it is filled or emptied, chargedor discharged; as, the mouth of a jar or pitcher; the mouth of thelacteal vessels, etc.(b) The opening or entrance of any cavity, as a cave, pit, well, orden.(c) The opening of a piece of ordnance, through which it isdischarged.(d) The opening through which the waters of a river or any stream aredischarged.(e) The entrance into a harbor.
One who menaces.
In a melancholy manner.
Same as Misericordia, 2.
A substance regarded as an anhydride of meconinic acid,existing in opium and extracted as a white crystalline substance.Also erroneously called meconina, meconia, etc., as though it were analkaloid.
To behave ill; -- with a reflexive pronoun; as, to misdemeanone's self.
See Molybdenite.
The juicy fruit of certain cucurbitaceous plants, as themuskmelon, watermelon, and citron melon; also, the plant thatproduces the fruit.
The act or operation of masticating; chewing, as of food.Mastication is a necessary preparation of solid aliment, withoutwhich there can be no good digestion. Arbuthnot.
Of or pertaining to a meadow; of the nature of a meadow;produced, growing, or living in, a meadow. "Fat meadow ground."Milton.
In a maimed manner.
A picture produced by a process in which development afterexposure may be deferred indefinitely, so as to permit transportationof exposed plates; also, the process itself.
Stupid; awkward. [Colloq.]
An insect which undergoes a metamorphosis.
To carry improperly; to carry (one's self) wrongly; tomisbehave. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The quality of being multiform; diversity of forms; variety ofappearances in the same thing. Purchas.
A rover in quest of booty or plunder; a plunderer; one whopillages. De Quincey.
In an ascending manner.

A process by which copper matte is treated by passing throughit a blast of air, to oxidize and remove sulphur. It is analogous inapparatus to the Bessemer process for decarbonizing cast iron. Socalled from Pierre Manh√®s, a French metallurgist, who invented it.
Molasses. [Obs.]
Withering without
A beast that has died of disease or by mischance. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.

The space between two bars. See Beat, Triple, Quadruple,Sextuple, Compound time, under Compound, a., and Figure.(c) (Poetry) The manner of ordering and combining the quantities, orlong and short syllables; meter; rhythm; hence, a foot; as, a poem iniambic measure.
The theory or practice of Marconi's wireless telegraph system.
Slimy; moist, and moderately viscous.
The mother and ruler of a family or of her descendants; a rulerby maternal right.
Any one of several species of lemurs, as the ruffed lemur(Lemur macaco), and the ring-tailed lemur (L. catta).
Common potash mica. See Mica.
A martyrology. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Mistiness. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the machinery of a poem; acting or used asa machine.[Obs.] Dryden.
To change into a different form; to transform; to transmute.And earth was metamorphosed into man. Dryden.
To moralize. [Obs.] Shak.

To use the hands in dexterous operations; to do hand work;specifically, to manage the apparatus or instruments used inscientific work, or in artistic or mechanical processes; also,specifically, to use the hand in mesmeric operations.
The postero-lateral ossification in the sternum of birds; also,the part resulting from such ossification.
To enslave; to bind; to restrict. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
Not graceful; displeasing. [Obs.] Gower.
Much. [Obs.]
A city and a province of Spain, on the Mediterranean. Hence,Malaga grapes, Malaga raisins, Malaga wines.
A variety of sugar, isomeric with sucrose, extracted from themanna of the larch (Larix). [Written also melicitose.]
One of the larger measures of electrical resistance, amountingto one million ohms.
To commemorate. [Obs.]

Causing mischief; harmful; hurtful; -- now often applied wherethe evil is done carelessly or in sport; as, a mischievous child."Most mischievous foul sin." Shak.This false, wily, doubling disposition is intolerably mischievous tosociety. South.
Of or pertaining to moment or momentum.
One who mistakes.Well meaning ignorance of some mistakers. Bp. Hall.
See Minnow.
The sunfish (Orthagoriscus, or Mola). [Written also molebat.]
Rubbish; refuse; dirt. [Obs.]All this mullok [was] in a sieve ythrowe. Chaucer.

A light, colorless, gaseous, inflammable hydrocarbon, CH4;marsh gas. See Marsh gas, under Gas. Methane series (Chem.), a seriesof saturated hydrocarbons, of which methane is the first member andtype, and (because of their general chemical inertness andindifference) called also the paraffin (little affinity) series. Thelightest members are gases, as methane, ethane; intermediate membersare liquids, as hexane, heptane, etc. (found in benzine, kerosene,etc.); while the highest members are white, waxy, or fatty solids, asparaffin proper.
A small crustacean with one median eye.
Misgovernment; misconduct; misbehavior. [Obs.] Chaucer.Spenser.
Quality of being malleable.
A talmudic exposition of the Hebrew law, or of some part of it.
The act of biting or gnawing. [Obs.]
Flowing as with honey; smooth; mellifluous.
The maiming of a person by depriving him of the use of any ofhis members which are necessary for defense or protection. See Maim.
Given to melancholy; depressed; melancholy; dejected; unhappy.Just as the melancholic eye Sees fleets and armies in the sky. Prior.

A white crystalline substance of a sweet taste obtained from aso-called manna, the dried sap of the flowering ash (Fraxinus ornus);-- called also mannitol, and hydroxy hexane. Cf. Dulcite.HO.CH2.(CHOH)4.CH2.OH = D-mannitol; manna sugar; cordycepic acid;Diosmol; Mannicol; Mannidex; Osmiktrol; Osmosal.-- used in pharmacy as excipient and diluent for solids and liquids.Used as a food additive for anti-caking properties, or as asweetener. Also used to "cut" (dilute) illegal drugs such as cocaineor heroin. ("excipient" use)
A genus of cruciferous plants (Alyssum) with white or yellowflowers and rounded pods. A. maritimum is the commonly cultivatedsweet alyssum, a fragrant white-flowered annual.

An alteration in a mineral or rock mass when involving achemical change of the substance, as of chrysolite to serpentine; --opposed to ordinary metamorphism, as implying simply arecrystallization.-- Met`a*so*mat"ic, a.
Belief in the coming of the Mahdi; fanatical devotion to thecause of the Mahdi or a pretender to that title. -- Mah"dist (#), n.

In military language, a strict disciplinarian; in general, onewho lays stress on a rigid adherence to the details of discipline, orto forms and fixed methods. [Hence, the word is commonly employed ina depreciatory sense.]
Any one of several metameric forms of the same substance, or ofdifferent substances having the same composition; as, xylene hasthree metamers, viz., orthoxylene, metaxylene, and paraxylene.
Pertaining both to the mandibular and the hyoid arch, orsituated between them.
Of or pertaining to metamorphosis; pertaining to, or involving,change.

Middle; intervening; as, a mesne lord, that is, a lord whoholds land of a superior, but grants a part of it to another person,in which case he is a tenant to the superior, but lord or superior tothe second grantee, and hence is called the mesne lord. Mesneprocess, intermediate process; process intervening between thebeginning and end of a suit, sometimes understood to be the wholeprocess preceding the execution. Blackstone. Burrill.-- Mesne profits, profits of premises during the time the owner hasbeen wrongfully kept out of the possession of his estate. Burrill.
The language of the Mahrattas; the language spoken in theDeccan and Concan. [Written also Marathi.]
The act of materializing, or the state of being materialized.
A veteran partisan; one who is so conservative in opinion thathe may be likened to a stone or old tree covered with moss.[Political Slang, U.S.]
To misconceive; to mistake; to miscomprehend; to take in awrong sense.
Of or pertaining to a single family or stock, or to developmentfrom a single common parent form; -- opposed to polyphyletic; as,monophyletic origin.
Having no meat; without food."Leave these beggars meatless." Sir T. More.
An application made to a court or judge orally in open court.Its object is to obtain an order or rule directing some act to bedone in favor of the applicant. Mozley & W.

Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a large and important naturalorder of trees and shrubs (Myrtace√¶), of which the myrtle is thetype. It includes the genera Eucalyptus, Pimenta, Lechythis, andabout seventy more.
An East Indian genus of large trees. Melanorrhoea usitatissimais the lignum-vit√¶ of Peru, and yelds a valuable black varnish.
Moorland. [Obs.]
Amendment. [Obs.]
Having small teeth.
Resembling a mountain in form.
Meteoric.
To munch. [Obs.]
See Morisco.
A species of gull or tern. [Prov.] Lowell.
See Meso-.
Formed from one pistil; -- said of fruits. R. Brown.
A female Moabite. Ruth i. 22.
Erroneous relation or narration. Abp. Bramhall.
A compost heap; a dunghill. Chaucer. Tennyson.
To toil. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
The Myxomycetes; -- so called by those who regard them as aclass of animals. -- My*ce`to*zo"an (#), a.
The state of being mossy.
To mark wrongly.
A tribe of Indians that formerly occupied the country betweenthe Wabash and Maumee rivers.
To pass from one key into another.
A great act or event; a great attainment. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The science that is concerned with metempirics.
An advocate of, or believer in, monarchy.
To perform Mass. [Obs.] Milton.
State or quality of being milky.
Having the form, or structure, of a maxilla.
The property, quality, or state, of being magnetic; themanifestation of the force in nature which is seen in a magnet.
The act of chewing. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
Like or pertaining to the genus Mullus, which includes thesurmullet, or red mullet.
Pertaining to, or like, marble.

The way in which the parts of anything are put together; often,the way in which an actor is dressed, painted, etc., in personating acharacter.The unthinking masses are necessarily teleological in their mentalmake-up. L. F. Ward.
Pertaining to a monodrama.
Wrong translation.

Containing more than once, or more than one; consisting of morethan one; manifold; repeated many times; having several, or many,parts. Law of multiple proportion (Chem.), the generalization thatwhen the same elements unite in more than one proportion, forming twoor more different compounds, the higher proportions of the elementsin such compounds are simple multiplies of the lowest proportion, orthe proportions are connected by some simple common factor; thus,iron and oxygen unite in the proportions FeO, Fe2O3, Fe3O4, in whichcompounds, considering the oxygen, 3 and 4 are simple multiplies of1. Called also the Law of Dalton, from its discoverer.-- Multiple algebra, a branch of advanced mathematics that treats ofoperations upon units compounded of two or more unlike units.-- Multiple conjugation (Biol.), a coalescence of many cells (aswhere an indefinite number of amoeboid cells flow together into asingle mass) from which conjugation proper and even fertilization mayhave been evolved.-- Multiple fruits. (Bot.) See Collective fruit, under Collective.-- Multiple star (Astron.), several stars in close proximity, whichappear to form a single system.
Learning; especially, mathematics. [R.] Pope.
One who practices or upholds monogamy. Goldsmith.
In a milky manner.
See Manteau. [Obs.] Bailey.
See Mouflon.
A person living in the marches between England and Scotland orWales.
Any species of marine annelids of the genus Maldane, or familyMaldanid√¶. They have a slender, round body, and make tubes in thesand or mud.
The science of, or a system of, weights and measures; also, atreatise on the subject.
A member of the scapolite, group, occuring in glassy crystalson Monte Somma, near Naples.
The religious system of the Moravians.
See Mellitic. [R.]
With mixture; in a mixed manner; mixedly. Bacon.
See Mistletoe.
See Marmalade. [Obs.]
The art of making microphotographs.
The hindmost mast of a three-masted vessel, or of a yawl-riggedvessel.
Same as 1st Maroon.
Same as Mameluke.
A spot. [Obs.]
The American great marbled godwit (Limosa fedoa). Applied alsoto the red-breasted godwit (Limosa h√¶matica). Hook-billed marlin, acurlew.
An ovum, as that of a mammal, only partially composed ofgerminal matter, that is, consisting of both a germinal portion andan albuminous or nutritive one; -- opposed to holoblast.
To put in a state of readiness for active service in war, as anarmy corps.

Less by a semitone in interval or difference of pitch; as, aminor third. Asia Minor (Geog.), the Lesser Asia; that part of Asiawhich lies between the Euxine, or Black Sea, on the north, and theMediterranean on the south.-- Minor mode (Mus.), that mode, or scale, in which the third andsixth are minor, -- much used for mournful and solemn subjects.-- Minor orders (Eccl.), the rank of persons employed inecclesiastical offices who are not in holy orders, as doorkeepers,acolytes, etc.-- Minor scale (Mus.) The form of the minor scale is various. Thestrictly correct form has the third and sixth minor, with a semitonebetween the seventh and eighth, which involves an augmented secondinterval, or three semitones, between the sixth and seventh, as, 6/F,7/G#, 8/A. But, for melodic purposes, both the sixth and the seventhare sometimes made major in the ascending, and minor in thedescending, scale, thus: --See Major.-- Minor term of syllogism (Logic), the subject of the conclusion.
To send amiss or incorrectly.
One skilled in myology.
The act of moving; motion. [Obs.]
Composition in metrical form; versification. [R.] Tennyson.
Having many knots or nodes.
A genus of plants (Polygala) of many species. The commonEuropean P. vulgaris was supposed to have the power of producing aflow of milk in nurses.
Mud poured out from volcanoes during eruptions; -- so called inSouth America.

A balloon which ascends by the buoyancy of air heated by afire; a fire balloon; -- so called from two brothers, Stephen andJoseph Montgolfier, of France, who first constructed and sent up afire balloon.
Varied with irregular markings, or witch a confused blending ofirregular spots and streaks.
A mass of fleshy or other more or less solid matter generatedin the uterus.
Remuneration. [Obs.]
A change in the letters or syllables of a word.
To bring or hasten to maturity; to promote ripeness in; toripen; to complete; as, to mature one's plans. Bacon.
To buy or sell in, or as in, a mart. [Obs.]To sell and mart your officer for gold To undeservers. Shak.
A yellow dyestuff extracted from the root bark of an EastIndian plant (Morinda citrifolia).
A little man. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Viciously proud. [Obs.] Shak.

A genus of small schizopod shrimps found both in fresh and saltwater; the opossum shrimps. One species inhabits the Great Lakes ofNorth America, and is largely eaten by the whitefish. The marinespecies form part of the food of right whales.
Failure. [Obs.]
The elementary and indestructible units which were conceived ofas endowed with the power to produce all the changes they undergo,and thus determine all physical and spiritual phenomena.
Having eyes affected by the moon; moonblind; dim-eyed;purblind.
Same as Marten. [Obs.]
To transfer (a piece or man) from one space or position toanother, according to the rules of the game; as, to move a king.

An American clupeoid fish (Clupea mediocris), similar to theshad in habits and appearance, but smaller and less esteemed forfood; -- called also hickory shad, tailor shad, fall herring, andshad herring.
A rock showing under the microscope the structure of a graphicgranite (pegmatite).-- Mi`cro*peg`ma*tit"ic, a.
The myristate of glycerin, -- found as a vegetable fat innutmeg butter, etc.
Having a pouch for carrying the immature young; of orpertaining to the Marsupialia.
A quantity of corn formerly given by the lord to his customarytenants, as an encouragement to, or reward for, labor and faithfulservice.
To make wonderful. [Obs.] Shak.
A lemur. See Lemur.
Riches; wealth; the god of riches; riches, personified.Ye can not serve God and Mammon. Matt. vi. 24.
To admonish; to warn. See Admonish. [Archaic] Ascham.
Capable of being bought or sold. [Obs.]
Connected with, or becoming an integral part of, a living unitor of the morphological framework; as, morphotic, or tissue,proteids. Foster.
Formed unnaturally or illegitimately; deformed. Spenser.Milton.
A hook with a long handle. [Obs.] Tusser.
A kind of easy-chair with a back which may be lowered orraised.

Any one of various species of gnats of the genus Culex andallied genera. The females have a proboscis containing, within thesheathlike labium, six fine, sharp, needlelike organs with which theypuncture the skin of man and animals to suck the blood. These bites,when numerous, cause, in many persons, considerable irritation andswelling, with some pain. The larv√¶ and pup√¶, called wigglers, areaquatic. [Written also musquito.] Mosquito bar, Mosquito net, a netor curtain for excluding mosquitoes, -- used for beds and windows.-- Mosquito fleet, a fleet of small vessels.-- Mosquito hawk (Zo√∂l.), a dragon fly; -- so called because itcaptures and feeds upon mosquitoes.-- Mosquito netting, a loosely-woven gauzelike fabric for makingmosquito bars.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, maltose; specif.,designating an acid called also gluconic or dextronic acid. SeeGluconic.
To do harm to. [Obs.] Milton.

An opening between the corbels which support a projectingparapet, or in the floor of a gallery or the roof of a portal,shooting or dropping missiles upen assailants attacking the base ofthe walls. Also, the construction of such defenses, in general, whenof this character. See Illusts. of Battlement and Castle.
A white, crystalline, aromatic substance resembling camphor,extracted from oil of peppermint (Mentha); -- called also mintcamphor or peppermint camphor.
A composer of madrigals.
Infected with or killed by murrain. [Obs.] Shak.
A rich but late variety of pea.
A kind of brass. See Maslin. [Obs.]
Resembling mucus. Dunglison. Mucoid degeneration, a form ofdegeneration in which the tissues are transformed into a semisolidsubstance resembling mucus. Quain.
One who marshals.
A tippler. [R.] Shak.
A short, heavy, double-breasted plaid coat, the design of whichis large and striking. [Local, U. S.]
, In a muddy manner; turbidly; without mixture; cloudily;obscurely; confusedly.
A rhizopod or moneran. Also used adjectively; as, a myxopodstate.
To contract mold; to grow moldy; to mold. [Obs.]Let us not moulen thus in idleness. Chaucer.
To wear ill. [Obs.] Bacon.
The lintel of a fireplace when of wood, as frequently in earlyhouses.
To feign with an evil design. [Obs.] Spenser.
Same as Mucigen.
See Motmot.
A salt of metatungstic acid.
Of or pertaining to meteorography.
See Mean.(c) (Logic) The mean or middle term of a syllogism; that by which theextremes are brought into connection.
Like a monk, or pertaining to monks; monastic; as, monkishmanners; monkish dress; monkish solitude.-- Monk"ish*ness, n.
That which has one or more of the three dimensions, length,breadth, and thickness.
See Materialist. [Obs.]

Of, pertaining to resembling, or containing, manganese;specif., designating compounds in which manganese has a highervalence as contrasted with manganous compounds. Cf. Manganous.Manganic acid, an acid, H2MnO4, formed from manganese, analogous tosulphuric acid.
To increase to the highest degree. Bentham.
Of or pertaining to the chin and lower jaw.-- n.
The discharge of the menses; also, the state or the period ofmenstruating.
Joined or constricted, at regular intervals, so as to resemblea string of beads; as, a moniliform root; a moniliform antenna. SeeIllust. of Antenna.
A mur√¶na.
To cause to be mechanical. Shelley.
A grotesque misuse of a word; a word so used.
A play of children, in swinging on ropes, or the like, tillthey are dizzy.
Organization in part. [R.]
A heavy wooden hammer or beetle. [Written also mall.]
Erroneousness.
Of or pertaining to the world; worldly; earthly; terrestrial;as, the mundane sphere.-- Mun"dane*ly, adv.The defilement of mundane passions. I. Taylor.
The quality or state of being manifest; obviousness.

Full of sorrow; expressing, or intended to express, sorrow;mourning; grieving; sad; also, causing sorrow; saddening; grievous;as, a mournful person; mournful looks, tones, loss.-- Mourn"ful*ly, adv.-- Mourn"ful*ness, n.
That branch of science which treats of moving machines.
Wrong or false worship; mistaken practices in religion. Bp.Hall.Such hideous jungle of misworships. Carlyle.
See Syntonin.
Capable of being modified; liable to modification.
One who misrepresents.
Same as Monogamian.
Inlaid work; work inlaid with pieces of wood, shells, ivory,and the like, of several colors.
A continuation of the petiole, extending from the base to theapex of the lamina of a leaf.
Speaking reproachfully; slanderous. [Obs.] Sir E. Sandys.
To date erroneously. Young.
Originally, a wig; afterwards, a mop for cleaning cannon.
A spotted trout (Salvelinus malma), inhabiting NorthernAmerica, west of the Rocky Mountains; -- called also Dolly Vardentrout, bull trout, red-spotted trout, and golet.
See Mahdism.
See Mickle.
Evil speaking. [Obs.] Atterbury.
To relate inaccurately.
A woman who commits murder.
One of the larger measures of electrical capacity, amounting toone million farads; a macrofarad.

A little hillock of earth thrown up by moles working underground; hence, a very small hill, or an insignificant obstacle ordifficulty.Having leapt over such mountains, lie down before a molehill. South.
A mass of interwoven brush, poles, etc., to protect a bank frombeing worn away by currents or waves.
A child brought up by its grandmother; a spoiled child. [R.]O, you are a more mammothrept in judgment. B. Jonson.

Formed by the action of the currents or waves of the sea; as,marine deposits. Marine acid (Chem.), hydrochloric acid. [Obs.] --Marine barometer. See under Barometer.-- Marine corps, a corps formed of the officers, noncommissionedofficers, privates, and musicants of marines.-- Marine engine (Mech.), a steam engine for propelling a vessel.-- Marine glue. See under Glue.-- Marine insurance, insurance against the perils of the sea,including also risks of fire, piracy, and barratry.-- Marine interest, interest at any rate agreed on for money lentupon respondentia and bottomry bonds.-- Marine law. See under Law.-- Marine league, three geographical miles.-- Marine metal, an alloy of lead, antimony, and mercury, made forsheathing ships. Mc Elrath.-- Marine soap, cocoanut oil soap; -- so called because, being quitesoluble in salt water, it is much used on shipboard.-- Marine store, a store where old canvas, ropes, etc., are boughtand sold; a junk shop. [Eng.]
Masseteric.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the nutmeg (Myristica).Specifically, designating an acid found in nutmeg oil and otoba fat,and extracted as a white crystalline waxy substance.
One who is sent on a mission; especially, one sent to propagatereligion. Swift. Missionary apostolic, a Roman Catholic missionarysent by commission from the pope.
A single unvaried tone or sound.
imp. of May. Etym: [AS. meahte, mihte.]
The offspring of an Indian or a negro and a European or personof European stock. [Spanish America] Mestizo wool, wool imported fromSouth America, and produced by mixed breeds of sheep.
See Maholi.
A substance obtained from, and resembling, pectin, andoccurring in overripe fruits.
Absent-minded; dazed; muddled; stupid.The whole company stared at me with a whimsical, muzzy look, like menwhose senses were a little obfuscated by beer rather then wine. W.Irving.
See Mongolian.
To educate in a wrong manner.
Having much or varied knowledge. [Obs.]
Being without mixture or adulteration; hence, strong; racy.[Obs.]

The name of a group of minerals characterized by highly perfectcleavage, so that they readily separate into very thin leaves, moreor less elastic. They differ widely in composition, and vary in colorfrom pale brown or yellow to green or black. The transparent formsare used in lanterns, the doors of stoves, etc., being popularlycalled isinglass. Formerly called also cat-silver, and glimmer.
Erroneous perception.

A small body moving through space, or revolving about the sun,which on entering the earth's atmosphere would be deflagrated andappear as a meteor.These bodies [small, solid bodies] before they come into the air, Icall meteoroids. H. A. Newton.
A mineral occurring in pale yellow or brownish hexagonalcrystals. It is an arseniate of lead.
Having the basal joints of the legs converted into jaws.
To have in wrong estimation; to repute or estimate erroneously.

A poisonous snake of the Southern United States. The watermoccasin (Ancistrodon piscivorus) is usually found in or near water.Above, it is olive brown, barred with black; beneath, it is brownishyellow, mottled with darker. The upland moccasin is Ancistrodonatrofuscus. They resemble rattlesnakes, but are without rattles.Moccasin flower (Bot.), a species of lady's slipper (Cypripediumacaule) found in North America. The lower petal is two inches long,and forms a rose-colored moccasin-shaped pouch. It grows in richwoods under coniferous trees.
The marigold; a blossom of the marigold. Shak.
To repeat wrongly; to give a wrong version of. Gov. Winthrop.
To affirm incorrectly.
That variety of xylene, or dimethyl benzene, in which the twomethyl groups occupy the meta position with reference to each other.It is a colorless inf
A mineral related to the micas, but low in silica and yieldingbrittle folia with pearly luster.
Gayety, with laughter; mirth; frolic. "Follies and lightmerriment." Spenser.Methought it was the sound Of riot and ill-managed merriment. Milton.

Evil practice; illegal or immoral conduct; practice contrary toestablished rules; specifically, the treatment of a case by a surgeonor physician in a manner which is contrary to accepted rules andproductive of unfavorable results. [Written also malepractice.]
A margin; border; brink; edge. [Obs.]The beached margent of the sea. Shak.
Unruly. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Manifold; multiple.
A stone used in mounting a horse; a horse block.
Having or consisting of lines resembling a map; as, the maplikefigures in which certain lichens grow.
Like or pertaining to the family Mustelid√¶, or the weasels andmartens.
Composed of, or resembling, muscular fiber.
Tending to mitigate; alleviating.

The act of mitigating, or the state of being mitigated;abatement or diminution of anything painful, harsh, severe,afflictive, or calamitous; as, the mitigation of pain, grief, rigor,severity, punishment, or penalty.
By or as by, magnetism.
Moorland.

Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, sea salt, or fromchlorine, one of the constituents of sea salt; hydrochloric. Muriaticacid, hydrochloric acid, HCl; -- formerly called also marine acid,and spirit of salt. See hydrochloric, and the Note under Muriate.
The process of bringing, or of coming, to maturity; hence,specifically, the process of suppurating perfectly; the formation ofpus or matter.
Thin and rather soft or pliable, as the leaves of the rose,peach tree, and aspen poplar.
The quality or state of being musculous; muscularity. [Obs.]
Tame; gentle; kind. [Obs.] Ray.
Dull-spirited. Shak.
A wrong done; a fault or crime; an offense; as, it was mymisdoing.
Of or pertaining to micrography.
Among Mohammedans, the last imam or leader of the faithful. TheSunni, the largest sect of the Mohammedans, believe that he is yet toappear.
Of or pertaining to the metatarsus.-- n.
A stuff made in imitation of velvet; -- probably the same asmock velvet. [Obs.]Our rich mockado doublet. Ford.
The fold of peritoneum which attaches the testis to the dorsalwall of the body cavity or scrotal sac.
A trifle; a trinket; a token. [Obs.] Spenser.

Formulated extemporaneously, or for a special case; -- opposedto officinal, and said of prescriptions and medicines. Dunglison.Magistral line (Fort.), the guiding line, or outline, or outline, bywhich the form of the work is determined. It is usually the crestline of the parapet in fieldworks, or the top line of the escarp inpermanent fortifications.
Destitute of a mother; having lost a mother; as, motherlesschildren.
The fresh-water drumfish (Haploidonotus grunniens).
The same Milleped.
In a monastic manner.
To swear falsely.
A mesh. [Obs.]
A communication of news; an announcement. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The doctrine that there is a tendency throughout nature towardimprovement. J. Sully.

Pertaining to, or containing, iron; chalybeate; as, martialpreparations. [Archaic] Martial flowers (Med.), a reddish crystallinesalt of iron; the ammonio-chloride of iron. [Obs.] -- Martial law,the law administered by the military power of a government when ithas superseded the civil authority in time of war, or when the civilauthorities are unable to enforce the laws. It is distinguished frommilitary law, the latter being the code of rules for the regulationof the army and navy alone, either in peace or in war.
Of or pertaining to measure.
Any coral of the genus Millepora, having the surface nearlysmooth, and perforated with very minute unequal pores, or cells. Theanimals are hydroids, not Anthozoa. See Hydrocorallia.
Destitute of mercy; cruel; unsparing; -- said of animatebeings, and also, figuratively, of things; as, a merciless tyrant;merciless waves.The foe is merciless, and will not pity. Shak.
Wrong credulity or belief; misbelief. Bp. Hall.
A collection or digest of Jewish traditions and explanations ofScripture, forming the text of the Talmud. [Written also Mischna.]

A genus of edentates, covered with large, hard, triangularscales, with sharp edges that overlap each other like tiles on aroof. They inhabit the warmest parts of Asia and Africa, and feed onants. Called also Scaly anteater. See Pangolin.
A foreign trader. [Obs.] Shak.

The show of an intention to inflict evil; a threat orthreatening; indication of a probable evil or catastrophe to come.His (the pope's) commands, his rebukes, his menaces. Milman.The dark menace of the distant war. Dryden.
See 4th Mow. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Serving to fix colors.
A kind of millet (Setaria Italica); German millet.
The longest note formerly used, equal to two longs, or fourbreves; a large.
An associate in a mess.
A process for checking the fermentation of the must of grapes.
A wrong conjecture or guess. Sir T. Browne.

That in a complex system which constitutes the materials, orinstruments employed, in distinction from the personnel, or men; as,the baggage, munitions, provisions, etc., of an army; or thebuildings, libraries, and apparatus of a college, in distinction fromits officers.

A plant that affords shelter and food to certain species ofants which live in symbiotic relations with it. Special adaptationsfor this purpose exist; thus, Acacia spadicigera has large hollowsthorns, and species of Cecropia have stem cavities. --Myr`me*co*phyt"ic (#), a.
Metalloid.
Play in which the score is reckoned by counting the holes wonor lost by each side; -- disting. from medal play.
Inducing or stimulating the secretion of mucus; blennogenous.
Nearly; almost; much. [Obs.] "Muchwhat after the same manner."Glanvill.
Conduct of one who moons. [R.]
Having soft hairs; downy.
Covered with a mitten or mittens. "Mittened hands." Whittier.
Exhibition or representation of the muscles. [R.]A good piece, the painters say, must have good muscling, as well ascoloring and drapery. Shaftesbury.
The act or art of divination. [R.]
Having no mane. Maneless lion (Zo√∂l.), a variety of the lionhaving a short, inconspicuous mane. It inhabits Arabia and adjacentcountries.
To deal or distribute wrongly, as cards; to make a wrongdistribution.
One of the larger measures of work, amounting to one millionergs; -- called also megalerg.
With the skill of a master.Thou dost speak masterly. Shak.
The number which is to be multiplied by another number calledthe multiplier. See Note under Multiplication.
A spectroscope arranged for attachment to a microscope, forobservation of the spectrum of light from minute portions of anysubstance.
The continent; the principal land; -- opposed to island, orpeninsula. Dryden.After the two wayfarers had crossed from the peninsula to themainland. Hawthorne.
One versed in the science of magnetism; a magnetist.
Beyond the scope or province of logic.
Meat. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Molybdic ocher.
Same as Meliorator.
In the manner of a mosaic.
The number by which another number is multiplied; a multiplier.
An African antelope (Hippotragus Bakeri). Its face is stripedwith black and white.
A monoclinal fold.
The apparatus used in Marconi wireless telegraphy.
To number wrongly.
A natural passage or canal; as, the external auditory meatus.See Illust. of Ear.
A beetle of the genus Melolontha, and allied genera. See Maybeetle, under May.
Measurement of time by an instrument.

Any parrot of the genus Sittace, or Macrocercus. About eighteenspecies are known, all of them American. They are large and have avery long tail, a strong hooked bill, and a naked space around theeyes. The voice is harsh, and the colors are brilliant and stronglycontrasted.

A physician. [Obs.] Shak. Medicine bag, a charm; -- so calledamong the North American Indians, or in works relating to them.-- Medicine man (among the North American Indians), a person whoprofesses to cure sickness, drive away evil spirits, and regulate theweather by the arts of magic.-- Medicine seal, a small gem or paste engraved with reversedcharacters, to serve as a seal. Such seals were used by Romanphysicians to stamp the names of their medicines.
Abounding in meat.
Enlargement or hypertrophy of the tongue.
A marquis. Lady marquess, a marchioness. [Obs.] Shak.
A prefix, in names of Scotch origin, signifying son.
The state or power of being multipresent.The multipresence of Christ's body. Bp. Hall.
A name for daisies and camomiles of several kinds.
The goddess of memory and the mother of the Muses.
Bringing or producing death; deadly; destructive; as, amortiferous herb. Gov. of Tongue.
The act of borrowing or exchanging. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.

The theme or subject; a leading phrase or passage which isreproduced and varied through the course of a comor a movement; ashort figure, or melodic germ, out of which a whole movement isdevelpoed. See also Leading motive, under Leading. [Written alsomotivo.]
A small or low mountain. [R.]
A lens convex on one side and concave on the other.
A medicine supposed to expel black bile or choler. [Obs.]
A weight of 1,000 kilograms, or 2,204.6 pounds avoirdupois.
To sit badly or imperfectly upon; to misbecome. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To diminish; to lessen.The living of poor men thereby minished. Latimer.
Ill governed, as a people; ill directed. "Rude, misgovernedhands." Shak.
A mistaken claim.
Devotion to the pursuit of wealth; worldliness. Carlyle.
One skilled in the art or science of music; esp., a skilledsinger, or performer on a musical instrument.

See Mussel. Muscle curve (Physiol.), contraction curve of amuscle; a myogram; the curve inscribed, upon a prepared surface, bymeans of a myograph when acted upon by a contracting muscle. Thecharacter of the curve represents the extent of the contraction.

Of or pertaining to mathematics; according to mathematics;hence, theoretically precise; accurate; as, mathematical geography;mathematical instruments; mathematical exactness.-- Math`e*mat"ic*al*ly, adv.
See 3d Minion.
A genus of plants. See Mouse-ear.
A writer of a monody.
The details of a banquet; a bill of fare.
A piece of metal in the form of a coin, struck with a device,and intended to preserve the remembrance of a notable event or anillustrious person, or to serve as a reward.
Having many titles.
The food supplied to the Israelites in their journey throughthe wilderness of Arabia; hence, divinely supplied food. Ex. xvi. 15.
Fit for market; such as is usually sold in market, or such aswill bring the ordinary price; as, merchantable wheat; sometimes, atechnical designation for a particular kind or class.
See Mouflon.
Same as Moonsail.
One who makes his mark, instead of writing his name, in signingdocuments. Burrill.
A compound of the so-called margaric acid with a base.
To trade; to carry on commerce. Bacon.
Small; delicate. [Obs.] "His minionette face." Walpole.
Wonderful; admirable. [Obs.] Shak.
A form of mental alienation in which the patient has grandiosedelusions.
A mitten; also, a covering for the wrist and hand and not forthe fingers.
A social musical party. [Colloq.]
Having the nature of a gift. [Obs.]
Same as Macron.
A person skilled in meteorology.
A surety, under the old writ of mainprise, for a prisoner'sappearance in court at a day.
The period of natural cessation of menstruation. See Change oflife, under Change.
An acid elevator, as a tube through which acid is forced tosome height in a sulphuric acid manufactory.
See Frogfish.
The benevolent spirits of the dead, especially of deadancestors, regarded as family deities and protectors.Hail, O ye holy manes! Dryden.
Freedom; security; immunity. [Obs.] W. Montagu.
A shrike or butcher bird; -- written also matagasse. [Prov.Eng.]
Pertaining to the muscles and the diaphragm; as, themusculophrenic artery.
Leading astray; delusive.
To aim amiss. [Obs.]
The science which relates to mammals or the Mammalia. SeeMammalia.
The system and influences of a monastic life; monasticism.
See Mule, 4.
Kind treatment. [Obs.]
For a moment. [Obs.]
A weapon resembling a hammer, often having one side of the headpointed; -- used by horsemen in the Middle Ages to break armor.Fairholt.
Mock; counterfeit; sham. [Obs.]
The least quantity assignable, admissible, or possible, in agiven case; hence, a thing of small consequence; -- opposed to Ant:maximum.
The act of magnetizing, or the state of being magnetized.
One of the bones of either the metacarpus or metatarsus.
Having spots or blotches; maculate.
The toll for grinding grain. Erskine.

A genus of very large hairy spiders having four lungs and onlyfour spinnerets. They do not spin webs, but usually construct tubesin the earth, which are often furnished with a trapdoor. The SouthAmerican bird spider (Mygale avicularia), and the crab spider, ormatoutou (M. cancerides) are among the largest species. Some of thespecies are erroneously called tarantulas, as the Texas tarantula (M.Hentzii).
Hiding; skulking; cowardly. [Colloq.] [Written also meachingand meeching.]
A short hollow cylinder surrounding an object, as a pipe.
Same as Malanders.
The Mohammedan tribes of the southern Philippine Islands, saidto have formerly migrated from Borneo. Some of them are warlike andaddicted to piracy.
Mother. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The Gorgon; or one of the Gorgons whose hair was changed intoserpents, after which all who looked upon her were turned into stone.
A mountain. [Obs.]
A female mulatto. G. W. Gable.
Containing a command; preceptive; directory.
The wife of a mayor.
Misgiving; hesitating. [Obs.] "Her misdoubtful mind." Spenser.
An instrument for measuring the muscular strength of man or ofother animals; a dynamometer. Dunglison.
One who brings to maturity.
Calling; vocation; business; trade.
The dotterel.
Like a miser; very covetous; sordid; niggardly.
To treat amiss; to abuse.
To ascend in vapors; to take the form of a meteor. Evelyn.
Same as Mollemoke.

A license to pass the limits of a jurisdiction, or boundary ofa country, for the purpose of making reprisals. Letters of marque,Letters of marque and reprisal, a license or extraordinary commissiongranted by a government to a private person to fit out a privateer orarmed ship to cruise at sea and make prize of the enemy's ships andmerchandise. The ship so commissioned is sometimes called a letter ofmarque.

A salmon (Salmo mykiss, syn. S. purpuratus) marked with blackspots and a red throat, found in most of the rivers from Alaska tothe Colorado River, and in Siberia; -- called also black-spottedtrout, cutthroat trout, and redthroat trout.
Having the form of a mandible; -- said especially of themaxill√¶ of an insect when hard and adapted for biting.
Of or pert. to, or characterized by, mania, or excitement.
A minute abrupt point, as of a leaf; any small, sharp point orprocess, terminating a larger part or organ.

Any one of numerous species of Asiatic starlings of the generaAcridotheres, Sturnopastor, Sturnia, Gracula, and allied genera. Inhabits they resemble the European starlings, and like them are oftencaged and taught to talk. See Hill myna, under Hill, and Mino bird.[Spelt also mynah.]
An instrument for measuring the intensity of magnetic forces;also, less frequently, an instrument for determining any of theterrestrial magnetic elements, as the dip and declination.
The business of a mercer.
Barreled salt beef, packed with about 80 pounds chuck and rump,two flanks, and the rest plates.
A kind of coarse punch with a rasplike face, used for making arough surface on etching ground, or on the naked copper, the effectafter biting being very similar to stippled lines.
The quality or state of being mild; as, mildness of temper; themildness of the winter.
Of, pertaining to, or like, the Mussulmans, or their customs:Mohammedan.
Pertaining to, or in honor of, Cybele; as, the Megalesian gamesat Rome.
The middle part of the main or sea. [Poetic] Chapman.
One who massacres. [R.]
Tending to convey a wrong impression; misrepresenting.
A marchioness. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A high tableland; a plateau on a hill. [Southwestern U.S.]Bartlett.
See Mel.
The monastic life, system, or condition. Milman.
The office of a moderator.
The central column in the osseous cochlea of the ear.
A yellow crystalline substance of acid properties extractedfrom fustic (Maclura tinctoria, formerly called Morus tinctoria); --called also moric acid.
A salt of malamic acid.
A bone containing marrow; pl. ludicrously, knee bones or knees;as, to get down on one's marrowbones, i. e., to kneel.
Having many, or several, capsules.
A little bagpipe. [Obs.] Drayton.
The Dutch equivalent of Mr. or Sir; hence, a Dutchman.
