Capable of being neutralized by a univalent base or basicradical; having but one acid hydrogen atom to be replaced; -- said ofacids; as, acetic, nitric, and hydrochloric acids are monobasic.
The forked bone of a fowl's breast; -- called also wishbone.See Furculum.
To shape ill; to give an ill or unnatural from to; to deform."Figures monstrous and misshaped." Pope.
Producing myosis, or contraction of the pupil of the eye, asopium, calabar bean, etc.-- n.
Of or pertaining to the language or people of the of Man.-- n.
Li
Lean; thin. [Obs.] Bailey.
A fine, soft muslin; mull.
See Moot-hill. [Scot.]
Wrong or bad management; as, he failed through mismagement.
One of the component segments of the body of an animal.
In the manner of Moslems.
A small fish; a minnow. [Prov. Eng.]
To make mad; to drive to madness; to craze; to excite violentlywith passion; to make very angry; to enrage.

A fine white claylike mineral, soft, and light enough when indry masses to float in water. It is a hydrous silicate of magnesia,and is obtained chiefly in Asia Minor. It is manufacturd into tobaccopipes, cigar holders, etc. Also called sepiolite.
The production and working or manufacture of metals. [R.] R.Park.
One of several species of sea birds of the generaSynthliboramphus and Brachyramphus, inhabiting the North Pacific.They are closely related to the murres.
See Mangel-wurzel.
A little moon. [R.] Bp. Hall.
One of the Monotremata.
Of or pertaining to the metacarpus.-- n.
With great multiplicity and diversity; with variety of modesand relations.
Produced on a mountain.
Having long legs or feet.
Pertaining to the measles; partaking of the nature of measels,or resembling the eruptions of that disease; measly.
Of or pertaining to, or in the manner or style of, the Moors;Moorish.-- n.
A widely distributed genus of fragrant herbs, including thepeppermint, spearmint, etc. The plants have small flowers, usuallyarranged in dense axillary clusters.
More; -- usually, more in number. [Obs.]An hundred thousand mo. Chaucer.Likely to find mo to commend than to imitate it. Fuller.
The act of migrating.
In a mourning manner.
One of a group of mammals having a small size as a typicalcharacteristic. It includes the lower orders, as the Insectivora,Cheiroptera, Rodentia, and Edentata.
Measured; -- a direction to perform a passage in strict ormeasured time.
One who excites contentions and quarrels. [Obs.]
An amercement. Burrill.
Of or pertaining to monogenesis.
A division of Infusoria including the Noctiluca. See Noctiluca.
An automatic instrument for registering, by photography orotherwise, the states and variations of any of the terrestrialmagnetic elements.
Conducing to ripeness or maturity; hence, conducing tosuppuration.
Bad advice.
The bright reflection of the moon's light on an expanse ofwater. [Poetic]
To calculate erroneously; to judge wrongly.-- Mis*cal`cu*la"tion, n.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, molybdenum; specif.,designating those compounds in which the element has a highervalence, as contrasted with molybdous compounds; as, molybdic oxide.
Morose. [Obs.] Sheldon.
One-leaved; composed of a single leaf; as, a monophyllousinvolucre or calyx.
Mucin. [R.]
Evil conduct; fraudulent practices; misbehavior, corruption, orextortion in office.
One of the higher order of Turkish judges; also, a Turkishtitle of respect for a religious and learned man. [Written alsomoolah.]
Of or pertaining to the metathorax.

An order of fishes in which the fin rays, except the anteriorray of the pectoral and dorsal fins, are closely jointed, and notspiny. It includes the carp, pike, salmon, shad, etc. Called alsoMalacopteri.
One who maligns.
A dreamer; an absent-minded person. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
One who cultivates land for a share (usually one half) of itsyield, receiving stock, tools, and seed from the landlord. [France &Italy] Milman.
Of or pertaining to Mantua.-- n.

Any one of numerous fishes of the genus Mugil; -- called alsogray mullets. They are found on the coasts of both continents, andare highly esteemed as food. Among the most valuable species areMugil capito of Europe, and M. cephalus which occurs both on theEuropean and American coasts.
A mistaking or mistake; wrong apprehension of one's meaning ofa fact; misconception; misunderstanding.
That science, or branch of applied mathematics, which treats ofthe action of forces on bodies.
A compound of mercaptan formed by replacing its sulphurhydrogen by a metal; as, potassium mercaptide, C2H5SK.

A quantity or coefficient, or constant, which expresses themeasure of some specified force, property, or quality, as ofelasticity, strength, efficiency, etc.; a parameter. Modulus of amachine, a formula expressing the work which a given machine canperform under the conditions involved in its construction; therelation between the work done upon a machine by the moving power,and that yielded at the working points, either constantly, if itsmotion be uniform, or in the interval of time which it occupies inpassing from any given velocity to the same velocity again, if itsmotion be variable; -- called also the efficiency of the machine.Mosley. Rankine.-- Modulus of a system of logarithms (Math.), a number by which allthe Napierian logarithms must be multiplied to obtain the logarithmsin another system.-- Modulus of elasticity. (a) The measure of the elastic force ofany substance, expressed by the ratio of a stress on a given unit ofthe substance to the accompanying distortion, or strain. (b) Anexpression of the force (usually in terms of the height in feet orweight in pounds of a column of the same body) which would benecessary to elongate a prismatic body of a transverse section equalto a given unit, as a square inch or foot, to double, or to compressit to half, its original length, were that degree of elongation orcompression possible, or within the limits of elasticity; -- calledalso Young's modulus.-- Modulus of rupture, the measure of the force necessary to break agiven substance across, as a beam, expressed by eighteen times theload which is required to break a bar of one inch square, supportedflatwise at two points one foot apart, and loaded in the middlebetween the points of support. Rankine.
Having many segments; cleft into several parts by linearsinuses; as, a multifid leaf or corolla.
Native magnesium carbonate occurring in white compact orgranular masses, and also in rhombohedral crystals.
Meditative; thoughtfully silent. "Museful mopings." Dryden.-- Muse"ful*ly, adv.
Marshy; fenny. [R.] Pennant.
The state or quality of being mazy.
An ant. [Obs.] See Pismire.

The dignity and authority of sovereign power; quality or statewhich inspires awe or reverence; grandeur; exalted dignity, whetherproceeding from rank, character, or bearing; imposing loftiness;stateliness; -- usually applied to the rank and dignity ofsovereigns.The Lord reigneth; he is clothed with majesty. Ps. xciii. 1.No sovereign has ever represented the majesty of great state withmore dignity and grace. Macaulay.
A variety of sugar obtained by the partial oxidation ofmannite, and closely resembling levulose.
Manliness; dignity; comeliness; civility. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]-- Mense"ful, a.-- Mense"less, a.
To plan; to contrive; esp., to form a scheme with the purposeof doing harm; to contrive artfully; to plot. "How long will youmachinate!" Sandys.
Misty; dark; murky; muggy. [Obs.]
An object of ridicule; a butt. Godwin.
Speaking sweetly or harmoniously.

Mischance; misfortune; ill lick; unlucky accident; illadventure. Chaucer. Homicide by misadventure (Law), homicide whichoccurs when a man, doing a lawful act, without any intention ofinjury, unfortunately kills another; -- called also excusablehomicide. See Homicide. Blackstone.
The fore part of the deck, having a bulkhead athwart ships highenough to prevent water which enters the hawse holes from runningover it.
State of being paired with a single mate.
A post, or one of a series of posts, set up to indicate spacesof a mile each or the distance in miles from a given place.
The striped mullet of California (Mugil cephalus, orMexicanus).

A capital letter; especially, one used in ancient manuscripts.See Majuscul√¶. Majuscule writing, writing composed wholly of capitalletters, especially the style which prevailed in Europe from thethird to the sixth century.
A herbaceous climbing vine (Boussingaultia baselloides) verypopular in cultivation, having shining entire leaves and racemes ofsmall fragrant white flowers.
An oxide containing one atom of oxygen in each molecule; as,barium monoxide.
Murrhine.
A false stroke with a billiard cue, the cue slipping from theball struck without impelling it as desired.
A female moderator. Fuller.
A genus of dipterous insects, including the common house fly,and numerous allied species.

An extinct genus of mammals closely allied to the elephant, buthaving less complex molar teeth, and often a pair of lower, as wellas upper, tusks, which are incisor teeth. The species were mostlylarger than elephants, and their romains occur in nearly all parts ofthe world in deposits ranging from Miocene to late Quaternary time.
A nunnery; -- a term still applied to the ruins of certainnunneries in England.
The act or practice of begging; beggary; mendicancy. Sir T.Browne.
The second day of the week; the day following Sunday.
A variety of apatite of a greenish blue color.
Having a medium compass between the soprano and contralto; --said of the voice of a female singer.-- n.(a) A mezzo-soprano voice.(b) A person having such a voice.
Pertaining to microscopy, or to the use of the microscope.Huxley.
Wine boiled and mingled with honey.
Consisting of, containing, or resembling, mother (in vinegar).
A black variety of garnet.
A genus of raptorial birds, including the European kite.
Furnished with monticles or little elevations.
A military engine formerly used for throwing stones andjavelins.
Having a medium orbital index; having orbits neither broad nornarrow; between megaseme and microseme.
The fold of peritoneum attached to the c√¶cum.-- Mes`o*c√¶"cal, a.
The doctrine, system, and practices of the Mormons.
The lowest sill of a structure, usually embedded in the soil;the lowest timber of a house; also, that sill or timber of a bridgewhich is laid at the bottom of the water. See Sill.
A genus of minute fungi. The plants consist of slender threadswith terminal globular sporangia; mold.
Soft like mush; figuratively, good-naturedly weak and effusive;weakly sentimental.She 's not mushy, but her heart is tender. G. Eliot.
Misadventure; ill-success. [Obs.] Spenser.
A kind of snuff.
A hole near the bottom, through which the sediment iswithdrawn.
The top or head of a mast; the part of a mast above the hounds.
Maggoty. [Prov. Eng.]
The practices of a mountebank; quackery; boastful and vainpretenses.
Having several or many planes or plane surfaces; as, amultiplane kite.

One of successive or homodynamous parts in animals and plants;one of a series of similar parts that follow one another in avertebrate or articulate animal, as in an earthworm; a segment; asomite. See Illust. of Loeven's larva.
To fall in very fine drops, as rain.
Erroneous citation.
To yoke improperly.
To slight or undervalue.O, for those vanished hours, so much misprized! Hillhouse.I do not blame them, madam, nor misprize. Mrs. Browning.
A hawser passed round the capstan, and having its two endslashed together to form an endless rope or chain; -- formerly usedfor heaving in the cable.
Like a mountebank or his quackery. Howell.
Mischievous. [Obs.] Foote.
One-chambered.

Any rodent of the genus Arctomys. The common European marmot(A. marmotta) is about the size of a rabbit, and inhabits the higherregions of the Alps and Pyrenees. The bobac is another Europeanspecies. The common American species (A. monax) is the woodchuck.
One who had charge of the wall of a town, or its repairs.
A young wild boar.
The concepts and relations which are conceived as beyond, andyet as related to, the knowledge gained by experience.
To wrong; to do injury to. [Obs.]Who hath you misboden or offended Chaucer.
Delicacy or softness in the representation of flesh.
See Moonstruck.
To punctuate wrongly or incorrectly.
A positive picture produced with sensitized collodion on asmooth surface of black varnish, coating a thin plate of iron; also,the process of making such a picture. [Written also melainotype.]
Creating amiss. [R.]

A low plant (Mandragora officinarum) of the Nightshade family,having a fleshy root, often forked, and supposed to resemble a man.It was therefore supposed to have animal life, and to cry out whenpulled up. All parts of the plant are strongly narcotic. It is foundin the Mediterranean region.And shrieks like mandrakes, torn out of the earth, That livingmortals, hearing them, run mad. Shak.
A rubbing or kneading of the body, especially when performed asa hygienic or remedial measure.
Of or pertaining to a metropolis; being a metropolis;metropolitan; as, the metropolitical chair. Bp. Hall.
A million webers.
A single algebraic expression; that is, an expressionunconnected with any other by the sign of addition, substraction,equality, or inequality.
See Mishna.
To carry away or mislead wrongfully, as by passion. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.

A block of black basalt, found at Dibon in Moab by Rev. F. A.Klein, Aug. 19, 1868, which bears an inscription of thirty-fourlines, dating from the 9th century b. c., and written in the Moabitealphabet, the oldest Phonician type of the Semitic alphabet. Itrecords the victories of Mesha, king of Moab, esp. those over Israel(2 Kings iii. 4, 5, 27).
Erroneous computation; false reckoning.
Dislike; aversion.
The state or quality of being monstrous, unusual,extraordinary. Shak.
In modern times. Milton.
Monarchic. Burke.
The offspring of a negress by a white man, or of a white womanby a negro, -- usually of a brownish yellow complexion.
A brown, amorphous, bitter substance having a strong emeticaction, extracted from the root of the mudar.
An agricultural implement used in Flanders, consisting of akind of large shovel drawn by a horse and guided by a man. [Writtenalso molleb√¶rt and mouldeb√¶rt.] Simmonds.
See Bonito, 3.
Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, myrrh.
A fat herring with undeveloped roe. [Written also matty.] [Eng.& Scot.]

A custom or right, analogous to borough-English in England,formerly existing in various parts of Europe, and surviving in partsof Germany and Austria, by which certain entailed estates, as ahomestead and adjacent land, descend to the youngest male heir.

An auxiliary verb qualifyng the meaning of another verb, byexpressing: (a) Ability, competency, or possibility; -- now oftenerexpressed by can.How may a man, said he, with idle speech, Be won to spoil the castleof his health ! Spenser.For what he [the king] may do is of two kinds; what he may do asjust, and what he may do as possible. Bacon.For of all sad words of tongue or pen The saddest are these: "Itmight have been." Whittier.(b) Liberty; permission; allowance.Thou mayst be no longer steward. Luke xvi. 2.(c) Contingency or liability; possibility or probability.Though what he learns he speaks, and may advance Some general maxims,or be right by chance. Pope.(d) Modesty, courtesy, or concession, or a desire to soften aquestion or remark.How old may Phillis be, you ask. Prior.(e) Desire or wish, as in prayer, imprecation, benediction, and thelike. "May you live happily." Dryden. May be, and It may be, are usedas equivalent to possibly, perhaps, by chance, peradventure. See 1stMaybe.
See Meliphagous.
Of or pertaining to Judas Maccabeus or to the Maccabees; as,the Maccabean princes; Maccabean times.
To flavor. [Obs.]
One who misconceives.
A modification of the stethoscope, for directly auscultatingthe uterus from the vagina.
The quality or state of being moderate; temperateness;moderation.
Of or pertaining to the myelon; as, the myelonal, or spinal,nerves.
The feast of St. Martin, the eleventh of November; -- oftencalled martlemans. Martinmas summer, a period of calm, warm weatheroften experienced about the time of Martinmas; Indian summer. PercySmith.
A tribe of Lepidoptera, including a vast number of minutespecies, as the plume moth, clothes moth, etc.
. See Sassy bark.
Morning time. [Poetic]
A short, precise step; an affected manner.
A class of Arthropoda, allied to the Crustacea. It includes thetrilobites, Eurypteroidea, and Limuloidea. All are extinct except thehorseshoe crabs of the last group. See Limulus.
A diseased state; unhealthiness. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A heap of ore; a mass undergoing the process of amalgamation.
A prayer; an invocation; a religious formula; a charm. [India]
The act of editing, or writing for, a magazine. [Colloq.]Byron.
Increase; enlargement. [Obs.] Bacon.
The name of several aromatic labiate plants, mostly of thegenus Mentha, yielding odoriferous essential oils by distillation.See Mentha.
To throw onto confusion or disorder; to render maudlin. [Obs.]
A mote. [Obs.] Shak.
Of or pertaining to the middle gastric lobe of the carapace ofa crab.
Of or pertaining to Madagascar or its inhabitants.
A kind of large yellow rose. [Written also Marshal Niel.]
One of the mouth appendages of Crustacea, situated next behindthe maxill√¶. Crabs have three pairs, but many of the lower Crustaceahave but one pair of them. Called also jawfoot, and foot jaw.
A combining form signifying long, large, great; asmacrodiagonal, macrospore.
Miltonic. Lowell.

One who or that which marks. Specifically:(a) One who keeps account of a game played, as of billiards.(b) A counter used in card playing and other games.(c) (Mil.) The soldier who forms the pilot of a wheeling column, ormarks the direction of an alignment.(d) An attachment to a sewing machine for marking a line on thefabric by creasing it.
The main substance of the muscular wall of the heart inclosedbetween the epicardium and endocardium.
One addicted to mannerism; a person who, in action, bearing, ortreatment, carries characteristic peculiarities to excess. Seecitation under Mannerism.
A rope of hair or of maguey fiber, for tying horses, etc.[Southwestern U. S.]
A tribe of warlike Indians formerly inhabiting NorthernCalifornia. They are nearly extinct.
See Mister, a trade.
See Mollemoke.
Same as Myopathia.
An error of a judge in charging the jury on a matter of law.Mozley & W.

One of a body of mounted soldiers recruited from slavesconverted to Mohammedanism, who, during several centuries, had moreor less control of the government of Egypt, until exterminated ordispersed by Mehemet Ali in 1811.
A bank; a fund. Mount of piety. See Mont de pi√©t√©.
A kind of sweet wine from Crete, the Canary Islands, etc. Shak.
Having a cylindrical body with a convex head of largerdiameter; having a head like that of a mushroom.
Having a mistaken confidence; wrongly trusting. [R.] Bp. Hall.
The art of making and striking medals and coins. [Written alsomedallurgy.]
Hindmost; nearest the stern; as, the mizzen shrouds, sails,etc.
A million amp√®res.
In the manner of metaphysical science, or of a metaphysician.South.
Ill feature. [R.] Keats.

I or me in person; -- used for emphasis, my own self or person;as I myself will do it; I have done it myself; -- used also insteadof me, as the object of the first person of a reflexive verb, withoutemphasis; as, I will defend myself.
One who marches.
Of or relating to the Middle Ages; as, medi√¶val architecture.[Written also medieval.]
Monocotyledonous.

A trope in which one word is put for another that suggests it;as, we say, a man keeps a good table instead of good provisions; weread Virgil, that is, his poems; a man has a warm heart, that is,warm affections.
Capable of being thrown; adapted for hurling or to be projectedfrom the hand, or from any instrument or rngine, so as to strike anobject at a distance.We bend the bow, or wing the missile dart. Pope.
Commerce; traffic; trade. [Obs.]
The power og changing color at will by the expansion of specialpigment cells, under nerve influence, as seen in many reptiles,fishes, etc. Cope.
One who manages ill.
A disease; black jaundice. See Mel.
Having a loud voice.
A person affected with melancholy; a melancholic. [Obs.] Dr. J.Scott.

A light earthy white substance, consisting of magnesium oxide,and obtained by heating magnesium hydrate or carbonate, or by burningmagnesium. It has a slightly alkaline reaction, and is used inmedicine as a mild antacid laxative. See Magnesium. Magnesia albaEtym: [L.] (Med. Chem.), a bulky white amorphous substance,consisting of a hydrous basic carbonate of magnesium, and used as amild cathartic.
A measure of energy or work done; the power exerted in raisingone gram through the distance of one meter against gravitation.
The mother of one's husband or wife.
Sulphide of mercury in isometric form and black in color.
To misjudge. [Obs.] Milton.
One who masquerades; a person wearing a mask; one disguised.
In a martial manner.
A large European sci√¶noid fish (Sci√¶na umbra or S. aquila),having white bloodless flesh. It is valued as a food fish. [Writtenalso maigre.]
To use for a bad purpose; to abuse; to misuse; as, tomisimprove time, talents, advantages, etc. South.
See Maslin.
Sheathed by mistake; wrongly sheathed; sheathed in a wrongplace. Shak.
Performing service as a minister; attendant on service; actingunder command; subordinate. "Princedoms and dominations ministrant."Milton.-- n.

The act of modifying, or the state of being modified; amodified form or condition; state as modified; a change; as, themodification of an opinion, or of a machine; the variousmodifications of light. Bentley.
A salt of metasilicic acid.
A clayey layer or pan underlying some moors, etc.
Mossiness. Jonhson.
A kind of high shoe anciently worn. [Written also moyle.]
Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, sweet clover or meliot;specifically, designating an acid of the aromatic series, obtainedfrom melilot as a white crystalline substance.
Same as Mantel.
A genus of longeared South American monkeys, including numerousspecies of marmosets. See Marmoset.
The office or rank of a major.
Same as Mosasauria.
A hill of meeting or council; an elevated place in the open airwhere public assemblies or courts were held by the Saxons; -- called,in Scotland, mute-hill. J. R. Green.

Any species of Melilotus, a genus of leguminous herbs having avanillalike odor; sweet clover; hart's clover. The blue melilot(Melilotus c√¶rulea) is used in Switzerland to give color and flavorto sapsago cheese.
Ill treatment; ill usage; abuse.
Illicit distilling. [Slang or Colloq., U. S.]
An old term covering natrolite or soda mesolite, scolecite orlime mesotype, and mesolite or lime-soda mesotype.
Wrong adjustment; unsuitable arrangement.
One who makes mischief; one who excites or instigates quarrelsor enmity.
That has one form, or retains its primary form, as, amonoplastic element.
A municipal district; a borough, city, or incorporated town orvillage.
A reformed prostitute.
Having many or several cells or compartments; as, amultilocular shell or capsule.
Making or producing myths or mythical tales.
Like a medusa; having the fundamental structure of a medusa,but without a locomotive disk; -- said of the sessile gonophores ofhydroids.-- n.
Attended with murmurs; exciting murmurs or complaint;murmuring. [Archaic or Poetic]The lime, a summer home of murmurous wings. Tennyson.
See Megafarad. [R.]
A monospermous plant.
The progeny resulting from a cross between two breeds, as ofdomestic animals; anything of mixed breed. Drayton.
The country inhabited by the Mormons; the Mormon people.
Having long or large feet, or a long stem.
A little mill.
One who follows the fashion.
One of a series of progenitors of human beings, and authors ofhuman wisdom.
A Linn√¶an order of plants, including those which have only onestyle or stigma.
Wrong measurement.
See Marrot.
One who abstractedly wanders or gazes about, as if moonstruck.[R.] Dickens.

A plant (Reseda odorata) having greenish flowers with orange-colored stamens, and exhaling a delicious fragrance. In Africa it isa low shrub, but further north it is usually an annual herb.Mignonette pepper, coarse pepper.
An evil deed; a wicked action.Evils which our own misdeeds have wrought. Milton.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, mustard; -- used specificallyto designate a glucoside called myronic acid, found in mustard seed.
Myself. [Obs.]
See Duck mole, under Duck. [Written also mollingong.]
Any species of Trichechus, a genus of sirenians; -- calledalsosea cow. [Written also manaty, manati.]
To build stonework or brickwork about, under, in, over, etc.;to construct by masons; -- with a prepositional suffix; as, to masonup a well or terrace; to mason in a kettle or boiler.
Mountance. [Obs.]
A Mohammedan; a Moslem.
A myotome.
The yard on which the mainsail is extended, supported by themainmast.
See Moorpan.
Fretwork. See Fret.
In a moving manner. Addison.

In a medical manner; with reference to healing, or to theprinciples of the healing art.

A ray of light from the moon.

A thin layer or fold of tissue, usually supported by a fibrousnetwork, serving to cover or line some part or organ, and oftensecreting or absorbing certain fluids.
Consisting of, or pertaining to, a monophthong.

Uttered in one unvarying tone; continued with dull uniformity;characterized by monotony; without change or variety; wearisome.-- Mo*not"o*nous*ly, adv.-- Mo*not"o*nous*ness, n.

A system of training and instruction, primarily for use withnormal children aged from three to six years, devised by Dr. MariaMontessori while teaching in the "Houses of Childhood" (schools inthe poorest tenement districts of Rome, Italy), and first fullydescribed by her in 1909. Leading features are freedom for physicalactivity (no stationary desks and chairs), informal and individualinstruction, the very early development of writing, and an extendedsensory and motor training (with special emphasis on vision, touch,perception of movement, and their interconnections), mediated by apatented, standardized system of "didactic apparatus," which isdeclared to be "auto-regulative." Most of the chief features of themethod are borrowed from current methods used in many institutionsfor training feeble-minded children, and dating back especially tothe work of the French-American physician Edouard O. Seguin (1812-80).
Of or pertaining to mazology.
A kind of lace made at, or originating in, Mechlin, in Belgium.
A deep flaring cuff.
A Mormon.-- a.
Hermaphrodite, or having both stamens and pistils in everyflower.

The technical name of methyl alcohol or wood spirit; also, byextension, the class name of any of the series of alcohols of themethane series of which methol proper is the type. See Methylalcohol, under Methyl.
A covering or incrusting with marble; a casing of marble; avariegating so as to resemble marble. [R.]
To paint ill, or wrongly.
Wrong guidance.
A hill. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
An aromatic plant (Thymus Serphyllum); -- called also wildthyme.
A fibrous material obtained by deviling rags or the remnants ofwoolen goods.

Of or pertaining to Manila or Manilla, the capital of thePhilippine Islands; made in, or exported from, that city. Manilacheroot or cigar, a cheroot or cigar made of tobacco grown in thePhilippine Islands.-- Manila hemp, a fibrous material obtained from the Musa textilis,a plant allied to the banana, growing in the Philippine and otherEast India islands; -- called also by the native name abaca. From itmatting, canvas, ropes, and cables are made.-- Manila paper, a durable brown or buff paper made of Manila hemp,used as a wrapping paper, and as a cheap printing and writing paper.The name is also given to inferior papers, made of other fiber.
An American wild cat (Felis tigrina), ranging from Mexico toBrazil. It is spotted with black. Called also long-tailed cat.
A mania for writing verses.
An edible fungus (Morchella esculenta), the upper part of whichis covered with a reticulated and pitted hymenium. It is used asfood, and for flavoring sauces. [Written also moril.]
The denser part of the protoplasm of a cell.
The act of measuring, or the cost of measuring.
To become gloomy or dejected in mind. Barrow.
Either one of two asclepiadaceous shrubs (Calotropis gigantea,and C. procera), which furnish a strong and valuable fiber. The acridmilky juice is used medicinally.
The continuation of a trope in one word through a succession ofsignifications, or the union of two or more tropes of a differentkind in one word.
A grotesque mask, representing a person chewing or grimacing,worn in processions and by comic actors on the stage.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid known only in itssalts (the metatungstates) and properly called polytungstic, orpyrotungstic, acid.

It haslarge obovate leaves and an egg-shaped fruit from three to fiveinches long, containing a pleasant-flavored pulp and a single largeseed. The fruit is called marmalade, or natural marmalade, from itsconsistency and flavor.

A region in the western part of the Peninsula of India, betweenthe mountains and the sea. Malabar nut (Bot.), the seed of an EastIndian acanthaceous shrub, the Adhatoda Vasica, sometimes usedmedicinally.

An instrument for measuring the tension or elastic force ofgases, steam, etc., constructed usually on the principle of allowingthe gas to exert its elastic force in raising a column of mercury inan open tube, or in compressing a portion of air or other gas in aclosed tube with mercury or other liquid intervening, or in bending ametallic or other spring so as to set in motion an index; a pressuregauge. Situated in the middle; lying in a plane dividing a bilateralanimal into right and left halves; -- said of unpaired organs andparts; as, median coverts. Median line. (a) (Anat.) Any line in themesial plane; specif., either of the lines in which the mesial planemeets the surface of the body. (b) (Geom.) The line drawn from anangle of a triangle to the middle of the opposite side; any linehaving the nature of a diameter.-- Median plane (Anat.), the mesial plane.-- Median point (Geom.), the point where the three median lines of atriangle mutually intersect.

A Portuguese money of account rated in the treasury departmentof the United States at one dollar and eight cents; also, a Brazilianmoney of account rated at fifty-four cents and six mills.

A genus of leguminous trees of tropical America, the differentspecies of which yield balsamic products, among which are balsam ofPeru, and balsam of Tolu. The species were formerly referred toMyrospermum.

of Meet.

An unaccompanied polyphonic song, in four, five, or more parts,set to secular words, but full of counterpoint and imitation, andadhering to the old church modes. Unlike the freer glee, it is bestsung with several voices on a part. See Glee.

Tending to produce death; threatening a fatal issue; virulent;as, malignant diphtheria. Malignant pustule (Med.), a very contagiousdisease, transmitted to man from animals, characterized by theformation, at the point of reception of the virus, of a vesicle orpustule which first enlarges and then breaks down into an unhealthyulcer. Gentle; pleasant; kind; soft; bland; clement; hence, moderatein degree or quality; -- the opposite of harsh, severe, irritating,violent, disagreeable, etc.; -- applied to persons and things; as, amild disposition; a mild eye; a mild air; a mild medicine; a mildinsanity.The rosy morn resigns her light And milder glory to the noon. Waller.Adore him as a mild and merciful Being. Rogers.Mild, or Low, steel, steel that has but little carbon in it and isnot readily hardened.

An instrument for intensifying and making audible very feeblesounds. It produces its effects by the changes of intensity in anelectric current, occasioned by the variations in the contactresistance of conducting bodies, especially of imperfect conductors,under the action of acoustic vibrations.

See Misgye. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being modern; recentness; novelty. M.Arnold.
Derived from, or pertaining to, the bone marrow.

A common composite herb (Achillea Millefolium) with whiteflowers and finely dissected leaves; yarrow. Water milfoil (Bot.), anaquatic herb with dissected leaves (Myriophyllum).

Of or pertaining to, or named from, Magellan, the navigator.Magellenic clouds (Astron.), three conspicuous nebul√¶ near the southpole, resembling thin white clouds.

A subclass of Mammalia, including nearly all the mammals ofAustralia and the adjacent islands, together with the opossums ofAmerica. They differ from ordinary mammals in having the corpuscallosum very small, in being implacental, and in having their youngborn while very immature. The female generally carries the young forsome time after birth in an external pouch, or marsupium. Called alsoMarsupiata.
A perforated stone-faced runner for grinding.
To cry as a cat; to mew; to caterwaul. Sir W. Scott.

Of, pertaining to, or employed in, trade or merchandise; as,the merchant service. Merchant bar, Merchant iron or steel, certaincommon sizes of wrought iron and steel bars.-- Merchant service, the mercantile marine of a country. Am. Cyc.-- Merchant ship, a ship employed in commerce.-- Merchant tailor, a tailor who keeps and sells materials for thegarments which he makes.

The art of making discriminations between objects of choice, ofdiscovering the whereabouts of hidden objects, etc., by inferencefrom the involuntary movements of one whose hand the reader holds orwith whom he is otherwise in muscular contact.

A tract of soft wet land, commonly covered partially or whollywith water; a fen; a swamp; a morass. [Written also marish.] Marshasphodel (Bot.), a plant (Nartheeium ossifragum) with linear equitantleaves, and a raceme of small white flowers; -- called also bogasphodel.-- Marsh cinquefoil (Bot.), a plant (Potentilla palustris) havingpurple flowers, and found growing in marshy places; marsh five-finger.-- Marsh elder. (Bot.) (a) The guelder-rose or cranberry tree(Viburnum Opulus). (b) In the United States, a composite shrubgrowing in salt marshes (Iva frutescens).-- Marsh five-finger. (Bot.) See Marsh cinquefoil (above).-- Marsh gas. (Chem.) See under Gas.-- Marsh grass (Bot.), a genus (Spartina) of coarse grasses growingin marshes; -- called also cord grass. The tall S. cynosuroides isnot good for hay unless cut very young. The low S. juncea is a commoncomponent of salt hay.-- Marsh harrier (Zo√∂l.), a European hawk or harrier (Circus√¶ruginosus); -- called also marsh hawk, moor hawk, moor buzzard,puttock.-- Marsh hawk. (Zo√∂l.) (a) A hawk or harrier (Circus cyaneus),native of both America and Europe. The adults are bluish slate above,with a white rump. Called also hen harrier, and mouse hawk. (b) Themarsh harrier.-- Marsh hen (Zo√∂l.), a rail; esp., Rallus elegans of fresh-watermarshes, and R. longirostris of salt-water marshes.-- Marsh mallow (Bot.), a plant of the genus Alth√¶a ( A.officinalis) common in marshes near the seashore, and whose root ismuch used in medicine as a demulcent.-- Marsh marigold. (Bot.) See in the Vocabulary.-- Marsh pennywort (Bot.), any plant of the umbelliferous genusHydrocotyle; low herbs with roundish leaves, growing in wet places; -- called also water pennywort.-- Marsh quail (Zo√∂l.), the meadow lark.-- Marsh rosemary (Bot.), a plant of the genus Statice (S.Limonium), common in salt marshes. Its root is powerfully astringent,and is sometimes used in medicine. Called also sea lavender.-- Marsh samphire (Bot.), a plant (Salicornia herbacea) found alongseacoasts. See Glasswort.-- Marsh St. John's-wort (Bot.), an American herb (Elodes Virginica)with small opposite leaves and flesh-colored flowers.-- Marsh tea. (Bot.). Same as Labrador tea.-- Marsh trefoil. (Bot.) Same as Buckbean.-- Marsh wren (Zo√∂l.), any species of small American wrens of thegenus Cistothorus, and allied genera. They chiefly inhabit saltmarshes.

Swift.
Destitute of a mouth.
Medicinal; acting like a medicine.
An itinerant player on the musette, an instrument formerlycommon in Europe.
The act of making soft or supple. [Obs.] Bacon.
See Muset.
A basic compound containing one amido group; as, methyl amineis a monamine.
A stick, carved with lines and dots, used, esp. by Australianaborigines, to convey information.
The condition, state, or habit of being mute, or withoutspeech. Max M√ºller.
A writer of miscellanies; miscellanarian.
Cast steel containing a considerable percentage of manganese,which makes it very hard and tough. See Alloy steel, above.
Of or pertaining to Ahura-Mazda, or Ormuzd, the beneficentdeity in the Zoroastrian dualistic system; hence, Zoroastrian.
Quality or state of mind. "The same hard mentality." Emerson.
Of or relating to a myriologue.
A morris dancer. [Obs.]
Epithelial mesoderm; a layer of cuboidal epithelium cells,formed from a portion of the mesoderm during the differetiation ofthe germ layers. It constitutes the boundary of the coelum.
Having many cavities.
In certain games, to score against, or take an advantage over(an opponent), as for an error, announcing the act by saying"muggins."
One of a class of poets which flourished in Nuremberg and someother cities of Germany in the 15th and 16th centuries. They boundthemselves to observe certain arbitrary laws of rhythm.
Dirt; filth; muck. [Prov. Eng.] ose.
Bad treatment; abuse. Spenser.
The distal segment of the fore limb, including the carpus andfore foot or hand.
Having or producing membranes.
Simple; unmixed. See Mere, a. [Obs.]
A catarrh. [Obs.] Gascoigne.
Of the nature of melody; relating to, containing, or made upof, melody; melodious.
The expected king and deliverer of the Hebrews; the Savior;Christ.And told them the Messiah now was born. Milton.
Mist; fine rain.
Lit., mine; that which is mine; -- used in the phrase meum ettuum, or meum and tuum; as, to confound meum and tuum, to fail todistinguish one's own property from that of others; to be dishonest.
The posterior part of the brain, including the medulla; theafterbrain. Sometimes abbreviated to meten.
Such as can be magnified, or extolled.
Sarcolemma.
The act of voiding urine; also, a morbidly frequent passing ofthe urine, in consequence of disease.
Having a bad or ugly form. "The mountains are misshapen."Bentley.-- Mis*shap"en*ly, adv.-- Mis*shap"en*ness, n.
Discomfort. [Obs.]
lord." Shak.
A print made by metallography.
A genus of bivalve mollusks, including the common long, orsoft-shelled, clam.
One who meets.

Filled with spongy pith; pithy. Medullary groove (Anat.), agroove, in the epiblast of the vertebrate blastoderm, the edges ofwhich unite, making a tube (the medullary canal) from which the brainand spinal cord are developed.-- Medullary rays (Bot.), the rays of cellular tissue seen in atransverse section of exogenous wood, which pass from the pith to thebark.-- Medullary sheath (Anat.), the layer of white semifluid substance(myelin), between the primitive sheath and axis cylinder of amedullated nerve fiber.
A whitish soluble powder used as a developer in photography.Chemically, it is the sulphate of methyl-p-amino-m-cresol.
Disposed; inclined; having a mind.Joseph... was minded to put her away privily. Matt. i. 19.If men were minded to live virtuously. Tillotson.
Having the middle of the body surrounded by bands of cilia; --said of the larv√¶ of certain marine annelids.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acidobtained by decomposition of melam, or of urea, as a whitecrystalline powder; -- called also melanurenic acid.
Moabite. Ruth ii. 6.
The principal or ruling evil spirit. E. Arnold.
Injurious. Fuller.
The person to whom property is mortgaged, or to whom a mortgageis made or given.
Of or pertaining to a meteoroid or to meteoroids.
A kind of mixed dish, as of cooked vegetables with white sauce,sweet jelly with whole fruit, etc. Also, fig., a medley.
A monopolist. Sylvester.
A monk.
To cheat by boasting and false pretenses; to gull. [R.] Shak.
The morbid deposition of black matter, often of a malignantcharacter, causing pigmented tumors.
Having an odor of musk, or somewhat the like. Milton.
A process from the middle of the coracoid in some animals.
Pertaining to, produced by, or of the nature of, magistery. SeeMagistery, 2.
See Membranous.
Of or pertaining to the forehead or frontal bones; frontal; as,the metopic suture.
The doctrines of Macedonius.
A miserable person. [Obs.] Sterne.
Mohammedanism.
The middle of the week. Also used adjectively.
Divided into many branches.
To construe wrongly; to interpret erroneously.Do not, great sir, misconstrue his intent. Dryden.Much afflicted to find his actions misconstrued. Addison.
A wrong way. [Obs.] Chaucer.
No befitting.
Produced in or by the sea.
A kind of nearly black cherry with dark red flesh and juice, --used chiefly for preserving.
Wrong speech. [Obs.]
To make mysterious; to make a mystery of.

In the Middle Ages, one of an order of men who subsisted by thearts of poetry and music, and sang verses to the accompaniment of aharp or other instrument; in modern times, a poet; a bard; a singerand harper; a musician. Chaucer.

A wind blowing part of the year from one direction, alternatingwith a wind from the opposite direction; -- a term appliedparticularly to periodical winds of the Indian Ocean, which blow fromthe southwest from the latter part of May to the middle of September,and from the northeast from about the middle of October to the middleof December.
With a low voice and indistinct articulation; in a mutteringmanner.
A small marmoset (Midas rosalia); the silky tamarin.
An erroneous explanation.
Of or pertaining to Manchuria or its inhabitants.-- n.
One skilled in coining, or in coins; a coiner.
Capable of being multiplied; multipliable.
To make sport contempt or in jest; to speak in a scornful orjeering manner.When thou mockest, shall no man make thee ashamed Job xi. 3.She had mocked at his proposal. Froude.
That form of reproduction which requires but one parent, as inreproduction by fission or in the formation of buds, etc., which dropoff and form new individuals; asexual reproduction. Haeckel.
To vouch falsely.
One of a class of sages, or "adepts," reputed to have knowledgeand powers of a higher order than those of ordinary men. --Ma*hat"ma*ism (#), n.
In the midst of; amidst. Shak.
A nervous disease in which the patient involuntarily imitatesthe words or action of another.
The quality or state of being musty.
Secreting, or producing, mucus or mucin.
Existing at the same time; contemporaneous.
Of, or relating to, a mobocracy.
A wrong position.

A crescentlike outwork. See Half-moon. Moon blindness. (a)(Far.) A kind of ophthalmia liable to recur at intervals of three orfour weeks. (b) (Med.) Hemeralopia.-- Moon dial, a dial used to indicate time by moonlight.-- Moon face, a round face like a full moon.-- Moon madness, lunacy. [Poetic] -- Moon month, a lunar month.-- Moon trefoil (Bot.), a shrubby species of medic (Medicagoarborea). See Medic.-- Moon year, a lunar year, consisting of lunar months, beingsometimes twelve and sometimes thirteen.
A rake for scraping up muck or dung. See Muckrake, v. i.,below.
The middle layer of the gonophore in the Hydrozoa.
See 1st Mot. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to the Metazoa.
See Madder.
The popular designation of the hereditary sovereign of Japan.
In Turkey, a sanjak whose head is a mutessarif.
A steward; a purveyor, particularly of a college or Inn ofCourt. Chaucer.
The quality or state of being musky; the scent of musk.
A stick used by painters as a rest for the hand while working.[Written also mahl-stick.]
A subdivision of the Niagara period in the American upperSilurian, characterized by the formations known as the Oneidaconglomerate, and the Medina sandstone. See the Chart of Geology.
Onanism; self-pollution.
An erroneous computation.
To subject to the action of machinery; to effect by aid ofmachinery; to print with a printing machine.
Dimetric.
Actuated or prompted by a devotion to money getting or theservice of Mammon. Carlyle.
Of a quality opposed to adroitness; clumsy; awkward;unskillful.-- Mal"a*droit`ly, adv.-- Mal`a*droit"ness, n.
Softness; effeminacy; weakness. [R.]
See Maslin.
Having many eyes, or more than two.
Belonging to the genus Meliphaga.
Any individual of the swarthy races of Africa or Asia whichhave adopted the Mohammedan religion. "In Spanish history the termsMoors, Saracens, and Arabs are synonymous." Internat. Cyc.
A plain cap or headdress for women or girls; especially, onetying under the chin by a very broad band, generally of the samematerial as the cap itself. Thackeray.
Property, landed or funded, so attached to a title of honor asto descend with it.
Pertaining to mediation; used in mediation; as, mediativeefforts. Beaconsfield.
The act or process of minimizing. Bentham.

A person clothed with power as a public civil officer; a publiccivil officer invested with the executive government, or some branchof it. "All Christian rulers and magistrates." Book of Com. Prayer.Of magistrates some also are supreme, in whom the sovereign power ofthe state resides; others are subordinate. Blackstone.
Of or pertaining to a manubrium; shaped like a manubrium;handlelike.
One who believes that the body of Christ was merged into theDeity when he ascended.
A Hebrew weight for gold or silver, being one hundred shekelsof gold and sixty shekels of silver. Ezek. xlv. 12.
A writer of mimes. Sir T. Herbert.

Of middle rank, state, size, or quality; about equally distantfrom the extremes; medium; moderate; mediocre; ordinary. "A town ofbut middling size." Hallam.Plainly furnished, as beseemed the middling circumstances of itsinhabitants. Hawthorne.-- Mid"dling*ly, adv.-- Mid"dling*ness, n.
Dull; stupid.
A sort of wax used in grafting, etc.
Monomyal.
A thing stolen found on the person of the thief.
A sandy calcareous straum, containing, or impregnated with,iron, and lying between the upper and lower Lias of England.
Full of mast; abounding in acorns, etc.
The Barbary ape.
Containing miasma; miasmatic.
Soft; dainty. [Obs.] B. Jonson.

A partly reduced copper sulphide, obtained by alternatelyroasting and melting copper ore in separating the metal fromassociated iron ores, and called coarse metal, fine metal, etc.,according to the grade of fineness. On the exterior it is dark brownor black, but on a fresh surface is yellow or bronzy in color.
A Mohammedan. [R.]
A louse. Hudibras.
To change by a metabolic process. See Metabolism.
The Marsipobranchiata.
To dislike; to disapprove of; to have aversion to; as, tomislike a man.Who may like or mislike what he says. I. Taylor.
In a mercurial manner.
A large Turkish ship. Crabb.
Discontinuance; also, continuance by undue process.
Dark; obscure; gloomy. "The murkiest den." Shak.A murky deep lowering o'er our heads. Addison.

Pertaining to, or derived from, gums and micilaginoussubstances; specif., denoting an acid obtained by the oxidation ofgums, dulcite, etc., as a white crystalline substance isomeric withsaccharic acid.

Any one of numerous species of small rodents belonging to thegenus Mus and various related genera of the family Murid√¶. The commonhouse mouse (Mus musculus) is found in nearly all countries. TheAmerican white-footed, or deer, mouse (Hesperomys leucopus) sometimeslives in houses. See Dormouse, Meadow mouse, under Meadow, andHarvest mouse, under Harvest.
See Meliphagan.

A gum resin, usually of a yellowish brown or amber color, of anaromatic odor, and a bitter, slightly pungent taste. It is valued forits odor and for its medicinal properties. It exuds from the bark ofa shrub of Abyssinia and Arabia, the Balsamodendron Myrrha. The myrrhof the Bible is supposed to have been partly the gum above named, andpartly the exudation of species of Cistus, or rockrose. False myrrh.See the Note under Bdellium.
The amorphous or homogenous matrix or ground mass, asdistinguished from well-defined crystals; as, the magma of porphyry.
The last or posterior segment of the thorax in insects. SeeIllust. of Coleoptera.
The musk deer. See Musk deer (below).
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid which occurs in opium,and which may be obtained by oxidizing narcotine.
See Mummery. Rowe.
Inadvertence.
One who, not being interested, maintains a cause dependingbetween others, by furnishing money, etc., to either party. Bouvier.Wharton.
The quality or state of being magisterial.
Marvel. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A thin, laminated variety of serpentine, usually of a palegreen color.
Shortsighted; purblind.
A hint, suggestion, token, or memorial, to awaken memory; thatwhich reminds or recalls to memory; a souvenir.Seasonable mementos may be useful. Bacon.
One who, or that which, modulates. Denham.
Profuse bleeding from the womb, esp. such as does not occur atthe menstrual period.
Moderately. [Obs.]A man meanly learned himself, but not meanly affectioned to setforward learning in others. Ascham.
of Misspend.
To form wrongly.
Having manifold power, or power to do many things. "Jovemultipotent." Shak.
Same as Mephitis, 1.
Marginal notes.
One of a body of nominal Christians, who speak the Arabiclanguage, and reside on Mount Lebanon and in different parts ofSyria. They take their name from one Maron of the 6th century.
To misadvise. [Obs.]
A class of air-breathing Arthropoda; -- called alsoProtracheata, and Onychophora.
A canoe or boat made from one piece of timber.
A prefix used adjectively and adverbially in the sense ofamiss, wrong, ill, wrongly, unsuitably; as, misdeed, mislead,mischief, miscreant.
That with which one makes shift; a temporary expedient. JamesMill.I am not a model clergyman, only a decent makeshift. G. Eliot.
To rain in very fine drops, like a thick mist; to mizzle.
One of the dominant people of Hungary, allied to the Finns; aHungarian.
An instrument of the ancients for finding two meanproportionals between two given lines, required in solving theproblem of the duplication of the cube. Brande & C.
The religion of Mohammed; also, idolatry. See Mawmet. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Much. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Mystery, a trade.
To print wrong.

A wasting of flesh without fever or apparent disease; a kind ofconsumption; atrophy; phthisis.Pining atrophy, Marasmus, and wide-wasting pestilence. Milton.Marasmus senilis Etym: [L.], progressive atrophy of the aged.
To err in speaking.
A hotchpotch. Sir T. Herbert.
Of or pertaining to medicaments or healing applications; havingthe qualities of medicaments.-- Med`ica*men"tal*ly, adv.
A woman who ministers. Akenside.
A messenger. [Obs.]
To make moral reflections; to regard acts and events asinvolving a moral.
Of the size and style of minuscules; written in minuscules.These minuscule letters are cursive forms of the earlier uncials. I.Taylor (The Alphabet).
In a miserable; unhappily; calamitously; wretchedly; meanly.They were miserably entertained. Sir P. Sidney.The fifth was miserably stabbed to death. South.

A crystalline nitrogenous substance having a splendiddichroism, being green by reflected light and garnet-red bytransmitted light. It was formerly used in dyeing calico, and wasobtained in a large quantities from guano. Formerly called alsoammonium purpurate.
Producing pearls.
A circular temple consisting of a roof supported on columns,without a cella.
One of an ancient sect who held that Christ had but one will ashe had but one nature. Cf. Monophysite. Gibbon.
To call by a wrong name; to miscall.
Capable of being medicated; admitting of being cured or healed.
Turning into many shapes; assuming many forms; protean.
A durable, fragrant, and dark-colored Australian wood, used bythe natives for spears. It is obtained from the small tree Acaciahomolophylla.
Munificent; liberal. [Obs. or R.]
Having the form of a brush.
One who marries.
Disordered in mind; hot-headed. Shak.
Commemorative. [Obs.] Hammond.
Property not attached to the soil.
Sullen, sulky.-- Mump"ish*ly, adv.-- Mump"ish*ness, n.
In a malignant manner.
See Mammillated.
Many times doubled; manifold; numerous.
A maltman. Swift.
Lower by a semitone; flat; as, E molle, that is, E flat.
A missionary; an envoy; one who conducts a mission. SeeMission, n., 6. "Like mighty missioner you come." Dryden.
A complex nitrogenous hydrocarbon obtained artificially (as bythe action of cyanogen chloride on aniline) as a white, crystallinesubstance; -- called also diphenyl guanidin.

Pertaining to the first part or early part of the day; being inthe early part of the day; as, morning dew; morning light; morningservice.She looks as clear As morning roses newly washed with dew. Shak.Morning gown, a gown worn in the morning before one is dressed forthe day.-- Morning gun, a gun fired at the first stroke of reveille atmilitary posts.-- Morning sickness (Med.), nausea and vomiting, usually occurringin the morning; -- a common sign of pregnancy.-- Morning star. (a) Any one of the planets (Venus, Jupiter, Mars,or Saturn) when it precedes the sun in rising, esp. Venus. Cf.Evening star, Evening. (b) Satan. See Lucifer.Since he miscalled the morning star, Nor man nor fiend hath fallen sofar. Byron.(c) A weapon consisting of a heavy ball set with spikes, eitherattached to a staff or suspended from one by a chain.-- Morning watch (Naut.), the watch between four A. M. and eight A.M..
A man who sells milk or delivers is to customers.
The state of consisting of molecules; the state or quality ofbeing molecular.
A genus of plants of the Milkweed family, mostly woody climberswith fragrant flowers, several species of which furnish valuablefiber, and one species (Marsdenia tinctoria) affords indigo.
A chiton.
The middle of winter. Dryden.
One who drives mules.
A brand originated by a dishonest cattleman, who, withoutowning any stock, gradually accumulates a herd by finding mavericks.[Western U. S.]
A kind of stout woolen cloth with unfinished face and withoutraised nap. A commoner variety has a cotton warp.
Of, pertaining to, or showing, monocrotism; as, a monocroticpulse; a pulse of the monocrotic type.
Having a single loculament.
The office of major.
To enter or insert wrongly, as a charge in an account.

A North American aquatic fur-bearing rodent (Fiber zibethicus).It resembles a rat in color and having a long scaly tail, but thetail is compressed, the bind feet are webbed, and the ears areconcealed in the fur. It has scent glands which secrete a substancehaving a strong odor of musk. Called also musquash, musk beaver, andondatra.
Of or pertaining to a region of the carapace of a crab coveringthe middle branchial region.
Having a dark complexion; of or pertaining to the Melanochroi.
To wrap the head of in a hood. [Obs.] Shak.
See Matress.
A round hill or point of land; hence, Morro castle, a castle ona hill.
One who gives or incorrect information.
One who writes a monograph.
A kind of baboon; the wanderoo.
An evil. See Mala.
Having but a single stone or kernel.
Of or pertaining to a mother; becoming to a mother; motherly;as, maternal love; maternal tenderness.
Pertaining to, or containing, mica; splitting into lamin√¶ orleaves like mica.
The main bronchus of each lung.
To conceal with masks; to disguise. "To masquerade vice."Killingbeck.
Pertaining to, or employed in, chewing.
Inhumanly. [Obs.]
Mohammedan.
A radical regarded as derived from ammonium by the substitutionof mercury for a portion of the hydrogen.
Designating, or pert. to, Marconi's system of wirelesstelegraphy; as, Marconi a√´rial, coherer, station, system, etc.
Capable of magnetized.
The dissection, or that part of anatomy which treats of thedissection, of muscles.
Worthy of meed, reward, or recompense; meritorious. "Meedfulworks." Wiclif.
A contemptuous name for Mohammed; hence, an evil spirit; adevil. [Obs.]Who's this, my mahound cousin Beau. & Fl.
To stammer. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being malleable; -- opposed tofriability and brittleness. Locke.
A salt of mannitic acid.
A South American carnivore of the genus Conepatus, allied tothe skunk, but larger, and having a longer snout. The tail is notbushy.
A bone of the carpus at the base of the third metacarpal bone.
Mazy. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
A kind of carpet having a short velvety pile.
The armed or feruled end of a staff; in a sheephook, the end ofthe staff to which the hook is attached. Sir P. Sidney.
A drinking cup. See 1st Maslin, 2. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A boundary. See Mere. [Obs.]
Intermediate. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
Approaching maturity; as, maturing fruits; maturing notes ofhand.
Of or pertaining to the middle division of the Tertiary.-- n.
Having many articulations or joints.

An East Indian sapotaceous tree (Bassia latifolia, and also B.butyracea), whose timber is used for wagon wheels, and the flowersfor food and in preparing an intoxicating drink. It is one of thebutter trees. The oil, known as mahwa and yallah, is obtained fromthe kernels of the fruit.
A cushion for terminating or softening a note made by astringed instrument with a keyboard.
A family of fungi constituting the order Melanconiales. --Mel`an*co`ni*a"ceous (#), a.
Situated in the middle.
Arranged in many rows, or series, as the scales of a pine cone,or the leaves of the houseleek.
See Mastersinger.
To suit ill.
The science of magnetism.
A kind of small roundish olive with a small freestone pit, afine skin, and a peculiar bitterish flavor. Manzanillas are commonlypitted and stuffed with Spanish pimientos.
Stoppage of the mences.
A bitter white crystalline alkaloid found in opium, possessingstrong narcotic properties, and much used as an anodyne; -- calledalso morphia, and morphina.
One who misconstrues.
A nozzle capable of turning completely round in a horizontalplane and having a limited play in a vertical plane, used inhydraulic mining, fire-extinguishing apparatus, etc.
Evil premonition; doubt; distrust. "Suspicious and misgivings."South.

A large tree of genus Melia (M. Azadirachta) found in India.Its bark is bitter, and used as a tonic. A valuable oil is expressedfrom its seeds, and a tenacious gum exudes from its trunk. The M.Azedarach is a much more showy tree, and is cultivated in theSouthern United States, where it is known as Pride of India, Pride ofChina, or bead tree. Various parts of the tree are consideredanthelmintic.The margosa oil . . . is a most valuable balsam for wounds, having apeculiar smell which prevents the attacks of flies. Sir S. Baker.
Having a round, full face.
A small mountain. [R.]
Having many fingers, or fingerlike processes.

Anything used for catching and retaining or communicating fire,made of some substance which takes fire readily, or remains burningsome time; esp., a small strip or splint of wood dipped at one end ina substance which can be easily ignited by friction, as a preparationof phosphorus or chlorate of potassium. Match box, a box for holdingmatches.-- Match tub, a tub with a perforated cover for holding slow matchesfor firing cannon, esp. on board ship. The tub contains a littlewater in the bottom, for extinguishing sparks from the lightedmatches.-- Quick match, threads of cotton or cotton wick soaked in asolution of gunpowder mixed with gum arabic and boiling water andafterwards strewed over with mealed powder. It burns at the rate ofone yard in thirteen seconds, and is used as priming for heavymortars, fireworks, etc.-- Slow match, slightly twisted hempen rope soaked in a solution oflimewater and saltpeter or washed in a lye of water and wood ashes.It burns at the rate of four or five inches an hour, and is used forfiring cannon, fireworks, etc.
Producing muriatic substances or salt. [Obs.]
To manumit. [Obs.] Dryden.
The act of killing a victim for sacrifice. [Obs.]
The act or process of beating into a plate, sheet, or leaf, asa metal; extension by beating.
A reception, or a musical or dramatic entertainment, held inthe daytime. See Soir√âe.
of May. Might.
Having a solitary head; -- said of unbranched composite plants.
Such as can be misconstrued, as language or conduct. R. North.
The art of painting or drawing in monochrome.
Menstruous. [Obs.]
A small Abyssinian antelope (Neotragus Saltiana), about thesize of a hare.

A manner of engraving on copper or steel by drawing upon asurface previously roughened, and then removing the roughness inplaces by scraping, burnishing, etc., so as to produce the requisitelight and shade. Also, an engraving so produced.

A title of courtesy prefixed to the name of a man or youth. Itis usually written in the abbreviated form Mr.To call your name, inquire your where, Or whet you think of MisterSome-one's book, Or Mister Other's marriage or decease. Mrs.Browning.

The membranes, or one of the membranes (consisting of a fold ofthe peritoneum and inclosed tissues), which connect the intestinesand their appendages with the dorsal wall of the abdominal cavity.The mesentery proper is connected with the jejunum and ilium, theother mesenteries being called mesoc, mesocolon, mesorectum, etc.
See Myth. Grote.
A spending improperly; a wasting. [Obs.] Barrow.
Of or pertaining to motorpathy.
In a manifest manner.
A mobcap. Goldsmith.
Same as Mung.
See Mur√¶na.
Dark; gloomy; murky. Spenser. Mrs. Browning.
Destitute of a motive; not incited by a motive.-- Mo"tive*less*ness, n. G. Eliot.
The power of moving.
Classification; a mode or system of classifying natural objectsaccording to certain common characteristics; as, the method ofTheophrastus; the method of Ray; the Linn√¶an method.
One of the Monandria.
The Infusoria.
Relating to manures.
The black rattlesnake (Crotalus, or Caudisona, tergemina),found in the Mississippi Valley.
Mesaraic.
The system of doctrines, polity, and worship, of the sectcalled Methodists. Bp. Warburton.
One of the smaller measures of electrical currents; themillionth part of one amp√®re.
Having the form of a mamma (breast) or mamm√¶.
Science of medicine. [Obs.]
Capable of being melted.
Monogrammic.
A large wild goat (Capra megaceros), having huge flattenedspiral horns. It inhabits the mountains of Northern India andCashmere.
The number by which another number is multiplied. See the Noteunder Multiplication.
Given to meddling; apt to interpose in the affairs of others;officiously intrusive.-- Med"dle*some*ness, n.
A species of civet; the zoril.
In various parts of Asia, an open space, as for militaryexercises, or for a market place; an open grassy tract; an esplanade.
Any mollusk which has a shell composed of more than two pieces.
One who argued moot cases in the inns of court.
Millionaire.
The state or quality of being mountainous.
A coarse lace made of twine, used especially in decoratingfurniture.
Same as Vertebrata.
The pons Varolii.
The fire god of the Ammonites in Canaan, to whom humansacrifices were offered; Molech. Also applied figuratively.
Bad government; want of government. Shak.
Under the influence of Mars; courageous; bold. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who manipulates
To regulate wrongly or imperfectly; to fail to regulate.
A thin silk fabric used for linings, etc., in ladies' dresses.
Of, pertaining to, concerned in, or occurring by, metalepsy.
The condition or quality of being muggy.
To construct wrongly; to construe or interpret erroneously.
A government mandarins; character or spirit of the mandarins.F. Lieder.
Remarkable. [Obs.] Sandys.
Converted into a mummy or a mummylike substance; having theappearance of a mummy; withered.
The world, considered as lying between heaven and hell. [Obs.]Shak.
Dark; murky.He can not see through the mantle murk. J. R. Drake.
Uttering murmurs; making low sounds; complaining.-- Mur"mur*ing*ly, adv.
The large muscle which raises the under jaw, and assists inmastication.

A lunar calendar reckoning from the year of the hegira, 622 a.d. Thirty of its years constitute a cycle, of which the 2d, 5th, 7th,10th, 13th, 16th, 18th, 21st, 24th, 26th, and 29th are leap years,having 355 days; the others are common, having 354 days. By thefollowing tables any Mohammedan date may be changed into theChristian date, or vice versa, for the years 1900-1935 a. d.
The thousandth part of one weber.
Motionless; fixed. "Moveless as a tower." Pope.
Matutinal. [R.]
To utter in a grumbling manner; to mutter.
Wandering over the world. [R.]
Mustiness.
Capable of being mixed.
Of or pertaining to the mesothorax.
Movable by hand. [R.]
A large extinct genus of labyrinthodonts, found in the EuropeanTriassic rocks.
A talebearer. [Obs.]
An instrument closely resembling the mandolin, but of largersize and tuned lower.
Having one hydrogen atom replaceable by a negative or acid atomor radical; capable of neutralizing a monobasic acid; -- said ofbases, and of certain metals.
Having numerous spiral coils round a center or nucleus; -- saidof the opercula of certain shells.
Capable of being mollified.
A marriage with a person of inferior social position; amisalliance.

The act of mystifying, or the state of being mystied; also,something designed to, or that does, mystify.The reply of Pope seems very much as though he had been playing off amystification on his Grace. De Quincey.
One who undertakes to discharge a specific business commission;a mandatory. Wharton.
In the middle of a ship; -- properly amidships.
To model. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
To store in, or as in, a magazine; to store up for use.
To make verse. [R.] Skelton.
A yard, staff, or rod, used as a measure. [Obs.] Shak.
Any one of several dark-colored augitic, eruptive rocks alliedto basalt.
To assay, or attempt, improperly or unsuccessfully. [Obs.] W.Browne.
A bolter from the Republican party in the national election of1884; an Independent. [Political Cant, U.S.]
To graft wrongly.

A comprehensive name for all of the pretended arts which claimto produce effects by the assistance of supernatural beings, ordeparted spirits, or by a mastery of secret forces in nature attainedby a study of occult science, including enchantment, conjuration,witchcraft, sorcery, necromancy, incantation, etc.An appearance made by some magic. Chaucer.Celestial magic, a supposed supernatural power which gave to spiritsa kind of dominion over the planets, and to the planets an influenceover men.-- Natural magic, the art of employing the powers of nature toproduce effects apparently supernatural.-- Superstitious, or Geotic, magic, the invocation of devils ordemons, involving the supposition of some tacit or express agreementbetween them and human beings.
Mother; -- word of tenderness and familiarity. [Written alsomama.]Tell tales papa and mamma. Swift.
Inflammation of the membranes of the brain or spinal cord.Cerebro-spinal meningitis. See under Cerebro-spinal.
The tribal history of forms; that part of phylogeny whichtreats of the tribal history of forms, in distinction from the tribalhistory of functions. Haeckel.
Of or pertaining to the Middle Ages; medi√¶val.
The European bee-eater. See Bee-eater. [Written also modwall.]
In the metric system, one million meters, or one thousandkilometers.
A mixing of races; amalgamation, as by intermarriage of blackand white.
Of or pertaining to the Muscicapid√¶, a family of birds thatincludes the true flycatchers.
That on which anything is mounted; a setting; hence, a saddlehorse. [Obs.] Spenser.
Manual.-- n.
The act or process of macerating.
Same as Midden.
A small copper coin of Spain, equal to three mils Americanmoney, less than a farthing sterling. Also, an ancient Spanish goldcoin.

Any substance which dissolves a solid body; a solvent.The proper menstruum to dissolve metal. Bacon.All liquors are called menstruums which are used as dissolvents, orto extract the virtues of ingredients by infusion or decoction.Quincy.
The quality or state of being mucous; sliminess.
See Franciscan Nuns, under Franciscan, a.
See Mich. [Obs. or Colloq.]
A salt of mandelic acid.
See Mollah.
A close-grained, neavy wood of a brownish color, brought fromBrazil, and used in turning, for making the handles of tools, and thelike. [Written also mostahiba.] MaElrath.
To reduce to method; to dispose in due order; to arrange in aconvenient manner; as, to methodize one's work or thoughts.Spectator.
Of or pertaining to Milan in Italy, or to its inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.

According to the mode, or customary manner; conformed to thefashion; fashionable; hence, conventional; as, a modish dress; amodish feast. Dryden. "Modish forms of address." Barrow.-- Mod"ish*ly, adv.-- Mod"ish*ness, n.
Being a monosyllable, or composed of monosyllables; as, amonosyllabic word; a monosyllabic language.-- Mon`o*syl*lab"ic*al*ly, adv.
The bearded tortoise (Chelys fimbriata) of South Americanrivers.
Resident; residentiary; as, mansionary canons.
The most posterior of the three pairs of embryonic renal organsdeveloped in many vertebrates.
One of the smaller cells, or blastomeres, resulting from thecomplete segmentation of a telolecithal ovum.
Distinct markings resembling the variegations of marble, as onbirds and insects.
Any singing bird of the genus Motacilla; a wagtail.
The middle part of the day; noon.
A loose outer garment worn the 16th and 17th centuries.
A dome parallel to the longer lateral axis of an orthorhombiccrystal. See Dome, n., 4.
A misinformer.
See Muzzle. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To defy. [Obs.] J. Webster.
A blur, or an appearance of a double impression, as when thepaper slips a little; a mackle.
The Irish elk.
A liquid measure equal to four gills, or an imperial pint.[Scot.]
Of or pertaining to the masseter.

A soft woolly mass prepared from the young leaves of ArtemisiaChinensis, and used as a cautery by burning it on the skin; hence,any substance used in a like manner, as cotton impregnated withniter, amadou.
An Offensive to the sense of smell; ill-smelling.-- Mal*o"dor*ous*ness. n. Carlyle.
Cultivation. [Obs.] Spenser.
One guilty of mutiny.
Having, or abounding with, mites.
Of the nature of, or like, marrow.
To subject to fine or amercement; to mulct; to amerce. [Obs.]
Connected with the formation of mucin; resembling mucin.The mucigenous basis is manufactured at the expense of the ordinaryprotoplasm of the cell. Foster.
Affected with madness; raging; furious.-- Mad"ding*ly, adv. [Archaic]Far from the madding crowd's ignoble strife. Gray.The madding wheels Of brazen chariots raged. Milton.
An animal (usually an old mare), wearing a bell and acting asthe leader of a troop of pack mules. [S. America]
A morbid condition in which the blood contains black pigmenteither floating freely or imbedded in the white blood corpuscles.
A picture of the Virgin Mary (usually with the babe).The Italian painters are noted for drawing the Madonnas by their ownwives or mistresses. Rymer.
See Metaphysics.
One of the Mollusca. [Written also mollusc.]
A tumor consisting of muscular tissue.
In the game of gleek, four cards of the same value, as fouraces or four kings; hence, four of anything. [Obs.] [Written alsomournival.]
Pertaining to, or denoting, any one of a series of compounds ofcertain metallic elements with organic radicals; as, zinc methyl,sodium ethyl, etc. [Written also metallorganic.]
To sport or make diversion in a mask or disguise; to mask.With mumming and with masking all around. Spenser.
Of or pertaining to the Malacozoa.
That part of the skeleton of the hind or lower limb between thetarsus and phalanges; metatarse. It consists, in the human foot, offive bones. See Illustration in Appendix.
Originally, a dealer in any kind of goods or wares; nowrestricted to a dealer in textile fabrics, as silks or woolens.[Eng.]
A woman's glove with a long, loosely fitting wrist.
Same as Microlite, 2.
A part; a fragment; a portion. [Obs.]
To move away; to go off. [Prov. Eng. or Local, U. S.]
Consisting of milk. [Obs.]
Of moment or consequence; very important; weighty; as, amomentous decision; momentous affairs.-- Mo*men"tous*ly, adv.-- Mo*men"tous*ness, n.
A mountaineer. [Obs.]
The hawthorn.
Quality, state, or degree, of a multivalent element, atom, orradical.
Obedient; obsequious. [Obs.] Brathwait.

The change of form which one animal species undergoes in aseries of successively produced individuals, extending from the onedeveloped from the ovum to the final perfected individual. Hence,metagenesis involves the production of sexual individuals bynonsexual means, either directly or through intervening sexlessgenerations. Opposed to monogenesis. See Alternate generation, underGeneration.
The front median plate of the labium in insects. See Labium.
Same as Malagasy.
A kind of shell limestone, whose strata form the middle one ofthe three divisions of the Triassic formation in Germany. See Chart,under Geology.
An instrument for noting minute portions of time.
Unnatural softness of any organ or part. Dunglison.
See Menhaden.
An instrument for executing minute writing or engraving.
A mineral occurring in small yellow crystals, found in thelavas (melilite basalt) of Vesuvius, and elsewhere. [Written alsomellilite.]
One who kills a human being; one who commits manslaughter.
One who regards Father, Son, and Spirit as modes of being, andnot as persons, thus denying personal distinction in the Trinity.Eadie.
To speak ill. [Obs.] Spenser.
See Muscat.
The act of demonstrating; proof. [Obs.]A certain monstration. Grafton.
The unlawful killing of a man, either in negligenc
To send on a mission. [Mostly used in the form of the pastparticiple.] Keats.
Same as 1st Morris.
Formed of small stones.
Formed with meshes; netted.
The posterior of the three principal basal cartilages in thefins of fishes.-- Me*tap`ter*yg"i*al, a.
To substitute motor-driven vehicles, or automobiles, for thehorses and horse-drawn vehicles of (a fire department, city, etc.). --Mo`tor*i*za"tion (#), n.
In the mind; in thought or meditation; intellectually; in idea.
Not to become; to suit ill; not to befit or be adapted to.Macaulay.Thy father will not act what misbecomes him. Addison.
Manganese.
A gallinule (Notornis Mantelli) formerly inhabiting NewZealand, but now supposed to be extinct. It was incapable of flight.See Notornis.
An alehouse; a pothouse. Tickel.

Of, pertaining to, or characterized by, the essential andimplied properties of a metal, as contrasted with a nonmetal ormetalloid; basic; antacid; positive. Metallic iron, iron in the stateof the metal, as distinquished from its ores, as magnetic iron.-- Metallic paper, paper covered with a thin solution of lime,whiting, and size. When written upon with a pewter or brass pencil,the lines can hardly be effaced.-- Metallic tinking (Med.), a sound heard in the chest, when acavity communicating with the air passages contains both air andliquid.
Having many phases; specif. (Elec.),
One who manufactures.
A South American curassow of the genus Mitua.

A frozen dessert of a frothy texture, made of sweetened andflavored whipped cream, sometimes with the addition of egg yolks andgelatin. Mousse differs from ice cream in being beaten before -- notduring -- the freezing process.
To manage ill or improperly; as, to mismanage public affairs.
Like the moon; variable.Being but a moonish youth. Shak.

Made of the stone or material called by the Romans murrha; --applied to certain costly vases of great beauty and delicacy used bythe luxurious in Rome as wine cups; as, murrhine vases, cups,vessels. Murrhine glass, glassware made in imitation of murrhinevases and cups.
To observe inaccurately; to mistake in observing. Locke.
To conceive wrongly; to interpret incorrectly; to receive afalse notion of; to misjudge; to misapprehend.Those things which, for want of due consideration heretofore, theyhave misconceived. Hooker.
Mohammedanism.
An extravagant fiction embodying an account of some marvelousexploit or adventure.
A membrane of a seed. See Secundine.
In a morbid manner.
Same as Belvedere.
A small South American monkey (Mico melanurus), allied to themarmoset. The name was originally applied to an albino variety.
To guess wrongly.
The parenchyma of a leaf between the skin of the two surfaces.Gray.
Born to misfortune. Spenser.

Using soft words; plausible; affectedly or timidly delicate ofspeech; unwilling to tell the truth in plain language. "Mealy-mouthedphilanthropies." Tennyson.She was a fool to be mealy-mouthed where nature speaks so plain.L'Estrange.-- Meal"y-mouth`ness, n.

Any combination of qualities or relations, considered apartfrom the substance to which they belong, and treated as entities;more generally, condition, or state of being; manner or form ofarrangement or manifestation; form, as opposed to matter.Modes I call such complex ideas, which, however compounded, containnot in them the supposition of subsisting by themselves, but areconsidered as dependencies on, or affections of, substances. Locke.
The fold of peritoneum connecting the stomach with the dorsalwall of the abdominal cavity; the mesogastrium.
The spleen.
To act coyly like a maiden; -- with it as an indefinite object.For had I maiden'd it, as many use. Loath for to grant, but loatherto refuse. Bp. Hall.
The common European gull (Larus canus); -- called also mar. SeeNew, a gull.
One who is skilled in or practices microtomy.
In the classification of Cohn, one of the four tribes ofBacteria.
Of or pertaining to manipulation.
The state or quality of being massy; ponderousness.
A salt of mucic acid.
of Melt. Chaucer. Spenser.
An instrument for cutting or scarifying the uterus or the neckof the uterus.
Of a middle quality; of but a moderate or low degree ofexcellence; indifferent; ordinary. " A very mediocre poet." Pope.
Of or pertaining to melodrama; like or suitable to a melodrama;unnatural in situation or action.-- Mel`o*dra*mat"ic*al*ly, adv.
Any spider crab of the genus Maia, or family Maiad√¶.
Moroseness. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
The oxeye daisy.
A discharge from the bowels of black matter, consisting ofaltered blood.
The larva of the bean fly.
A house where insane persons are confined; an insane asylum; abedlam.
A form of corbel arch employing regular small corbels.
A European whitefish of the genus Coregonus.

A town and district upon the seacoast of the Malay Peninsula.Malacca cane (Bot.), a cane obtained from a species of palm of thegenus Calamus (C. Scipionum), and of a brown color, often mottled.The plant is a native of Cochin China, Sumatra, and Malays.
Pertaining to a natural order (Magnoliace√¶) of trees of whichthe magnolia, the tulip tree, and the star anise are examples.
One of a family of fresh-water pectinibranchiate mollusks,having a turret-shaped shell.
The art of using the microtome; investigation carried on withthe microtome.
See Muscadel.
A salt of meconic acid.

An instrument, used with a telescope or microscope, formeasuring minute distances, or the apparent diameters of objectswhich subtend minute angles. The measurement given directly is thatof the image of the object formed at the focus of the object glass.Circular, or Ring, micrometer, a metallic ring fixed in the focus ofthe object glass of a telescope, and used to determine differences ofright ascension and declination between stars by observations of thetimes at which the stars cross the inner or outer periphery of thering.-- Double image micrometer, a micrometer in which two images of anobject are formed in the field, usually by the two halves of abisected lens which are movable along their line of section by ascrew, and distances are determined by the number of screwrevolutions necessary to bring the points to be measured into opticalcoincidence. When the two images are formed by a bisected objectsglass, it is called a divided-object-glass micrometer, and when theinstrument is large and equatorially mounted, it is known as aheliometer.-- Double refraction micrometer, a species of double imagemicrometer, in which the two images are formed by the doublerefraction of rock crystal.-- Filar, or Bifilar, micrometer.
