See under Bifilar.-- Micrometer caliper or gauge (Mech.), a caliper or gauge with amicrometer screw, for measuring dimensions with great accuracy.-- Micrometer head, the head of a micrometer screw.-- Micrometer microscope, a compound microscope combined with afilar micrometer, used chiefly for reading and subdividing thedivisions of large astronomical and geodetical instruments.-- Micrometer screw, a screw with a graduated head used in someforms of micrometers.-- Position micrometer. See under Position.-- Scale, or Linear, micrometer, a minute and very delicatelygraduated scale of equal parts used in the field of a telescope ormicroscope, for measuring distances by direct comparison.
See Mechitarist.
A kind of gonophore produced by hydroids of the genusGonothyr√¶a. It has tentacles, and otherwise resembles a free medusa,but remains attached by a pedicel.

The principal or most important spring in a piece of mechanism,especially the moving spring of a watch or clock or the spring in agunlock which impels the hammer. Hence: The chief or most powerfulmotive; the efficient cause of action.
One who believes that Christ will reign personally on earth athousand years; a Chiliast; also, a believer in the universalprevalence of Christianity for a long period.
The feat of the archangel Michael, a church festival,celebrated on the 29th of September. Hence, colloquially, autumn.Michaelmas daisy. (Bot.) See under Daisy.
Wishing evil; disposed to injure others; rejoicing in another'smisfortune.
A miscreant, or believer in a false religious doctrine. [Obs.]Holinshed.
Any one of several species of small lemurs, as Lemur murinus,which resembles a rat in size.
See Moebles. [Obs.]
The wife of a marquis; a marchioness.
A vessel having (so many) masts; -- used only in compounds; as,a two-master.
Tending or serving to modify; modifying. Max M√ºller.
The third above the keynote; -- so called because it dividesthe interval between the tonic and dominant into two thirds.
Resembling marl; partaking of the qualities of marl.
Biting; acrid; as, the mordicant quality of a body. [R.] Boyle.
A species of small opossum (Didelphus murina) ranging fromMexico to Brazil.
Cultivation. [Obs.] Warner.
Relating to a member.
One who measures; one whose occupation or duty is to measurecommondities in market.
The art of forming melody; melody; -- now often used for amelodic passage, rather than a complete melody.
Margaric.
A retinue of servants; a household. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Any of several arthropods erroneously supposed to kill livestock, in the southern United States, by stinging or by beingswallowed; as:(a) A whip scorpion. [Florida](b) A walking-stick insect. [Texas](c) A mantis.(d) A wheel bug.
The quality of being magniloquent; pompous discourse;grandiloquence.
To alter wrongly; esp., to alter for the worse. Bp. Hall.
The quality of being martial.
gives a mortgage.
Molluscan.
Done in a moment; continuing only a moment; lasting a veryshort time; as, a momentary pang.This momentary joy breeds months of pain. Shak.
See Molossus.

A class, or subclass, of arthropods, related to the hexapodinsects, from which they differ in having the body made up ofnumerous similar segments, nearly all of which bear true jointedlegs. They have one pair of antenn√¶, three pairs of mouth organs, andnumerous tracha√¶, similar to those of true insects. The larv√¶, whenfirst hatched, often have but three pairs of legs. See Centiped,Galleyworm, Milliped.
An extinct mammal of the Horse family, but not larger than asheep, and having three toes on each foot.
Belonging to the Moesogoths, a branch of the Goths who settledin Moesia.

Compacted into, or consisting of, a mass; having bulk andweight ot substance; ponderous; bulky and heavy; weight; heavy; as, amassy shield; a massy rock.Your swords are now too massy for your strengths, And will not beuplifted. Shak.Yawning rocks in massy fragments fly. Pope.
Made. Chaucer.
It seems to me. [Poetic]
One who is versed in, or who studies, mycology.
The Australian crested goatsucker (√Ügotheles Nov√¶-Hollandi√¶).Also applied to other allied birds, as Podargus Cuveiri.
Transposition, as of the letters or syllables of a word; as,pistris for pristis; meagre for meager.
A trader. Bunyan.

Of or pertaining to marriage; derived from marriage; connubial;nuptial; hymeneal; as, matrimonial rights or duties.If he relied upon that title, he could be but a king at courtesy, andhave rather a matrimonial than a regal power. Bacon.
The European whiting.
Of or pertaining to the genus Miliola; containing miliolites.
An aviator. [Colloq.]
A fern of the genus Hemionitis.
A handkerchief.
The muskellunge.
Of or pertaining to the chin; genian; as, the mental nerve; themental region.
The menstrual flux; menses. [Obs.]
One who depends on merit for salvation. [Obs.] Milner.
Having many hoofs.

Of, pertaining to, or discovered by, Meibomius. Meibomianglands, the slender sebaceous glands of the eyelids, which discharge,through minute orifices in the edges of the lids, a fatty secretionserving to lubricate the adjacent parts.
To state erroneously.
A genus of labiate herbs, including the balm, or bee balm(Melissa officinalis).
Evil accident; ill luck; misfortune; mischance. Chaucer.Secure from worldly chances and mishaps. Shak.
A sporangium or conceptacle containing only very minute spores.Cf. Macrosporangium.
Dying; a gradual decrescendo at the end of a strain or cadence.
Mortling. [Eng.] Ainsworth.
A subdivision of decapod Crustacea, having the abdomen largelydeveloped. It includes the lobster, prawn, shrimp, and many similarforms. Cf. Decapoda.
Like a maid; suiting a maid; maiden-like; gentle, modest,reserved.Must you be blushing . . . What a maidenly man-at-arms are you become! Shak.
The deity who assigns to every man his lot.
To mix. [Obs.] Spenser.
In a magistral manner. Abp. Bramhall.
Pertaining to the maxilla and mandible; as, the maxillo-mandibular nerve.
To divide wrongly.
Misconception. [Obs.]
A small medal.
To handle ill or wrongly; to maltreat.
The process of restoring a cheek which has been destroyedwholly or in part.
Long and tedious talk without much substance; superfluity ofwords.
One who fights in single combat; a duelist.
A fire-backed pheasant. See Fireback.

Consisting of one color, or presenting rays of light of onecolor only. Monochromatic lamp (Opt.),a lamp whose flame yields raysof some one homogenous light. It is of great importance in opticalexperiments.
Of or pertaining to mountains; consisting of mountains.
A mythologist.
One of a number of copies of anything multiplied mechanically.
Of great bulk or consequence; very important. [Obs.] Dr. H.More.
A history or account of martyrs; a register of martyrs. Bp.Stillingfleet.
A scramble, as when small objects are thrown down, to be takenby those who can seize them; a confused struggle. Shak.

A cavity cut into a piece of timber, or other material, toreceive something (as the end of another piece) made to fit it, andcalled a tenon. Mortise and tenon (Carp.), made with a mortise andtenon; joined or united by means of a mortise and tenon; -- usedadjectively.-- Mortise joint, a joint made by a mortise and tenon.-- Mortise lock. See under Lock.-- Mortise wheel, a cast-iron wheel, with wooden clogs inserted inmortises on its face or edge; -- also called mortise gear, and coregear.

One of a sect in the United States, followers of Joseph Smith,who professed to have found an addition to the Bible, engraved ongolden plates, called the Book of Mormon, first published in 1830.The Mormons believe in polygamy, and their hierarchy of apostles,etc., has control of civil and religious matters.

A color of a delicate purple, violet, or lilac. Mauve aniline(Chem.), a dyestuff produced artificially by the oxidation ofcommercial aniline, and the first discovered of the so-called coal-tar, or aniline, dyes. It consists of the sulphate of mauve√Øne, andis a dark brown or bronze amorphous powder, which dissolves to abeatiful purple color. Called also aniline purple, violine, etc.
See Melocoton.
In a mazy manner.
A priest who celebrates Mass. [R.] Bale.
Approaching maturity.
Same as Monandrous.
To mix; to meddle. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A South American wild dog (Canis cancrivorus); the crab-eatingdog.
Having the inflections of, or construed with, words pertainingespecially to male beings, as distinguished from feminine and neuter.See Gender.-- Mas"cu*line*ly, adv.-- Mas"cu*line*ness, n.
One who murmurs.
See Mohammedanism.
Lit., remember to die, i.e., that you must die; a warning to beprepared for death; an object, as a death's-head or a personalornament, usually emblematic, used as a reminder of death.
Dead pay; the crime of taking pay for the service of deadsoldiers, or for services not actually rendered by soldiers. [Obs.]Bacon.
A unit of conductivity, being the reciprocal of the ohm.

A sojourner; an immigrant; an alien resident in a Grecian city,but not a citizen. Mitford.The whole force of Athens, metics as well as citizens, and all thestrangers who were then in the city. Jowett (Thucyd. ).
Like or pertaining to the genus Mugil, or family Mugilid√¶.
That which is thrown into a scale to make weight; something oflittle account added to supply a deficiency or fill a gap.
To fail to apprehend; to misunderstand. [Obs.] Holland.
One of a tribe of Indians who formed part of the Five Nations.They formerly inhabited the valley of the Mohawk River.
One who worships wrongly.

An antidote against poison, or a composition in form of anelectuary, supposed to serve either as a remedy or a preservativeagainst poison; an alexipharmic; -- so called from King Mithridates,its reputed inventor.[Love is] a drop of the true elixir; no mithridate so effectualagainst the infection of vice. Southey.
The state or quality of being muscular. Grew.
A dark race inhabiting the Micronesian Islands. They aresupposed to be a mixed race, derived from Polynesians and Papuans.
Of or pertaining to meadows; resembling, or consisting of,meadow.
The middle bark of a tree; the green layer of bark, usuallysoon covered by the outer or corky layer, and obliterated.
Wrong arrangement.
Of or pertaining to Messina, or its inhabitans.
One of the Mastigopoda.
A modification of the magic lantern, used esp. for throwing amagnified image of an opaque object on a screen, solar or artificiallight being used.
A battlement in ancient fortifications with interstices forfiring through.
Exceedingly; very; very much. "A monstrous thick oil on thetop." Bacon.And will be monstrous witty on the poor. Dryden.
An edible fungus. Same as 1st Morel.
To mark with spots of different color, or shades of color, asif stained; to spot; to maculate.
To train amiss.
An uxorious, effeminate, or spiritless man. [Obs.] Johnson.
A sulphide of iron resembling pyrite or common iron pyrites incomposition, but differing in form; white iron pyrites. Goldenmarcasite, tin. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to a mile, or to distance by miles; denoting amile or miles.A milliary column, from which they used to compute the distance ofall the cities and places of note. Evelyn.
A spiritual change, as during baptism.
Of or pertaining an acid intermediate between malic acid andmalamide, and known only by its salts.
A kind of musical toy into which one sings, hums, or speaks,producing a coarse, reedy sound.
To render warlike; as, to martialize a people.
A kind of open helmet, without visor or beaver, and somewhatresembling a hat.A battered morion on his brow. Sir W. Scott.
Having the form of a mammilla.

Of or pertaining to Cardinal Mazarin, prime minister of France,1643-1661. Mazarine Bible, the first Bible, and perhaps the firstcomplete book, printed with movable metal types; -- printed byGutenberg at Mentz, 1450-55; -- so called because a copy was found inthe Mazarine Library, at Paris, about 1760.-- Mazarine blue, a deep blue color, named in honor of CardinalMazarin.
A South African lemur (Galago maholi), having very large ears.[Written also moholi.]
The quality of being mensurable.
A sparoid fish (Diabasis aurolineatus) of the Gulf of Mexico,esteemed as a food fish; -- called also red-mouth grunt.
The scup. [Local, U. S.]
Of or pertaining to a mother; like, or suitable for, a mother;tender; maternal; as, motherly authority, love, or care. Hooker.
Of or pertaining to Freemasons or to their craft or mysteries.
Such as can be used or transferred as merchandise.
A demand. [Obs.] See Demand.
See Mathematical.
Proceeding from disease; morbid; unhealthy.Morbose tumors and excrescences of plants. Ray.
To seek for wrongly. [Obs.]
The act of manumitting, or of liberating a slave from bondage."Given to slaves at their manumission." Arbuthnot.
Merchantlike; suitable to the character or business of amerchant. [Obs.] Gauden.
An old form of gunlock containing a match for firing thepriming; hence, a musket fired by means of a match.
The art of mechanically multiplying copies of a writing, or anywork of art.
Containing, or resembling, marble.
One versed in the science of malacology.
A militiaman who was to be ready to march at a moment's notice;-- a term used in the American Revolution.
The farm attached to a mansion house. [Scot.]
Monstrous in size. Pope.
One who believes in the millennium. [Obs.] Johnson.
Receiving its charge through the muzzle; as, a muzzle-loadingrifle.
Border; margin; edge; verge. [Poetic] Tennyson.Along the river's stony marge. Wordsworth.
A picture made up of several smaller pictures, drawn uponseparate pieces in such a manner as to admit of combination in manydifferent ways, thus producing a great variety of scenes orlandscapes.
Capable of being made.
Having the edge veined or spotted with different colors likemarble, as a book.
Flowing as with honey; smooth; flowing sweetly or smoothly; as,a mellifluous voice.-- Mel*lif"lu*ous*ly, adv.
A wise and faithful counselor or monitor.
The theory or doctrine that the human races have a commonorigin, or constitute a single species.
. A fine oil obtained from the kernel of Prunus brigantiaca. Itis used instead of olive or almond oil. De Colange.
See Merrymake, n.
Imitation; mimicry.
Pertaining to, or designating, one of several isomeric acidsobtained from citric acid.
Lasting but one day.
Irregular; disorderly. [Obs.]
Partaking of the nature of, or consisting of, mica and lime; --applied to a mica schist containing carbonate of lime.
Pertaining to that part of the columella of the ear which, insome animals, connects the stapes with the other parts of thecolumella.-- n.
A man who controls a motor.

An elementary substance, as sodium, calcium, or copper, whoseoxide or hydroxide has basic rather than acid properties, ascontrasted with the nonmetals, or metalloids. No sharp line can bedrawn between the metals and nonmetals, and certain elements partakeof both acid and basic qualities, as chromium, manganese, bismuth,etc.
Having large teeth.-- n.
One who edits or writes for a magazine. [R.]

A love-singer; specifically, one of a class of German poets andmusicians who flourished from about the middle of the twelfth to themiddle of the fourteenth century. They were chiefly of noble birth,and made love and beauty the subjects of their verses.
A poisonous amido acid, C6H13NO2, separated by Brieger fromdecaying horseflesh. In physiological action, it is similar tocurare.
One of a genus (Calochortus) of tuliplike bulbous herbs withlarge, and often gaycolored, blossoms. Called also butterfly lily.Most of them are natives of California.
Capable of being masticated.
Without moisture.
Any monocotyledonous plant.
Relating to the morning, or to matins; matutinal.
A genus of Foraminifera, having a porcelanous shell withseveral longitudinal chambers.
Full of spirit; possessing constitutional ardor; fiery; as, amettlesome horse.-- Met"tle*some*ly, adv.-- Met"tle*some*ness, n.
The sea mew. [Obs.] Spenser.
A species of poem of a mournful character, in which a singlemourner expresses lamentation; a song for one voice.
A firearm which receives its charge through the muzzle, asdistinguished from one which is loaded at the breech.
One who is versed in metaphysics.
The tissue which fills the cavities of most bones; the medulla.In the larger cavities it is commonly very fatty, but in the smallercavities it is much less fatty, and red or reddish in color.
Of or pertaining to Myrmica, a genus of ants including thesmall house ant (M. molesta), and many others.
An aromatic composite herb, the costmary; also, the SouthEuropean Achillea Ageratum, a kind of yarrow.
The descent of the moon below the horizon; also, the time whenthe moon sets.
To give out doubt and apprehension; to be fearful orirresolute. "My mind misgives." Shak.

A thin cotton, white, dyed, or printed. The name is alsoapplied to coarser and heavier cotton goods; as, shirting andsheeting muslins. Muslin cambric. See Cambric.-- Muslin delaine, a light woolen fabric for women's dresses. SeeDelaine. [Written also mousseline de laine.]
One who, or that which, mows; a mowing machine; as, a lawnmower.
Of or pertaining to the Magi.
A polymeric modification of acrolein obtained by heating itwith caustic potash. It is a crystalline substance having an aromaticodor.

A thousand years; especially, thousand years mentioned in thetwentieth chapter in the twentieth chapter of Revelation, duringwhich holiness is to be triumphant throughout the world. Some believethat, during this period, Christ will reign on earth in person withhis saints.
pl. of Mow, may. [Obs.] Wyclif.
Erroneous or inaccurate quotation.
A flat or somewhat hollowed stone upon which grain or otherfood is ground, by means of a smaller stone or pestle. [SouthwesternU. S. & Sp. Amer.]
A Mohammedan professor or teacher of language. [India]

A class of Vertebrata, lower than fishes, characterized bytheir purselike gill cavities, cartilaginous skeletons, absence oflimbs, and a suckerlike mouth destitute of jaws. It includes thelampreys and hagfishes. See Cyclostoma, and Lamprey. Called alsoMarsipobranchiata, and Marsipobranchii.
One who monishes; an admonisher. [Archaic]
The sun shining at midnight in the arctic or antarctic summer.
A mowing, or that which is gathered by mowing; -- chiefly usedin composition; as, an aftermath. [Obs.]The first mowing thereof, for the king's use, is wont to be soonerthan the common math. Bp. Hall.
A precipitate; a fine substance deposited by precipitation; --applied in old chemistry to certain white precipitates from metallicsolutions; as, magistery of bismuth. Ure.
One who mangles or tears in cutting; one who mutilates any workin doing it.

A hydrocarbon radical, CH3, not existing alone but regarded asan essential residue of methane, and appearing as a component part ofmany derivatives; as, methyl alcohol, methyl ether, methyl amine,etc. [Formerly written also methule, methyle, etc.] Methyl alcohol(Chem.), a light, volatile, inflammable liquid, CH3.OH, obtained bythe distillation of wood, and hence called wood spirit; -- calledalso methol, carbinol, etc.-- Methyl amine (Chem.), a colorless, inflammable, alkaline gas,CH3.NH2, having an ammoniacal, fishy odor. It is producedartificially, and also occurs naturally in herring brine and otherfishy products. It is regarded as ammonia in which a third of itshydrogen is replaced by methyl, and is a type of the class ofsubstituted ammonias.-- Methyl ether (Chem.), a light, volatile ether CH3.O.CH3, obtainedby the etherification of methyl alcohol; -- called also methyl oxide.-- Methyl green. (Chem.) See under Green, n.-- Methyl orange. (Chem.) See Helianthin.-- Methyl violet (Chem.), an artificial dye, consisting of certainmethyl halogen derivatives of rosaniline.

To represent by a map; -- often with out; as, to survey andmap, or map out, a county. Hence, figuratively: To represent orindicate systematically and clearly; to sketch; to plan; as, to map,or map out, a journey; to map out business.I am near to the place where they should meet, if Pisanio have mappedit truly. Shak.
A salt of metaphosphoric acid.
Moonlight. [R.] Clarendon.
A kind of machine gun; -- named after its inventor, Hiram S.Maxim.
The number from which another number is to be subtracted.
A mocking bird. Mocker nut (Bot.), a kind of hickory (Caryatomentosa) and its fruit, which is far inferior to the true shagbarkhickory nut.
A kind of bellflower, Companula Trachelium, once called ViolaMariana; but it is not a violet.
A genus of beetles without wings, but having short oval elytra;the oil beetles. These beetles are sometimes used instead ofcantharides for raising blisters. See Oil beetle, under Oil.
Biting; given to biting; hence, figuratively, sarcastic;severe; scathing.-- Mor*da"cious*ly, adv.
A bog or quagmire. [Obs.] Ainsworth.
A climbing plant (Ullucus officinalis) of the Andes, havingtuberous roots which are used as a substitute for potatoes.

A qualification involving the idea of variation or departurefrom some general rule or form, in the way of either restriction orenlargement, according to the circumstances of the case, as in thewill of a donor, an agreement between parties, and the like. Bracton.
To put in a wrong place; to set or place on an improper orunworthy object; as, he misplaced his confidence.
The act of mollifying, or the state of being mollified; asoftening. Chaucer.
A colorless liquid of an agreeable odor, C6H10O, obtained bydistilling a mixture of sugar and lime; -- so called because formerlyregarded as a polymeric modification of acetone.
The dorsal portion of the metaphorax of insects.
Full of marrow; pithy.

Designated or distinguished by, or as by, a mark; hence;noticeable; conspicuous; as, a marked card; a marked coin; a markedinstance.-- Mark"ed*ly, adv. J. S. Mill. A marked man, a man who is noted bya community, or by a part of it, as, for excellence or depravity; --usually with an unfavorable suggestion.
Misadventure. [Obs.]
Resembling mycelium.
Wrongly taught; as, a mistaught youth. L'Estrange.
To perplex greatly; to bewilder; to astonish and confuse; toamaze. South.

Pertaining to, produced by, or exhibiting, certain changeswhich minerals or rocks may have undergone since their originaldeposition; -- especially applied to the recrystallization whichsedimentary rocks have undergone through the influence of heat andpressure, after which they are called metamorphic rocks.
Muscular. [Obs.] Jonhson.
In a masterful manner; imperiously.A lawless and rebellious man who held lands masterfully and in highcontempt of the royal authority. Macaulay.
The process or operation of obtaining the mercury, in its fluidform, from mercuric minerals.
A nearly pellucid variety of feldspar, showing pearly oropaline reflections from within. It is used as a gem. The bestspecimens come from Ceylon.
To translate erroneously.
A genus of nemertean worms, parasitic in the gill cavity ofclams and other bivalves. They have a large posterior sucker, likethat of a leech. See Illust. of Bdellomorpha.
Manganese.
A South American rodent (Cavia rupestris), allied to the Guineapig, but larger; -- called also rock cavy.

The process of giving an orange color to goods formed of animaltissue, as silk or wool, not by coloring matter, but by producing acertain change in the fiber by the action of dilute nitric acid.Tomlinson.
Same as Moodir.
Coarse plain India muslins.
Clouded with, or as with, mist.
A genus of South American monkeys, including the howlers. SeeHowler, 2, and Illust.
To provide with a motive; to move; impel; induce; incite. --Mo`ti*va"tion (#), n.  William James.
A fabled monster, half man and half bull, confined in thelabyrinth constructed by D√¶dalus in Crete.
The laws of organic formation.
One of a religious congregation of the Roman Catholic Churchdevoted to the improvement of Armenians.
Mistakenly zealous. [Obs.]
Skill of a marksman.
To assign wrongly.
Many-minded; many-sided.The multanimous nature of the poet. J. R. Lowell.
Tending to mitigate; mitigating; lentitive. Johnson.

A process, invented by P. Ostberg, for producing malleable ironcastings by melting wrought iron, to which from 0.05 to 0.1 per centof aluminium is added to lower the melting point, usually in apetroleum furnace, keeping the molten metal at the bubbling pointuntil it becomes quiet, and then pouring the molten metal into a moldlined with a special mixture consisting essentially of molasses andground burnt fire clay; also, a casting made by this process; --called also wrought-iron casting.
Slavery; involuntary servitude. [Obs.] Johnson.
A lozenge voided.
An order of curious parasitic worms found on crinoids. The bodyis short and disklike, with four pairs of suckers and five pairs ofhook-bearing parapodia on the under side.
Unmanageable.[R.]
In many different ways; variously.
The post or office of a monitor.
The act of making a mummy.
The middle of the night; twelve o'clock at night.The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve. Shak.
A composer of verses. [Obs.]
Having the nose of medium width; between leptorhine andplatyrhine.
Lady; mistress; -- used by Hindustani-speaking natives in Indiain addressing European women.
Aspect; air; manner; demeanor; carriage; bearing.Vice is a monster of so frightful mien, As, to be hated, needs but tobe seen. Pope.
One of a middle or intermediate class in some schools andseminaries.
An old Scotch silver coin; a mark or marc. [Scot.]
A light, volatile liquid, H2C(OCH3)2, regarded as a complexether, and having a pleasant ethereal odor. It is obtained by thepartial oxidation of methyl alcohol. Called also formal.
One of a group of univalve shells, having a large aperture ormouth.
A million ergs; a megerg.
A place for mooring.
A hydrous sulphate of iron of a green color and vitreousluster; iron vitriol.
A book giving an account of monasteries.

An extinct, hairy, maned elephant (Elephas primigenius), ofenormous size, remains of which are found in the northern parts ofboth continents. The last of the race, in Europe, were coeval withprehistoric man.
A medicine, or application, which promotes suppuration.
Of or pertaining to manufactures. [R.]
Molluscoid.
Doing mischief; causing harm or evil; nefarious; hurtful. [R.]Chaucer.
The millionth part of one weber.
A person engaged in illicit distilling; -- so called becausethe work is largely done at night. [Cant, U.S.]
That which modifies or qualifies, as a word or clause.
A marine fish having a very slender, flat, transparent body. Itis now generally believed to be the young of the conger eel or someallied fish.
To mistrust. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A sword. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
A minute arachnid, of the order Acarina, of which there aremany species; as, the cheese mite, sugar mite, harvest mite, etc. SeeAcarina.
One whose business is to make sport for others; a buffoon; azany; especially, one who attends a mountebank or quack doctor.
A captain or commander of ten thousand men.
Fit to be mentioned.
Abounding in mast; producing mast in abundance; as, the mastfulforest; a mastful chestnut. Dryden.
A small passageway, as in a mine, that a man may pass through.Raymond.

Of, pertaining to, designating, those compounds of manganese inwhich the element has a lower valence as contrasted with manganiccompounds; as, manganous oxide. Manganous acid, a hypotheticalcompound analogous to sulphurous acid, and forming the so-calledmanganites.
To cause to be like the Mexicans, or their country, esp. inrespect of frequent revolutions of government.
A term of reproach for a low or vulgar labor person. [Slang]

The weight of the half hydrogen molecule, or of the hydrogenatom, taken as the standard in comparing the atomic weights of theelements; thus, an atom of oxygen weighs sixteen microcriths. SeeCrith. J. P. Cooke.
See Bonnet monkey, under Bonnet.
Manageable. [Obs.] Bacon.
Of or pertaining to the lobe of the carapace of crabs coveringthe posterior branchi√¶.
The last day of Carnival; Shrove Tuesday; -- in some cities agreat day of carnival and merrymaking.
One who dislikes.
Perhaps; peradventure. [Prov. or Dialectic]
The celebrating of May Day. "He met her once a-Maying." Milton.
A tract of soft, wet ground; a marsh; a fen. Morass ore. (Min.)See Bog ore, under Bog.
A paper or pasteboard box or shell, wound about with strongtwine, filled with an explosive, and ignited with a fuse, -- used tomake a noise like a cannon. [Written also maroon.]
In a moody manner.
Iron pyrites, or arsenical pyrites; -- so called by the Cornishminers.
Metaphrase.
A salt of moric acid.
Same as Menace. [Obs.]
The god of mockery and censure.
Covered with, or wearing, a moccasin or moccasins. "Moccasinedfeet." Harper's Mag.
One versed in mammalogy.
A bird of the Thrush family.
A growth of minute powdery or webby fungi, whitish or ofdifferent colors, found on various diseased or decaying substances.
To make wet or moist. [R.]
The three membranes that envelop the brain and spinal cord; thepia mater, dura mater, and arachnoid membrane.
The whole body of soldiers; soldiery; militia; troops; thearmy.

The act or process of putting a mast or masts into a vessel;also, the scientific principles which determine the position ofmasts, and the mechanical methods of placing them. Masting house(Naut.), a large building, with suitable mechanism overhanging thewater, used for stepping and unstepping the masts of vessels.
A salt of myristic acid.
The part of the mesoblast which gives rise to the connectivetissues and blood.
Of or pertaining to monastery, or to monastic life.-- Mon`as*te"ri*al*ly, adv.
Excess of words or talk. [R.]
One who mutilates.
A biting quality; corrosiveness. [R.] Evelyn.
A small hammer used by marble workers and sculptors.
The state or condition of being monogynous.

Pertaining to, or resembling, pearl; pearly. Margaric acid. (a)(Physiol. Chem.) A fatty body, crystallizing in pearly scales, andobtained by digesting saponified fats (soaps) with an acid. It wasformerly supposed to be an individual fatty acid, but is now known tobe simply an intimate mixture of stearic and palmitic acids. (b)(Chem.) A white, crystalline substance, C17H34O2 of the fatty acidseries, intermediate between palmitic and stearic acids, and obtainedfrom the wax of certain lichens, from cetyl cyanide, and othersources.
Native hydrous carbonate of copper, usually occurring in greenmammillary masses with concentric fibrous structure.
To copy amiss.
Pertaining to a natural order (Menispermace√¶) of climbingplants of which moonseed (Menispermum) is the type.
Of or relating to the Messiah; as, the Messianic office orcharacter.
A small herbaceous plant growing on muddy shores (Limosellaaquatica).
Mother-of-pearl.

The suppression of a day in the calendar to prevent the date ofthe new moon being set a day too late, or the suppression of thebissextile day once in 134 years. The opposite to this is theproemptosis, or the addition of a day every 330 years, and anotherevery 2,400 years.
A composition of passages detached from several differentcompositions; a potpourri.
A Japanese evergreen rose (Rosa wichuraiana) with creepingbranches, shining leaves, and single white flowers. It is oftenplanted in cemeteries.

The name of one or two trees of the genus Rhizophora (R.Mangle, and R. mucronata, the last doubtfully distinct) inhabitingmuddy shores of tropical regions, where they spread by emittinga√´rial roots, which fasten in the saline mire and eventually becomenew stems. The seeds also send down a strong root while yet attachedto the parent plant.
A white crystalline substance forming the ethyl salt of malamicacid.
A handkerchief. [Obs.]
One who has made a special study of miasma.
A genus of minute flagellate Infusoria of which there are manyspecies, both free and attached. See Illust. under Monad.

Practicing beggary; begging; living on alms; as, mendicantfriars. Mendicant orders (R. C. Ch.), certain monastic orders whichare forbidden to acquire landed property and are required to besupported by alms, esp. the Franciscans, the Dominicans, theCarmelites, and the Augustinians.
A mistress; a wife; -- so used by the illiterate. G. Eliot.
See Mummichog.
A red-colored respiratory pigment found associated withhemoglobin in the muscle tissue of a large number of animals, bothvertebrate and invertebrate.
Migniard. [Obs.]

One of a sect of Christians, the outgrowth of a smallassociation called the "Holy Club," formed at Oxford University, A.D.1729, of which the most conspicuous members were John Wesley and hisbrother Charles; -- originally so called from the methodicalstrictness of members of the club in all religious duties.
A mineral occurring usually in small isolated crystals, --phosphate of the cerium metals.
One who is hired; a hireling; especially, a soldier hired intoforeign service. Milman.
A mandrel.
One who is skilled in mantology; a diviner. [R.]
Any bird of the genus Manucodia, of Australia and New Guinea.They are related to the bird of paradise.
The art and principles of method.
Mirth; frolic; a meeting for mirth; a festival. [Written alsomerrimake.]
The essential material of muscle fibers.
Designating an orange-red dyestuff obtained from naphthylamine,and called magdala red, naphthalene red, etc.
The state or quality of being better; melioration. [Obs.]Bacon.
of Misbede.
Having finlike appendages or flukes instead of legs, as acetacean.
Having many forms, shapes, or appearances.A plastic and multiform unit. Hare.
See Maze. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Infested with mice; smelling of mice.
See Manorial.
To give a wrong color to; figuratively, to set fortherroneously or unfairly; as, to miscolor facts. C. Kingsley.
Moderation. [Obs.] Caxton.
One devoted to the acquisition of wealth or the service ofMammon. C. Kingsley.
Thousandth; consisting of thousandth parts; as, millesimalfractions.
Having mustachios.
See Mollah.
Moresque.
A potato. [Humorous] Thackeray.

The year used by Mohammedans, consisting of twelve lunar monthswithout intercalation, so that they retrograde through all theseasons in about 32¬Ω years. The Mohammedan era begins with the year622 a.d., the first day of the Mohammedan year 1332 begin Nov. 30,1913, acording to the Gregorian calendar.
Minutely muricate.

A speaking or notice of anything, -- usually in a brief orcursory manner. Used especially in the phrase to make mention of.I will make mention of thy righteousness. Ps. lxxi. 16.And sleep in dull, cold marble, where no mention Of me more must beheard of. Shak.
Military. [Obs.] Bacon.
A temporary blindness, or impairment of sight, said to becaused by sleeping in the moonlight; -- sometimes called nyctalopia.
Possessing but one capacity or power. "Monodynamic men." DeQuincey.
See Mongrel.
Winding; having many turns.
Capable of being mixed; mixable; as, water and alcohol aremiscible in all proportions. Burke.
A microscopic form of life; an animal or vegetable organismmicroscopic size.
Being, or having the power to be, present in two or more placesat once.
A person subjected to the influence of animal magnetism. [R.]

A genus of Spherobacteria, in the form of very small globularor oval cells, forming, by transverse division, filaments, or chainsof cells, or in some cases single organisms shaped like dumb-bells(Diplococcus), all without the power of motion. See Illust. ofAscoccus.
Malcontent.-- Mal`con*tent"ed*ly, adv.-- Mal`con*tent"ed*ness, n.
Filled with motes, or fine floating dust; as, the air. "Motedsunbeams." Tennyson.
A meadlike drink. [Obs.]
A vertical water space in a fire box or combustion chamber.
See Moil, and Moile.
The people who lived in the Middle Ages. Ruskin.
In a modal manner.A compound proposition, the parts of which are united modally ... bythe particles "as" and "so." Gibbs.
A measuring rod. Ascham.

Used in, or adapted for, ascertaining measurements, or dividingby measure. Measuring faucet, a faucet which permits only a givenquantity of liquid to pass each time it is opened, or one by means ofwhich the liquid which passes can be measured.-- Measuring worm (Zo√∂l.), the larva of any geometrid moth. SeeGeometrid.
The quality or state of being mensurable; measurableness.
Regard; mindfulness.
. See Mal-.
See Muscle curve, under Muscle.
That branch of science which treats of the development ofelectricity by the action of magnets; -- the counterpart of electro-magnetism.
Of or pertaining to a mass of matter; -- said of the propertiesor motions of masses, as distinguished from those of molecules oratoms. Carpenter.
Science or study of microseisms.
One who makes a motion; a mover. Udall.
Merciful. [Obs.]
See 2d Milt.

A disease characterized by deafness and vertigo, resulting ininco√∂rdination of movement. It is supposed to depend upon a morbidcondition of the semicircular canals of the internal ear. Named afterM√©ni√®re, a French physician.
Consisting of a very great, but indefinite, number; as, myriadstars.
Dominion; rule; command. [R.] Shak.
The country of one's ancestors; -- same as fatherland.
Miasma.
See Malfeasance.
Resembling myrtle or myrtle berries; having the form of amyrtle leaf.
The dorsal portion of the mesothorax of insects.
pl. of Madame and Madam.
Of, pertaining to, or caused by, metastasis; as, a metastaticabscess; the metastatic processes of growth.
A female Moor; a Moorish woman.
Quality of being meaty.
The womb.All that openeth the matrix is mine. Ex. xxxiv. 19.
Without uttering words or sounds; in a mute manner; silently.
To moderate. [Obs.]
A very large red and black butterfly (Danais Plexippus); --called also milkweed butterfly.
Musculation.
That part of the skeleton of the hand or forefoot between thecarpus and phalanges. In man it consists of five bones. See Illust.of Artiodactyla.
Trade; commerce. [Obs.] Bp. Sanderson.

A large cervine mammal (Alces machlis, or A. Americanus),native of the Northern United States and Canada. The adult male isabout as large as a horse, and has very large, palmate antlers. Itclosely resembles the European elk, and by many zo√∂logists isconsidered the same species. See Elk. Moose bird (Zo√∂l.), the Canadajayor whisky jack. See Whisky jack.-- Moose deer. Same as Moose.-- Moose yard (Zo√∂l.), a locality where moose, in winter, herdtogether in a forest to feed and for mutual protection.
See Morintannic.
See Maunder.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid produced artifically asa white crystalline substance, CH2.(CO2H)2, and so called becauseobtained by the oxidation of malic acid.
To be gathered together for parade, inspection, exercise, orthe like; to come together as parts of a force or body; as, hissupporters mustered in force. "The mustering squadron." Byron.
The doctrine or theory of monads.
Any one of several species of sea birds of the genus Uria, orCatarractes; a guillemot.
Wrong collocation. De Quincey.
The collective body of officials or persons of rank in China.S. W. Williams.
To point improperly; to punctuate wrongly.
Same as Mesodermal.
To swear falsely. Same as Mainswear.
See Muscatel, n.Quaffed off the muscadel. Shak.
Doing evil to others; harmful; mischievous.
The condition or quality of being mangy.
A pigment of a green color, the chief constituent of which isoxide of chromium.
The refuse matter which remains after the pressure of fruit,particularly of grapes.
Showing manliness, or manly spirit; hence, brave, courageous,resolute, noble. " Manful hardiness." Chaucer.-- Man"ful*ly, adv.-- Man"ful*ness, n.
A genus of herbaceous or suffruticose plants, chiefly nativesof South Africa. The leaves are opposite, thick, and f
A deep trench around the rampart of a castle or other fortifiedplace, sometimes filled with water; a ditch.
A form of kaleidoscope.
A seismometer for measuring amplitudes or periods, or both, ofmicroseisms. --Mi`cro*seis*mom"e*try (#), n.
A large, pearly, spiral, marine shell (Turbo margaritaceus),from the Pacific Islands. It is used as an ornament.
A bird of Celebes (megacephalon maleo), allied to the brushturkey. It makes mounds in which to lay its eggs.
A kind of brass made in imitation of gold. It contains eightyper cent of copper and twenty of zinc. Ure.
A mace bearer; an officer of a court. P. Plowman.
Having the form or structure of a metal.
A single narrative framed from the statements of the fourevangelists; a gospel harmony. [R.]

Any one of several species of long-tailed, passerine birds ofthe genus Momotus, having a strong serrated beak. In most of thespecies the two long middle tail feathers are racket-shaped at thetip, when mature. The bird itself is said by some writers to trimthem into this shape. They feed on insects, reptiles, and fruit, andare found from Mexico to Brazil. The name is derived from its note.[Written also momot.]
Of or belonging to me; -- used always attributively; as, mybody; my book; -- mine is used in the predicate; as, the book ismine. See Mine.
To mimic. [Obs.] -- Mim"er, n.
Of or pertaining to the mesonephros; as, the mesonephric, orWolffian, duct.
Of or pertaining to the genus Meleagris.
My lord; -- an ecclesiastical dignity bestowed by the pope,entitling the bearer to social and domestic rank at the papal court.(Abbrev. Mgr.)
Erroneous or inaccurate recollection.
To hesitate; to mutter doubtfully. [Obs.]
Capable of being measured; measurable.
A widely dispersed genus of shrubs and trees, usually witharomatic foliage. It includes the bayberry or wax myrtle, the sweetgale, and the North American sweet fern, so called.
The middle of summer. Shak. Midsummer daisy (Bot.), the oxeyedaisy.
Seamanship. [Obs.] Udalt.
Amygdaloid.

A sauce compounded of raw yolks of eggs beaten up with oliveoil to the consistency of a sirup, and seasoned with vinegar, pepper,salt, etc.; -- used in dressing salads, fish, etc. Also, a dishdressed with this sauce.
See Mucedin. [Obs.]

A gum of a crimson color, obtained from a tree (MacarangaIndica) that grows in the East Indies. It is used in takingimpressions of coins, medallions, etc., and sometimes as a medicine.Balfour (Cyc. of India).
See Mamma.
Minor; in the minor mode; as, A moll, that is, A minor.

Of or pertaining to the hand; done or made by the hand; as,manual labor; the king's sign manual. "Manual and ocularexamination." Tatham. Manual alphabet. See Dactylology.-- Manual exercise (Mil.) the exercise by which soldiers are taughtthe use of their muskets and other arms.-- Seal manual, the impression of a seal worn on the hand as a ring.-- Sign manual. See under Sign.
Multiplied by millions; innumerable. [Obs.] Shak.
A minnow.
. An officer of the army holding a rank next above that ofbrigadier general and next below that of lieutenant general, and whousually commands a division or a corps.
The chief magistrate of a city or borough; the chief officer ofa municipal corporation. In some American cities there is a citycourt of which the major is chief judge.
A high explosive similar to lyddite, consisting principally ofpicric acid, used in the French military service.
To fare ill. [Obs.] -- n.

Any of several minute protozoans of the genus Plasmodium (syn.H√¶matozo√∂n) which in their adult condition live in the tissues ofmosquitoes of the genus Anopheles (which see) and when transferred tothe blood of man, by the bite of the mosquito, produce malaria. Theyoung parasites, or sporozoites, enter the red blood corpuscles,growing at their expense, undergoing sporulation, and finallydestroying the corpuscles, thus liberating in the blood plasma animmense number of small spores called merozoites. An indefinite butnot ultimated number of such generations may follow, but if meanwhilethe host is bitten by a mosquito, the parasites develop into gametesin the stomach of the insect. These conjugate, the zygote thusproduced divides, forming spores, and eventually sporozoites, which,penetrating to the salivary glands of the mosquito, may be introducedinto a new host. The attacks of the disease coincide with thedissolution of the corpuscles and liberation of the spores andproducts of growth of the parasites into the blood plasma. Severalspecies of the parasite are distinguished, as P. vivax, producingtertian malaria; P. malari√¶, quartan malaria; and P. (subgenusLaverania) falciferum, the malarial fever of summer and autumn commonin the tropics.

A plant of the Rubia (R. tinctorum). The root is much used indyeing red, and formerly was used in medicine. It is cultivated inFrance and Holland. See Rubiaceous.

One who, or that which, has an appetite for human flesh;specifically, one of certain large sharks (esp. CarcharodonRondeleti); also, a lion or a tiger which has acquired the habit offeeding upon human flesh.

A light silver-white metallic element, malleable and ductile,quite permanent in dry air but tarnishing in moist air. Its compounds occur abundantly, as in dolomite, talc,meerschaum, etc. Symbol Mg. Atomic weight, 24.4. Specific gravity,1.75. Magnesium sulphate. (Chem.) Same as Epsom salts.

A machine for smoothing linen or cotton cloth, as sheets,tablecloths, napkins, and clothing, by roller pressure. Mangle rack(Mach.), a contrivance for converting continuous circular motion intoreciprocating rectilinear motion, by means of a rack and pinion, asin the mangle. The pinion is held to the rack by a groove in such amanner that it passes alternately from one side of the rack to theother, and thus gives motion to it in opposite directions, accordingto the side in which its teeth are engaged.-- Mangle wheel, a wheel in which the teeth, or pins, on its face,are interrupted on one side, and the pinion, working in them, passesfrom inside to outside of the teeth alternately, thus converting thecontinuous circular motion of the pinion into a reciprocatingcircular motion of the wheel.

A moving picture or a moving picture show; -- commonly used inpl. [Slang or Colloq.]

Fit for, or capable of, marriage; of an age at which marriageis allowable.-- Mar"riage*a*ble*ness, n.

A rhythmical succession of single tones, ranging for the mostpart within a given key, and so related together as to form a musicalwhole, having the unity of what is technically called a musicalthought, at once pleasing to the ear and characteristic inexpression.

An optical device for making an indicator diagram for high-speed engines. It consists of a light-tight box or camera having atone end a small convex mirror which reflects a beam of light on tothe ground glass or photographic plate at the other end. The mirroris pivoted so that it can be moved in one direction by a smallplunger operated by an elastic metal diaphragm which closes a tubeconnected with the engine cylinder. It is also moved at right anglesto this direction by a reducing motion, called a reproducer, so as tocopy accurately on a smaller scale the motion of the engine piston.The resultant of these two movements imparts to the reflected beam oflight a motion similar to that of the pencil of the ordinaryindicator, and this can be traced on the sheet of ground glass, orphotographed.
An alkaloid found in opium, and extracted as a yellow amorphoussubstance which is easily decomposed.
One who, or that which, moistens. Johnson.
Like a miss; prim; affected; sentimental.-- Miss"ish*ness, n.

Engaged in warfare; fighting; combating; serving as a soldier.-- Mil"i*tant*ly, adv.At which command the powers militant... Moved on in silence. Milton.Church militant, the Christian church on earth, which is supposed tobe engaged in a constant warfare against its enemies, and is thusdistinguished from the church triumphant, in heaven.
To read amiss; to misunderstand in reading.
To impart metallic properties to; to impregnate with a metal.[R.]
A character which obeys Mendel's law in regard to itshereditary transmission.
In the army, a soldier who feigns himself sick, or who inducesor protracts an illness, in order to avoid doing his duty; hence, ingeneral, one who shirks his duty by pretending illness or inability.
By the microscope; with minute inspection; in a microscopicmanner.
To mew; to molt. [Obs.] Quarles.
To beat with a mall; to beat with something heavy; to bruise;to maul.

A person born of relations between whom marriage was forbiddenby the Mosaic law; a bastard. Deut. xxiii. 2 (Douay version).

To enroll; to enter in a register; specifically, to enter oradmit to membership in a body or society, particularly in a collegeor university, by enrolling the name in a register.In discovering and matriculating the arms of commissaries from NorthAmerica. Sir W. Scott.
The shelf of a mantel.

A very minute plant, one of certain unicellular alg√¶, such asthe germs of various infectious diseases are believed to be.
Infested with moths; moth-eaten. "An old mothy saddle." Shak.
Market; trade. [Obs.] Bp. Sprat.

The European small-spotted dogfish, or houndfish. See the Noteunder Houndfish.

An alcoholate of methyl alcohol in which the hydroxyl hydrogenis replaced by a metal, after the analogy of a hydrate; as, sodiummethylate, CH3ONa.
Pertaining to, or in the region of, the lower jaw and the hyoidapparatus; as, the mylohyoid nerve.
Having many branches.

Pertaining to, or designating, a compound of tin (metastannicacid), obtained, as an isomeric modification of stannic acid, in theform of a white amorphous substance.

A slender European weed (Galium Cruciata); -- called alsocrossweed.

, abbreviation of Amuck. To run a muck. See Amuck.

A child born of a white father and Indian mother. [S. Amer.]

Having more than one axis; developing in more than a singleline or plain; -- opposed to Ant: monoaxial.

To give bad counsel to.
One who, or that which, mitigates.

To bring the mouth or muzzle near.The bear muzzles and smels to him. L'Estrange.
One of the larger measures of force, amounting to one milliondynes.
Wonderful. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the Monera.

A member of the Congregation of Saint Maur, an offshoot of theBenedictines, originating in France in the early part of theseventeenth century. The Maurists have been distinguished for theirinterest in literature.

An albuminous body present in dead muscle, being formed in theprocess of coagulation which takes place in rigor mortis; the clotformed in the coagulation of muscle plasma. See Muscle plasma, underPlasma.

Having but one finger or claw.

sing. of Mores.

Like, or suitable to, a monk. [R.]

To cause to act through an agent or to hold a subordinateposition; to annex; -- specifically applied to the annexation duringthe former German empire of a smaller German state to a larger, whileallowing it a nominal sovereignty, and its prince his rank.The misfortune of being a mediatized prince. Beaconsfield.

A peculiar malignant disease, occurring in parts of the westernUnited States, and affecting certain kinds of farm stock (esp. cows),and persons using the meat or dairy products of infected cattle. Itschief symptoms in man are uncontrollable vomiting, obstinateconstipation, pain, and muscular tremors. Its origin in cattle hasbeen variously ascribed to the presence of certain plants in theirfood, and to polluted water.

Of or pertaining to management or a manager; as, managerialqualities. "Managerial responsibility." C. Bront√©.

Any neuropterous insect of the genus Mantispa, and alliedgenera. The larv√¶ feed on plant lice. Also used adjectively. SeeIllust. under Neuroptera.

A church of a monastery. To value wrongly or too little; to undervalue.But for I am so young, I dread my work Wot be misvalued both of oldand young. W. Browne.

Consisting of or containing matter like honey; -- said ofcertain encysted tumors.

A white fluid secreted by the mammary glands of female mammalsfor the nourishment of their young, consisting of minute globules offat suspended in a solution of casein, albumin, milk sugar, andinorganic salts. "White as morne milk." Chaucer.
To spend amiss or for wrong purposes; to aquander; to waste;as, to misspend time or money. J. Philips.

In a metameric manner.
One of the Malacostraca.
Magniloquent. [Obs.]
A word of one syllable.
An old name for mosses in the widest sense, including the truemosses and also hepatic√¶ and sphagna.
Raving with madness; raging with disordered intellect; affectedwith mania; mad.

The act of process of applying manure; also, the manureapplied.
A musket-proof shield of rope, wood, or metal, which issometimes used for the protection of sappers or riflemen whileattacking a fortress, or of gunners at embrasures; -- now commonlywritten mantlet.
Being without a moon or moonlight.

Any plant of the genus Mitella, -- slender, perennial herbswith a pod slightly resembling a bishop's miter; bishop's cap. Falsemiterwort, a white-flowered perennial herb of the United States(Tiarella cardifolia).

A nobleman in England, France, and Germany, of a rank nextbelow that of duke. Originally, the marquis was an officer whose dutywas to guard the marches or frontiers of the kingdom. The office hasceased, and the name is now a mere title conferred by patent.
of Mistake.

Imitating, esp. in derision, or so as to cause derision;mimicking; derisive. Mocking bird (Zo√∂l.), a North American singingbird (Mimus polyglottos), remarkable for its exact imitations of thenotes of other birds. The name is also applied to other species of thesame genus, found in Mexico, Central America, and the West Indies.-- Mocking thrush (Zo√∂l.), any species of the genus Harporhynchus,as the brown thrush (H. rufus).-- Mocking wren (Zo√∂l.), any American wren of the genus Thryothorus,esp. T. Ludovicianus.
Having the cotyledons of a dicotyledonous embryo confluent, andforming a large mass compared with the rest of the body. Henslow.

A little world; a miniature universe. Hence (so called byParacelsus), a man, as a supposed epitome of the exterior universe orgreat world. Opposed to macrocosm. Shak.
Consisting of a single carpel, as the fruit of the pea, cherry,and almond.

A day, May 30, appointed for commemorating, by decorating theirgraves with flowers, by patriotic exercises, etc., the dead soldiersand sailors who served the Civil War (1861-65) in the United States;Decoration Day. It is a legal holiday in most of the States. In theSouthern States, the Confederate Memorial Day is: May 30 in Virginia;April 26 in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, and Mississippi; May 10 inNorth Carolina and South Carolina; the second Friday in May inTennessee; June 3 in Louisiana. Consisting of many, or of more than one; multiple; multifold.Multiplicate flower (Bot.), a flower that is double, or has anunusual number of petals in consequence of the abnormalmultiplication of the parts of the floral whorls.

An East Indian curry soup.
One who mumbles.

A genus of endogenous plants found in tropical America, andsome species also in India. They have tuberous roots containing alarge amount of starch, and from one species (Maranta arundinacea)arrowroot is obtained. Many kinds are cultivated for ornament.
Belonging to the table; transacted at table; as, mensaconversation.

Like, or pertaining to, the genus Myxine.-- n.

A low shrubby tree of the genus Pistacia (P. Lentiscus),growing upon the islands and coasts of the Mediterranean, andproducing a valuable resin; -- called also, mastic tree.

Of or pertaining to merchants, or the business of merchants;having to do with trade, or the buying and selling of commodities;commercial.The expedition of the Argonauts was partly mercantile, partlymilitary. Arbuthnot.Mercantile agency, an agency for procuring information of thestanding and credit of merchants in different parts of the country,for the use of dealers who sell to them.-- Mercantile marine, the persons and vessels employed in commerce,taken collectively.-- Mercantile paper, the notes or acceptances given by merchants forgoods bought, or received on consignment; drafts on merchants forgoods sold or consigned. ,fr. March, v. Marching money (Mil.), the additional pay ofofficer or soldier when his regiment is marching.-- In marching order (Mil.), equipped for a march.-- Marching regiment. (Mil.) Bearing in mind; regardful; attentive; heedful; observant.What is man, that thou art mindful of him Ps. viii. 4.I promise you to be mindful of your admonitions. Hammond.-- Mind"ful*ly, adv.-- Mind"ful*ness, n.

To cause to be swallowed up; to immerse; to sink; to absorb.To merge all natural ... sentiment in inordinate vanity. Burke.Whig and Tory were merged and swallowed up in the transcendent dutiesof patriots. De Quincey.

of Menge.

One who meliorates.

The act of mesmerizing; the state of being mesmerized.
Pertaining to a mesentery; mesaraic.

A white or buff-colored granular powder,
One whose motive is to please men or the world, rather thanGod. Eph. vi. 6.

Pertaining to, connected with, or dependent upon, bothmechanics and chemistry; -- said especially of those sciences whichtreat of such phenomena as seem to depend on the laws both ofmechanics and chemistry, as electricity and magnetism.

The mesial plane dividing the body of an animal into similarright and left halves. The line in which it meets the dorsal surfacehas been called the dorsimeson, and the corresponding ventral edgethe ventrimeson. B. G. Wilder.

A colorless, fragrant liquid, C6H3(CH3)3, of the benzene seriesof hydrocarbons, obtained by distilling acetone with sulphuric acid.-- Me*sit`y*len"ic, a.

A small European fresh-water cyprinoid fish (Phoxinus l√¶vis,formerly Leuciscus phoxinus); sometimes applied also to the young oflarger kinds; -- called also minim and minny. The name is alsoapplied to several allied American species, of the genera Phoxinus,Notropis, or Minnilus, and Rhinichthys.
Having teeth of moderate size.
To learn wrongly.
A voltaic series of two or more large plates, producing a greatquantity of electricity of low tension, and hence adapted to theexhibition of electro-magnetic phenomena. [R.]
Mode, or manner, of living; hence, a temporary arrangement ofaffairs until disputed matters can be settled.
A phylum of the vegetable kingdom consisting of the classMyxomycetes. By some botanists it is not separated from theThallophyta.
One who monopolizes; one who has a monopoly; one who favorsmonopoly.
Resembling mucus; having the character or appearance of mucus.
Of or pertaining to meloplasty, or the artificial formation ofa new cheek.

One who molests.
A West African monkey (Cercopithecus cephus). It has yellowwhiskers, and a triangular blue mark on the nose.

The condition of an ovule having but a single embryo.-- Mon*em`bry*on"ic, a.

Malmsey wine. See Malmsey. " A jub of malvesye." Chaucer.
An extinct genus of small Triassic mammals, the oldest yetfound in European strata.
One who mumms, or makes diversion in disguise; a masker; abuffon.Jugglers and dancers, antics, mummers. Milton.
Serving to aid; ministering.
An alloy consisting of copper, nickel, tungsten, and aluminium;-- used by jewelers.

An immensely long blackish seaweed of the Pacific (Macrocystispyrifera), having numerous almond-shaped air vessels.
Full of moisture. [R.]

Falling in small drops; mistling; mizzing. [Obs.] Arbuthnot.

Same as Manila.

A piano having a mechanical attachment which enables the playerto prolong the notes at will.

To christen wrongly.
The decimal part of a logarithm, as distinguished from theintegral part, or characteristic.

One of the aboriginal inhabitants of New Zealand; also, theoriginal language of New Zealand.-- a.
Matrimony. [Obs.]
The state of being murky.

discontented; uneasy; dissatisfied; especially, dissatisfiedwith the government. [Written also malecontent.]The famous malcontent earl of Leicester. Milner.

Any of certain basslike marine fishes (mostly of tropical seas,and having a deep, compressed body, protracile mouth, and largesilvery scales) constituting the family Gerrid√¶, as Gerres plumieri,found from Florida to Brazil and used as food. Also, any of numerousother fishes of similar appearance but belonging to other families.

Having only one sepal, or the calyx in one piece or composed ofthe sepals united into one piece; gamosepalous.

Movement; manner of movement; particularly, movement withincreased rapidity; -- used especially in the phrase con moto,directing to a somewhat quicker movement; as, andante con moto, alittle more rapidly than andante, etc.

The third month of the year, containing thirty-one days.The stormy March is come at last, With wind, and cloud, and changingskies. Bryant.As mad as a March Hare, an old English Saying derived from the factthat March is the rutting time of hares, when they are excitable andviolent. Wright.
A monomial.
The tarsius, or spectral lemur.
Fitly; suitably; properly.
A word having more than one form of the root.

A genus of trees of Southern India and Northern Africa. Onespecies (Moringa pterygosperma) is the horse-radish tree, and itsseeds, as well as those of M. aptera, are known in commerce as ben orben nuts, and yield the oil called oil of ben.
One who, or that which, magnifies.

A cake of unleavened bread eaten by the Jews at the feast ofthe Passover.

Of or pertaining to matricide.
Any one of several species of small American cyprinodont fishesof the genus Fundulus, and of allied genera; the killifishes; --called also minnow. [Written also mummychog, mummachog.]
Five hundred; as, a mease of herrings. [Prov. Eng.]
To mix in a disorderly way; to make a mess of. [Obs.] Udall.
of Mortify.

The posterior division of the foot in the Gastropoda andPteropoda.
An implement for digging and grubbing. The head has two longsteel blades, one like an adz and the other like a narrow ax or thepoint of a pickax.'T is you must dig with mattock and with spade. Shak.
To be dull and spiritless. "Moping melancholy." Milton.A sickly part of one true sense Could not so mope. Shak.
One who has metromania.
To paint or tinge with red lead or vermilion; also, to decoratewith letters, or the like, painted red, as the page of a manuscript.T. Wharton.

Having machicolations. "Machicolated turrets." C. Kingsley.

An optical phenomenon sometimes seen on the summit of mountains(as on the Brocken) when the observer is between the sun and a massof cloud. The figures of the observer and surrounding objects areseen projected on the cloud, greatly enlarged and often encircled byrainbow colors.
The practices of a mountebank; mountebankery.
To supply with food. [Obs.] Tusser.His shield well lined, his horses meated well. Chapman.

A large American pike (Esox nobilitor) found in the GreatLakes, and other Northern lakes, and in the St. Lawrence River. It isvalued as a food fish. [Written also maskallonge, maskinonge,muskallonge, muskellonge, and muskelunjeh.]
A ball or globe forming part of the regalia of an emperor orother sovereign. It is encircled with bands, enriched with preciousstones, and surmounted with a cross; -- called also globe.

Any one of numerous small birds belonging to Pipra, Manacus,and other genera of the family Piprid√¶. They are mostly natives ofCentral and South America. some are bright-colored, and others havethe wings and tail curiously ornamented. The name is sometimesapplied to related birds of other families.
Of or pertaining to the mesopodialia or to the parts of thelimbs to which they belong.

A kind of oil formerly used in dressing the hair; -- so calledbecause originally obtained from Macassar, a district of the Islandof Celebes. Also, an imitation of the same, of perfumed castor oiland olive oil.
To get a wrong idea of or about; to misunderstand.
A salt of methionic acid.
A genus of African siluroid fishes, including the electriccatfishes. See Electric cat, under Electric.
The act or process of medicating.
In a modest manner.

Same as Mackintosh.

Of or pertaining to a mean or average; mean; as, medialalligation.

With a medium fullness of sound.

One of a mixed white and Indian people living in parts ofTennessee and the Carolinas. They are descendants of earlyintermixtures of white settlers with natives. In North Carolina theCroatan Indians, regarded as descended from Raleigh's lost colony ofCroatan, formerly classed with negroes, are now legally recognized asdistinct.
Disarranged; rumpled. [Colloq. U.S.]
A measure of but a single foot.
A lemur; -- applied to several species, as the White-fronted,the ruffed, and the ring-tailed lemurs.
To dispose in due order, as the different quarterings on anescutcheon, or the different crests when several belong to anachievement.
A magpie. [Obs.] Shak.
A tubercle projecting from the anterior articular processes ofsome vertebr√¶; a mammillary process.
Having the character or appearance of both mucus and pus.Dunglison.
A duck (Cairina moschata), larger than the common duck, oftenraised in poultry yards. Called also musk duck. It is native oftropical America, from Mexico to Southern Brazil.
The conductir of a mule team; also, a head shepherd.
To act or treat as a monkey does; to ape; to act in a grotesqueor meddlesome manner. To monkey with, to handle in a meddlesomemanner. [Colloq.]
Having many, or several, colors.
Abounding with mines; like a mine. "Miny caverns." Thomson.
Of or relating to the Medici, a noted Italian family; as, theMedicean Venus. Medicean planets (Astron.), a name given by Galileoto the satellites of Jupiter.

Much. [Obs.]
To make malleable.
A murderer. [Obs. or Prov.]

The transference of the relation between one set of objects toanother set for the purpose of brief explanation; a compressedsimile; e. g., the ship plows the sea. Abbott & Seeley. "All theworld's a stage." Shak.
The outermost of the three small auditory bones, ossicles; thehammer. It is attached to the tympanic membrane by a long process,the handle or manubrium. See Illust. of Far.
Divided into many chambers by partitions, as the pith of thepokeweed.
Any right whale, or whalebone whale. See Cetacea.
Ill desert. [Obs.] Spenser.
To furbish up for sale; to set off to advantage. [Obs. or R.]B. Jonson.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a sulphonic (thionic) acidderivative of methane, obtained as a stable white crystallinesubstance, CH2.(SO3H)2, which forms well defined salts.
To make in an ill form. Spenser.
One of the Mammalia. Age of mammals. See under Age, n., 8.
A powerful tribe of North American Indians that formerlyoccupied the region of Georgia, Florida, and Alabama. Theyconstituted a large part of the Creek confederacy. [Written alsoMuscogees.]
Manganous.
See Amenuse. [Obs.]
See Mun.
An error; a mistake. Shak.
The wife of a margrave.
Magistracy. [Obs.]
Bad execution. D. Webster.
One of the dark race inhabiting principally the islands ofEastern Polynesia. Also used adjectively.

Of or pertaining to Mecca, in Arabia.-- n.
An earthy black oxide of copper, arising from the decompositionof other ores.
Capable of being mended.

A seaweed. See Baddrelocks.
Evil; wicked; bad. [Obs.] Marston.
Any one of a series of complex nitrogenous substances regardedas derived from one molecule of urea; as, alloxan is a monureid.[Written also monureide.]

An order or subclass of cryptogamous plants; the mosses. SeeMoss, and Cryptogamia.
Same as Malicho.
Of or pertaining to the morn; morning. [Obs.] "White as mornemilk." Chaucer.
The state of being a master; hence, disposition to command orhector. C. Bront√©.
Memory. Memoria technica, technical memory; a contrivance foraiding the memory.
An exhibition in which an actor sustains many characters.
Idiocy; fatuity; stupidity.
Of or pertaining to the Macrura; having a long tail.
A kind of sweet bread or biscuit; a cake of pounded almonds andsugar. [Obs.]marzipan Shak.
A form of spore, usually elongate or falciform, and somewhatamoboid, produced by segmentation of the schizonts of certainSporozoa, as the malaria parasite.
One who mesmerizes.
A process projecting backward and downward from the acromion ofthe scapula of some mammals.

To make war; to fight; to contend; -- usually followed byagainst and with.These are great questions, where great names militate against eachother. Burke.The invisible powers of heaven seemed to militate on the side of thepious emperor. Gibbon.
A hipped curb roof; that is, a roof having on all sides twoslopes, the lower one being steeper than the upper one.

A small animal of Java (Paradoxirus fasciatus), allied to thecivets. It swallows, but does not digest, large quantities of ripecoffee berries, thus serving to disseminate the coffee plant; henceit is called also coffee rat.
Of or pertaining to Modena or its inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.
In the game of pinochle, to declare or announce for a score;as, to meld a sequence.
The thousandth part of one amp√®re.
A fine kind of leather, prepared commonly from goatskin (thoughan inferior kind is made of sheepskin), and tanned with sumac anddyed of various colors; -- said to have been first made by the Moors.
Driven or actuated by a motor, esp. by an individual electricmotor. An electric motor forms an integral part of many machine toolsin numerous modern machine shops.
A remarkable variable star in the constellation Cetus (o Ceti).
Metalorganic.
A mineral of an iron-black color, and very sectile, consistingprincipally of sulphur, antimony, and silver.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, molybdenum; specif.,designating those compounds in which molybdenum has a lower valenceas contrasted with molybdic compounds.
A writer of martyrology; an historian of martyrs. T. Warton.
The century plant, a species of Agave (A. Americana). SeeAgave.
An alley where there are stables; a narrow passage; a confinedplace. [Eng.]Mr. Turveydrop's great room... was built out into a mews at the back.Dickens.
Every moment; from moment to moment. Shenstone.
A hamper to be carried in the hand; a hand basket used incarrying grapes to the press.
Madam; my lady; -- a colloquial contraction of madam often usedin direct address, and sometimes as an appellation.
A wrong allotment.
The small entrails of a calf or a hog.
Having a husband; married. [Obs.]
A thick woolen fabric, watered or with embossed figures; --used in upholstery, for curtains, etc.
